story:
A 17 year old Gaia DS student wrote a script and we must bring it to life. It's that simple.

"Spirit of the World" is about the destruction of the Earth and Tree of Life told through myth and music. Ancient characters play for power in a biblical apocalyptic world.

Please support Gaia Democratic School--we produce AMAZING ORIGINAL MUSICAL THEATER totally created by youth. It is so important that young people can express themselves creatively. It makes their self confidence, teamwork abilities, and academic skills grow immensely, while having fun!

In addition to a profound, hilarious, original script, we have an eager and talented cast (ages 5-19) and director (age: 42 and feeling it), a wonderful performance space--Intermedia Arts, and musicians willing to donate time and music.

We need money to rent performance space and tech stuff, hire helpers, and get prop/costumes supplies. We also need snacks for hungry performers. We plan to do at least 3 shows for the public May 23,  24, 25, 2014.

Please note: We are into GREEN THEATER meaning we use recycled/reclaimed materials for over 90% of our needs in producing this show.

Gaia Democratic School is a small, independent, private school for K-12 grade students. We operate democratically and encourage students to be active in their own education. Gaia DS supports each student's right to learn in ways that best fit their unique learning styles, interests, and abilities. Gaia DS believes in freedom--of expression, movement, speech, intellect, and to choose what and how to learn.

I couldn't get the following to work on my Bio page so here is a list of youth plays/musicals I have had the honor of directing over the years:

Mayday Festival stage (1990) We did an anti-garbage burner show.

Persephone's Descent (at Playwrights Center, 1993) This was a collection of short performances that was based on a writing class. One piece was entirely made up of conversations overheard in the Hard Times Cafe.

Enter At Your Own Risk (1995) Southern Theater: An original collaboratively written show in partnership with Project Offstreets' Kulture Klub (Homeless Youth)

I Wrote This Play to Impress My Parents (1996) at the Southern Theater Original & collaboratively written, mostly by Erin Tate, who is now the Drummer for the band Minus the Bear. I played a psycho mother & Jay H. was a wingnut cop. There was a live snake at the end.

Circus Maximus (1997-8) An original collaboratively written circus themed-show, multiple performance sites, including Mpls. City Parks--also when the GYM MURAL was first painted.

Damn Fine Casserole (Peoples Center & Bedlam, 2001) An original collaboratively written show about stereotypes featuring fantasizing housewife Alberta smashing dishes & Eliot as Suzie--a beautiful, suicidal, suburban, princess. William was an alligator, Mae was Martha Stewart, & Jazmin was the gay boy, Billy. Casey was the statue of Liberty & I’m pretty sure she “gave birth” to Eliot at the end & then came the cherry jello placenta, yum.

Hodgepodge (Bedlam, 2002) A collection of random one acts by SFS students, including Helen & Marvel's "Toast" & Emme’s first play with SFS.

Rocky Horror Picture Show (Walker Church, 2003) with all live music by the Eliot (who also played Meatloaf), Luke, Klaus, (ala Dangerboy & the Road Vultures or Tornado!) & Travis, Charlie as Frank, Emily & Jazmin as Janet & Brad, Emme & Isaac as Majenta & Riff Raff, Ben as the Investigator. Shadow puppets! Absolutely so much fun!

MaskRaid (Walker Church, 2004) An original collaboratively written show based on twisted versions of Wizard of Oz, Alice & Wonderland, Where the Wild Things Are... Awesome, original music by Travis, Anna as the Queen of Hearts (that plastic wig!), Tre as "genderless" Alix, Johann as Max, and Martha/Emme as Good/Bad Alice. Marina spoke the sacred tree poems & Isaac was The Man with Plan. There was a Barbie Army?!

The Bacchae (Varsity, 2005) Starring Andre (who is teaching in Poland now) & many amazing madwomen including Wonder Woman played by Ariel (previously Annie) Pinkerton. Using the Wole Soyinka translation from the ancient Euripides script, we added characters, humor, & music by Starri, Kata & Dimitry. As one of the very first shows at the now-popular Varsity venue, it was a stunning environment for our tribute to the God of Wine and Dance. Remember the sheep? & Mike describing the sheep? Jake & his Village people line. Dru & his bursting appendix, making me think the madwomen had truly eaten him alive.

Wonderland  (Bedlam, 2006)    Emme & I were both fascinated by the amusement park that was in our South Minneapolis neighborhood 100 years ago (Lake St. & 31st). We began to research & create characters, scenes, & songs based on our discoveries. We shot a video in the cemetery where some of the displayed incubator babies are buried. Music by Eatin' Hogeye, Emme, & Starri. Highlights: the church ladies & preacher man, the street kids, Eeka & ElDiablo, the crazy doctor & smoking nurse, the fortune teller & Xelias Aerial Arts.

Fools Eye or the Adventures of the Joyfully Disturbed (Bedlam 2007) We wrote this script entirely from dreams! There was also a lot of Tarot ideas. Highlights: Hassan as Pepsi-makes-me-fly guy, Luna as Kitty, Light & Dark, Sandman, Riva’s zillion costume changes, the hermit video of commercials taking over dreams & Emme’s video of the ocean, Ian as the “bad man” (scary!) and the lovely whisperers.

Goodbye Berlin: Cabaret with Liberty Taken (Bedlam, 2008) music director: Mark Garcia...and those great musicians. We took the short story turned play turned movie turned broadway musical, old classic & rewrote it---making it even more intense than it was before! Highlights: the gorilla head/s, 2 Ladies, the German crystal available in the lobby, the blue rabbit coat, the chair dance & the Hard Knock Life Kids. Remember Nara’s tomorrow!? Wow.

Crybaby (Bedlam, 2009) music director: Mark Garcia & those awesome musicians again! With Riva & Marissa as Johnny Depp/Crybaby & Allison & the Walker family/gang  played by: Calem (Ramona), Treana (HatchetFace), Jadeen (IggyPop), Emme as Pepper & Rainy & Nara as her kids & Kimmy as Lenore.............I just know we would have made John Waters proud! Classic 1950’s music. So many highlights!!!

3 (an original tragedy in fractions at Peoples Center, 2010) Collaboratively written by Emme, Jadeen, Bree, Riva, Starri based on mythology & heartbreak,the Selkie & the unicorn, the gollum, centaur & Bird, of course. From the press release: Let us take you on a magical, dismal journey that transcends time and space! Blending fantasy, mythology, and science fiction to create a series of epic adventures throughout the ages, "3" features: a beautiful spirit stolen by vampires, a bride and groom parted by a jealous, malicious god, two star-crossed, drugged-up,genetically-altered, futuristic lovers, one mysterious troubadour-witch, and a swarm of fickle, wicked fairies.

MUSIC BOX (People's Center Theater, 2011) Collaboratively created coming of age story set in Minneapolis-- a rollicking, magical-realism adventure exploring the dreams & memories of 4 life-long friends, featuring ghosts, thieves, unreal twins, & a mighty strange musical Wizard.

And the Devil Will Drag You Under an original production led by Bree McPherson with music by Lady of the Red Heart starring Sage Doring as the Devil himself, Bree, Sara Anderson, Sadie Morris, Zion Braveheart, Sophia Stenwick, Baylee Floyd as Angela , Jeune Mayer as Diablo. Jack & Joe were hilarious!

Down the Rabbit Hole- a mash up of Alice in Wonderland, Through the Looking Glass, and The Matrix. Live Music with Johnny, brilliant costumes by Erin, and all around fabulousness by all cast!

story:
Our Ask...

  • My name is Farnaz Ehtessabian. After 15 years of teaching Math and being present to how the challenge of Algebra changes a child's motivation, my dream was to make Algebra simple and clear for those who struggle with it.
  • Inspired by the many successes transforming students' relationship with Math, I now have a calling to put this in the hands of the low-income student. 
  • Our ultimate goal is to give this comprehensive system away to at least 10,000 underserved students in America. Your support will help us start this journey.
  • Research shows...the more you challenge your mind to learn, the more your brain cells grow.  The key to growing the brain is practice. Algebra is a powerful exercise for strengthening the brain, it is a critical gateway to higher level math and the pathway to college enrollment, consequently into a better job market.
  • Math is the building block to so many areas; people who do better in math, do better in music, learning new languages, taking standardized tests, and better at getting along with others.
  • Together we can make a difference...Give a child a chance for a better life. "Give a man a fish; and you feed him for a day;                                                                  Show him how to catch fish; and you feed him for a lifetime.”     

                                                                                                 Chinese Proverb

Our Mission Statement 

            "To inspire self-confidence and enhance higher order thinking skills..."

  • AlgebraCards...transforming the Art of Teaching.
  • Embracing this knowledge, learning these concepts, in this most natural way, will instill within the student a greater overall knowledge and a confidence that may be seen throughout the individual's development, career and life

What We Need & What You Get

  • Your contribution can get AlgebraCards into the hands of kids in underserved communities. Support in Education is rewarding:
    One person can make a difference in the world. In fact, it is always because of one person that changes which matter in the world come about.  This is an amazing feel good experience!
In addition, this is a system that can actually bring Parents and Children together. They are meant to be shared, and therefore even parents will find themselves getting a great 'brain workout' and BONDING in an unexpected way with their kids. 

    Our Challenges

    Reaching out to those who find Algebra difficult and challenging is not an easy task.  As an independent company we have a lot of obstacles - Exposure & Funding in particular are always a challenge. However, with your support, we can serve the many students who need help for Algebra, creating the possibility to change lives.

    Please Visit www.AlgebraCards.com

    By giving students the opportunity to use these cards in conjunction with the podcast for each card, concepts can be reachable, more easy to grasp so homework can be done. 

    Your contribution can keep this powerful learning tool within reach of a lot of folks. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you just can't contribute that doesn't mean you can't help!!

      • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
      • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

      For more information on all things please visit www.AlgebraCards.com

      THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR GETTING THIS FAR!

      NOW LET'S MAKE SOME INSPIRING & POWERFUL STUFF HAPPEN!

story:
Dear all,

Some of you might know me through Facebook and some of you might have met me in person playing in the same orchestra or music ensemble. I'm Vincent Kok, born and raised in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. I grew up in an average family, and chasing my dream to be a musician has not been easy for me.

I was a founding member of the Malaysian Philharmonic Youth Orchestra (MPYO) and I received a full scholarship from the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory of Music, National University of Singapore soon after I graduated from Malaysian Institute of Art (MIA) in 2009.


Life has been a roller coaster for me since the very first day as a conservatory student. The teachers, friends, competition and environment had shaped me to become a stronger and better person and musician. Alongside with my studies, I was given the opportunity to help out in the conservatory's Ensemble Office as acting Assistant Orchestra Manager during my last year of school.

Amongst scheduling rehearsals for orchestra, I got to work with visiting artitsts as well as students from different conservatory. My interest in arts administration grows tremendously ever since and it opened up a brand new vision for me thus I see myself more likely to be in the managerial roll of an arts organization (e.g orchestra).



After graduation, I continued to work with other orchestras and organizations like the Metropolitan Festival Orchestra and Symphony 92.4FM (Singapore's first and only classical music station). I'm glad that my performance is being recognized and I want to learn more so that I can contribute in this niche industry, where musicians can continue their passion and the public can get to enjoy more quality performances.


I'm in the midst of applying to the University of Agder, Norway, to get my Master Degree in Music Management. However, I'm stumbled on a major financial issue. Despite the generous free education that offered by the Norwegian government, I need to fork out NOK 97,850 equivalent of USD 15,904 to prove to the immigrant authorities I'm capable of living in Norway for a year without having to work. This is a huge sum of money for any average Malaysian families and my family definitely couldn't afford it.

Therefore I seek for your generousity and make my trip to Norway possible!

Thank you and Terima Kasih!

story:
Project Summary

Trash Talk Recycled: INDIA GO GO

We are puppeteer, Maggie Winston, and musician/writer, Laura Barron.  For years, we've collaborated on a variety of community art projects throughout Vancouver.  And now, we are excited to introduce Indiegogo users to our trans-continental youth theatre project,Trash Talk Recycled.  

Both of us have been deeply moved by the people and places that we have experienced on our travels to India.  However, we also share concerns about the trash problems that we have observed while visiting this fascinating and complex country.  So, these have inspired us to develop an arts-based youth program that will allow students to explore their feelings about the concept of "trash" in our world and in ourselves (i.e.“trash thinking.”)

To realize this exciting vision, we will be leading a series of theatre, puppetry and music activities with students at Ramana's Garden School in Rishikesh, India, during Feb/March 2015, investigating ideas of self-image and identity. Artist facilitator Maggie Winston was introduced to the Ramana's Garden School in 2010 when she came to Rishikesh to study meditation and spirituality. She is now a disciple of Sri Prem Baba of Brazil, who gives spiritual teachings in the Vedic Tradition (Saccha Baba Lineage) at Saccha Dam Ashram in Rishikesh, India. And this arts initiative is inspired by these teachings, following the principles of the "Awaken Love" project. http://www.sriprembaba.org/en/the-birth-of-awaken-love.   

During our arts engagements, we will use interactive theatre techniques, drawing upon true-to-life situations, and facilitating open dialogue to inform the artistic product. The information gathered from these exercises will be used to create a puppet that will represent each participant.  Then, stories will be devised for the puppets and the actors to play out. The students will also compose music to accompany their narrative content. And all engagements will lead to a final performance that will ultimately be shared with fellow students and local community members.  Finally, most appropriately, all of the musical instrument and puppetry elements will be created out of found objects (trash) and reclaimed materials, collected from the students' environment.

Prior to our arts engagements in Rishikesh, we will also lead the same activities with students in Southeast Vancouver, who will communicate with the students in India by initiating a pen pal letter exchange.  Like their Indian peers, this primarily South Asian neighbourhood has limited access to the arts and many children do not often have the opportunity to engage themselves in creative activities. We expect this rich cultural exchange to foster understanding between these children, about similarities and differences in each other's lives.  

What We Need & What You Get

Fortunately, all of our workshop expenses ($8,760) in Vancouver and India have already been covered by the non-profits, Instruments of Change (instrumentsofchange.org) and ArtStarts (artstarts.com).  So, we are only asking our Indiegogo supporters to help us raise enough funding to cover our travel expenses to India ($4,000 TOTAL).

In exchange, you will enjoy profuse thanks from the student and facilitating artists, as well as a range of music, puppetry and spirituality-related gifts of appreciation (depending on your level of contribution).

    The Impact

    By participating in Trash Talk Recycled:

    ·  Students, through truthful investigations during the art-making process, will develop an understanding of themselves in relationship to large global issues affecting the environment- identifying personal responsibility.

    ·  Students will also have a greater understanding of themselves in terms of the ways in which they might “trash” their own or others' thoughts and feelings.

    ·  Vancouver students will have the rare opportunity to develop relationships with students at Ramana's Garden (a school for orphaned children in Rishikesh, India), building empathy within both groups.

    ·  Students will gain experience and confidence by creating an original collaborative performance that they can acknowledge as their own.

    ·  Students will develop working/playing relationships with the artists, each of whom has established community ties in the neighborhoods where both the Vancouver and Indian schools are located.

    ·  Students may be inspired to involve themselves in future social/environmental activism.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that not everyone is in a position to make a financial contribution.  So, we invite each of you to spread the word about our campaign through Indiegogo's share feature, and through your social media channels.
story_txt:
Project Summary

Trash Talk Recycled: INDIA GO
GO

We are puppeteer,
Maggie Winston, and musician/writer, Laura Barron.  For years, we've collaborated on a variety of community art projects throughout Vancouver.  And now, we are excited to introduce Indiegogo users to our trans-continental youth theatre project,Trash Talk Recycled.  
Both of us have been deeply moved by the people and places that we have experienced on our travels to India.  However, we also share concerns about the trash problems that we have observed while visiting this fascinating and complex country.  So, these have inspired us to develop an arts-based youth program that will allow students to explore their feelings about the concept of "trash" in our world and in ourselves (i.e.“trash thinking.”)



To realize this exciting vision, we will be leading a series of theatre, puppetry and music activities with students at Ramana's Garden School in Rishikesh, India, during Feb/March 2015, investigating ideas of self-image and identity. Artist facilitator Maggie Winston was introduced to the Ramana's Garden School in 2010 when she came to Rishikesh to study meditation and spirituality. She is now a disciple of Sri Prem Baba of Brazil, who gives spiritual teachings in the Vedic Tradition (Saccha Baba Lineage) at Saccha Dam Ashram in Rishikesh, India. And this arts initiative is inspired by these teachings, following the principles of the "Awaken Love" project. http://www.sriprembaba.org/en/the-birth-of-awaken-love.   
During our arts engagements, we will use interactive
theatre techniques, drawing upon true-to-life situations, and facilitating open
dialogue to inform the artistic product. The information gathered from these exercises
will be used to create a puppet that will represent each participant.  Then, stories
will be devised for the puppets and the actors to play out. The students will also compose music to accompany their narrative content. And all engagements will lead to a final
performance that will ultimately be shared with fellow students and local
community members.  Finally, most appropriately, all of the musical instrument and puppetry elements will be
created out of found objects (trash) and reclaimed materials, collected from the students' environment.




Prior
to our arts engagements in Rishikesh, we will also lead the same activities with
students in Southeast Vancouver, who will communicate with the students in India by initiating a pen pal letter exchange. 
Like their Indian peers, this primarily South Asian neighbourhood has
limited access to the arts and many children do not often have the opportunity
to engage themselves in creative activities. We expect this rich cultural exchange to foster understanding between these children, about similarities and differences in each other's lives.  





What We Need & What You Get
Fortunately, all of our workshop expenses ($8,760) in Vancouver and India have already been covered by the non-profits, Instruments of Change (instrumentsofchange.org) and ArtStarts (artstarts.com).  So, we are only asking our Indiegogo supporters to help us raise enough funding to cover our travel expenses to India ($4,000 TOTAL).In exchange, you will enjoy profuse thanks from the student and facilitating artists, as well as a range of music, puppetry and spirituality-related gifts of appreciation (depending on your level of contribution).

  The Impact
By participating in Trash Talk Recycled:
 
·  Students, through truthful investigations during the art-making process, will develop an
understanding of themselves in relationship to large global issues affecting
the environment- identifying personal responsibility. 
·  Students
will also have a greater understanding of themselves in terms of the ways in
which they might “trash” their own or others' thoughts and feelings.
·  Vancouver students will have the rare opportunity to develop relationships with students at Ramana's Garden (a school for orphaned children in Rishikesh, India), building empathy within both groups.
·  Students
will gain experience and confidence by creating an original collaborative
performance that they can acknowledge as their own.
·  Students
will develop working/playing relationships with the artists, each of whom has established community ties in the neighborhoods where both the Vancouver and Indian schools are located.
·  Students
may be inspired to involve themselves in future social/environmental activism.


 Other Ways You Can Help
 We understand that not everyone is in a position to make a financial contribution.  So, we invite each of you to spread the word about our campaign through Indiegogo's share feature, and through your social media channels.

story:
Our Story

Hello CMCers! About a year ago a bunch of CMCers -- Dan Taylor ('04), Miles Orton ('04), Nicolas Heidorn ('06) -- were sitting around drinking some beers (of course) at a quasi-political event (of course). Somehow a discussion broke out over how few people know much of anything about the Federalist Papers today, even though the debates of that era remain relevant in many contexts -- for instance, what role should the federal government play over the states in taking on health care reform? The conversation later meandered to how cool it was that CMC (through the Keck Center) allowed students to compete to do research and write a paper in certain areas, but that once you had the money it could be a bit hard to be motivated to write an awesome paper with so many other commitments clammoring for attention. We put two and two together and the Federalist Project was born! 

 

The Federalist Project is an essay competition: students must submit 8-14 page papers on any topic relating to the Federalist or Anti-Federalist Papers and the winning essay wins $1000. The winner will be given his award along with graduating Seniors at the awards ceremony.

The Impact

The hope is that this essay competition will help spur further interest in the Federalist Papers. Also, we hope this will put more emphasis on CMC's gov department, one of our school's traditional strengths that of late has been a bit overshadowed by the econ department. Curse you, highly successful econ department!

What We Need & What You Get

We decided to set the essay prize at $1000, the same amount as the Keck Center fellowships and an amount we hope will encourage a good number of applicants. Thus, we need to raise $1000! All the money goes straight to CMC so is tax-deductible.

 

But, that's not all, in addition to that you get:

 

Under $20: the pride and bragging points of having supported the alma mater!

$20-$50: a poster of the essay competition!

$50+: the option of being one of our essay judges!

Other Ways You Can Help

Know any other CMCers, particularly Gov Majors? Spread the word!

story:
Since 2009, thinkpeace workshop for girls has been inspiring girls to use their voices and actions to create peace in their homes, schools, communities, and the world.   

By exploring the self through yoga, journaling, art, and discussion girls are able to discover their inner voice and passions.  By collaborating on outreach projects, story telling, performance pieces, and more, girls are able to discover the power they have when they join their voices with girls worldwide.  

Thinkpeace girls learn skills that truly empower them to be agents of change in the global girl community:

  • accepting self and others
  • communicating effectively
  • resolving conflicts
  • understanding intercultural differences

We need your help!

We believe that camps and workshops need to be filled with girls reflecting the diversity of the real world. We would like our workshops to be available to girls from the inner city and rural areas as well as suburban communities.  In 2012 we personally funded 5 scholarships to our summer camp.  These 5 girls brought a diversity to the group that reinforced our belief that similarities and differences should all be valued and celebrated. Every voice is vital to the peacemaking process.  In 2013 we will include at-risk girls to our thinkpeace community, a group of girls who are rarely given the opportunity to learn how to 'be the change' they wish to see in their communities. Every dollar of every donation goes directly towards the cost of the scholarships we offer.

The Impact

The strength, confidence, knowledge and relationships each girl leaves our camps and workshops with is only the beginning. Thinkpeace girls become agents of change in the world in very unique ways. From California to Germany our girls have embraced art activism as a means to raise awareness about the ongoing genocides around the world.  They have collected undergarment donations and have sewn cloth sanitary napkins and belts for women and girls in Haiti, Zimbabwe and Uganda.  They have launched enironmental animal cruelty awareness campaigns.  They have held community bicycle rides/fundraisers on behalf of girls in Afghanistan and other countries who are not allowed the freedom felt from riding a bike. They have campaigned to end the practice of child marriage and have been ardent supporters of a girl's right to an education.

Giving Back 

Your donation to our program has a ripple effect.  After attending a thinkpeace workshop, girls are required to continue with a project or cause that strikes a chord within her, 'Paying it Forward' by giving back to her community or to an global project.  We work with the girls to help them achieve their goals, create connections with other organizations they can volunteer with, or help fund their projects.  

We believe that peace begins with a girl!

story:
About Us: El Congreso de UCSB

An activist Chican@/Latin@ student organization and recognized official M.E.Ch.A. Chapter at UCSB, compromised of committees which address various areas of interest. Congreso strives through its workshops, programs, and conferences to support, defend, and assist the needs of Chican@/Latin@ students and the local community.We are a diverse community of people (indigenous, immigrant, multi racial/ethnic, etc.) actively working against homophobia, racism, sexism, and the many other oppressive isms that exist today. We continue on with the struggle, keeping the legacy of the Chican@ movement alive.

Raza College Day

Twenty-Two years ago, El Congreso organized Raza College Day, a conference to address the lack of Chican@ Latin@ Students at the university. Currently, out of all the students enrolled at UCSB, fifty four percent are students of color, half of which identify as Chican@/Latin@ students. Despite the University of California, Santa Barbara being the only UC in the tri-county area, only eleven percent of the student body at UCSB consists of students from San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Ventura, and Kern counties. Based on these statistics, El Congreso continues to see the need to offer local students a conference that will introduce students to the UCSB campus and the overall processes of higher education.

Raza College Day is a one-day event that targets underprivileged families in the community by introducing them to the processes of higher education and encouraging them to begin thinking, planning, and exercising the necessary steps to acquire a higher education. We aim to create an environment that is not only educational, but personal and empowering as well. Transportation is provided for students from their high schools, junior high schools, and community colleges. The agenda is composed of workshops that will emphasize the importance of preparing for the university, admissions, financial aid, academics, community activism, and other issues that are of concern to students. A number of distinguished community members will be presenting to the students as well. The event provides lunch, culturally relevant entertainment, and most important of all, the inspiration these students need to understand that they too can make it to a university!

As a student-organized outreach event, we are responsible for raising our own funds each year. As traditional funding sources on campus are no longer available due to continued budget cuts, we now rely on generous individuals like yourself to fund this crucial outreach program. A long standing and popular event, Raza College Day hosts four to five hundred students each year. While the event is free to the students, the total cost of campus facilities, materials, keynote speakers, lunch and transportation total to $23,000. Of course, no donation is too small, and we would appreciate whatever you could provide.

We hope you can help us continue the legacy and inspiration of Raza College Day, and help us, “keep the doors open for those yet to come”

Thank You!

story:
My Story:

  • My name is Anais DeLosSantos and I am a high school Junior with a passion for cinema and art. I live in Hillsborough New Jersey and was just accepted to study experimental film and sculpture over the summer at the San Francisco Art Institute. I get to fully immerse myself in a rigorous art program with other teens just as enthusiastic about creating. Pre-college is five weeks long and I will receive college credits. With the course I get to learn from the amazing teachers at SFAI and get a taste of life in art school. 

What I Need:

  • The entire cost of the 5-week program, including room and board plus meal plan, is $5,000. My goal is to try and raise as much of that as I can.  I will need to  pay for transportation costs from New Jersey to California, as well as art supplies and living expenses for the 5 weeks. I will be taking film and sculpture classes, as well as meeting teachers from SFAI and learning about their program. I'm hoping to also get a partial scholarship from SFAI, but not many are available. 

Why I Need this:

  • This pre-college program is a once in a life time opportunity I never thought I could accomplish. I get to study what I love in an amazing city that I have only seen in photographs. What I am most looking forward to is finally meeting talented peers who I can connect to and collaborate with. With your help I can begin the first steps in my career as an artist. Thank You!

story:
Short Summary

On 3/15/12, I, Kyle Ray, received an email with the following statement:

"Congratulations, you have been accepted to participate in the 2012 Fall program at University of Canterbury in New Zealand."

Going abroad to study has been a hope of mine for several years and I have been offered the opportunity to do so. Any contributions I receive will be used toward additional expenses that financial aid does not cover. These fees include airfare, meals over in New Zealand, books and materials, housing goods - such as bedding, toiletries, medication, etc. - and the occasional entertainment if time permits. Your contributions will be greatly appreciated and no form of gratitude would be enough to express my thanks.

I am a Computer Information Systems major at Sage College of Albany. I am taking a semester abroad to further my cultural and self-intellect. This opportunity is one that I am unwilling to pass up, but I am in need of assistance from all of my family, friends and neighbors.

What I Need & What You Get

The following is a breakdown of fees that come as additional costs to the program:

  *   Airfare: $2,500

  *   Meals: $1,500

  *   Books: $500

  *   Housing Goods: $250

  *   Entertainment: $250

Some of these expenses are adding some leniency in case of emergency when I am abroad and add to a total of $5,000.

With every contribution - big or small - I will be one step closer to affording something very important to me.

The following perks will serve as incentives to make a contribution:

  *   With a $25 donation, you will receive a postcard around midterm time.

  *   With a $50 donation, you will receive monthly email updates on my experiences and a postcard around midterm time.

  *   With a $100 donation, you will be invited to a presentation dinner after my return to the U.S., monthly email updates on my experiences and a postcard around midterm time.

  *   With a $250 donation, you will receive the opportunity to visit places of interest with me - well your likeness on a "Stanley" doll that is! – you will be invited to a presentation dinner after my return to the U.S., monthly email updates on my experiences and a postcard around midterm time.

  *   With a $500 donation, you will receive a piece of original artwork created by myself, you will receive the opportunity to visit places of interest with me - well your likeness on a "Stanley" doll that is!, you will be invited to a presentation dinner after my return to the U.S., monthly email updates on my experiences and a postcard around midterm time.

The Impact

This chance to study Computer Science at the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand is an opportunity that I had previously only dreamed of.

I will begin my travels on June 26th from Los Angeles, CA and will be in New Zealand from June 29th to November 10th on a nineteen week term. Although my studies will consume most of my time abroad, I know this opportunity will be life changing and a period of enormous personal growth.

Other Ways You Can Help

As I realize that not everybody can afford to make a contribution, I ask those of you to spread the word of my intent to study abroad to you family, friends and neighbors. The more help I can get, the easier this experience will become.

I give advanced thanks to those of you who contributed to this opportunity. I am looking forward to sharing my experiences with all of you.

story:
Equalize Warped Tour!

After attending Warped Tour in 2008 and not finding any gender or sexual minority representation in their non-profit area, I saw not only a gap, but an opportunity to bring about a massive change in the music community.  I founded Equalize, an organization dedicated to educating music fans about issues that affect the sexual and gender minority communities and giving folks (both LGBTQ and straight allies!) the tools to create positive changes in the world.

I've always felt that I've had to keep my sexuality and gender identity, my passion for social justice, and my music separate from each other, but through Equalize, I've discovered that there are so many people like me in the world that want to mix the three together.  We want to create a safe space not only in places like the Warped Tour, but the world as a whole, where people can be themselves, no matter who they are or whom they love.

We have attended Warped Tour in Portland every year since we started, but it's time to Equalize the east coast!  With your help, we will be attending six dates of the tour in some of the largest cities in the country: New York, Boston, DC, and more, starting conversations about equality with literally thousands of young music fans, as well as providing a place for people to express who they are completely.

 

Going on Tour

All of the Equalizers going on Mission: Equalize Warped Tour have been on the road before.  We know how to cut costs while still ensuring a safe and healthy tour.  Our budget of $2500 includes transportation to Boston, where we will be starting, a rental car to get us from city to city, gas, food, admission, supplies, literature, and merchandise.

Being an Equalizer doesn't just mean standing up against oppression for people in the LGBTQ community, but for the planet as a whole!  So, during the tour, we will be doing what we can to have as small an impact on the environment as possible.  These measures include getting a car with a high MPG, and making a commitment to produce as little food product waste as we can by having reusable containers and utensils for everyone.

 

Making Equalizers

The campaign we are taking on tour with us is the Equalizer Pledge. 


Equalizing is all about inspiring people to start conversations with people who will inspire others to start conversations with people and those people will start more conversations and...you get the idea.  We know that every person makes a difference, because we have witnessed it so much in our own lives.
Being an Equalizer is a way to bring positive changes to the world in a way that anyone can do!

In Portland, we have started thousands of conversations already.  From conferences to concerts, panels to parties, Equalize has reached out to more than we can count.  Our NO HOMO(PHOBIA) shirts and stickers alone spark meaningful interactions on a daily basis!



Beyond just getting people talking, we also offer leadership opportunities for youth and young adults.  We are starting up a street team program where young music fans across the nation can learn how to be leaders in their own communities and organize events, actions, and workshops.  Many of the Equalizers we meet at shows travel hours from small towns and rural areas where there aren’t many opportunities to safely discuss sexuality or gender identity; starting a street team will give them a way to do this.  In larger cities, even ones known for being gay-friendly, street teams will give people a chance to find each other and work together in new ways to uplift their communities.


Either Way, Namaste!

Whether or not you contribute to our campaign, please share the message through the Indiegogo share tools, and the old fashioned way.  Every conversation started is a win, every person we connect to a victory.

Also, please be sure to “like” our Facebook - http://www.facebook.com/equalizeit - and share it with your friends.

Thank you so much for your time, and for any and all contributions. See you at Warped!
story_txt:
Equalize Warped Tour!
After attending Warped Tour in 2008 and not finding any gender or sexual minority representation in their non-profit area, I saw not only a gap, but an opportunity to bring about a massive change in the music community.  I founded Equalize, an organization dedicated to educating music fans about issues that affect the sexual and gender minority communities and giving folks (both LGBTQ and straight allies!) the tools to create positive changes in the world.I've always felt that I've had to keep my sexuality and gender identity, my passion for social justice, and my music separate from each other, but through Equalize, I've discovered that there are so many people like me in the world that want to mix the three together.  We want to create a safe space not only in places like the Warped Tour, but the world as a whole, where people can be themselves, no matter who they are or whom they love.
We have attended Warped Tour in Portland every year since we started, but it's time to Equalize the east coast!  With your help, we will be attending six dates of the tour in some of the largest cities in the country: New York, Boston, DC, and more, starting conversations about equality with literally thousands of young music fans, as well as providing a place for people to express who they are completely.
 
Going on Tour
All of the Equalizers going on Mission: Equalize Warped Tour have been on the road before.  We know how to cut costs while still ensuring a safe and healthy tour.  Our budget of $2500 includes transportation to Boston, where we will be starting, a rental car to get us from city to city, gas, food, admission, supplies, literature, and merchandise.Being an Equalizer doesn't just mean standing up against oppression for people in the LGBTQ community, but for the planet as a whole!  So, during the tour, we will be doing what we can to have as small an impact on the environment as possible.  These measures include getting a car with a high MPG, and making a commitment to produce as little food product waste as we can by having reusable containers and utensils for everyone.
 
Making Equalizers
The campaign we are taking on tour with us is the Equalizer Pledge. 

Equalizing is all about inspiring people to start conversations with people who will inspire others to start conversations with people and those people will start more conversations and...you get the idea.  We know that every person makes a difference, because we have witnessed it so much in our own lives.Being an Equalizer is a way to bring positive changes to the world in a way that anyone can do!In Portland, we have started thousands of conversations already.  From conferences to concerts, panels to parties, Equalize has reached out to more than we can count.  Our NO HOMO(PHOBIA) shirts and stickers alone spark meaningful interactions on a daily basis!
Beyond just getting people talking, we also offer leadership opportunities for youth and young adults.  We are starting up a street team program where young music fans across the nation can learn how to be leaders in their own communities and organize events, actions, and workshops.  Many of the Equalizers we meet at shows travel hours from small towns and rural areas where there aren’t many opportunities to safely discuss sexuality or gender identity; starting a street team will give them a way to do this.  In larger cities, even ones known for being gay-friendly, street teams will give people a chance to find each other and work together in new ways to uplift their communities.
Either Way, Namaste!
Whether or not you contribute to our campaign, please share the message through the Indiegogo share tools, and the old fashioned way.  Every conversation started is a win, every person we connect to a victory.
Also, please be sure to “like” our Facebook - http://www.facebook.com/equalizeit - and share it with your friends.
Thank you so much for your time, and for any and all contributions. See you at Warped!

story:
I am Lillian Stonecypher, a 13 year old 7th grader. I am a student at Johnson Middle in Bradenton, FL and receive A's and B's with a 3.7 GPA. I was invited by People to People to go on the European Heritage Trip to 7 countries in 22 days. The countries we will be visiting are Austria, Belguim, England, France, Germany, Holland, and Switzerland. This is a really exciting opportunity for me. This is not only a wonderful vacation, but an excellent learning experience. I am really excited about meeting new people and learning about their cultures.

The cost of the trip is $7000. I would greatly appreciate it if you could assist me in getting there and in fulfilling my dreams of world travel.

We leave on June 20th and return July 9th. I will be sharing all my pics with everyone when I return and will tell you all about the trip!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help by spreading the word about my campaign to raise the funds for my trip!

story:
Story: Approximately 8,000+ people have died so far in Nepal, and an additional 17,500+ people have been seriously injured in the 4/25 earthquake, the worst in the country in 81 years. Many thousands of men, women, and children are now homeless, and they are taking shelter in the streets without knowledge of when or where their next meal might come from. 

Nepal is one of the world's poorest countries, and it truly breaks my heart to see the condition they are in right now. The people of Nepal desperately need your help now - more than ever. Please be kind enough to make a contribution.

-----------------------------------------

Who I am: My name is Tsering Wangmo and I am here to raise money for the victims (and their families) of the recent 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Nepal. I was born and raised in Boudha, Nepal until I was 12 years old, therefore this is a cause that is very close to my heart. I am currently working and studying in New York with focus on Health Care Admin. and Nonprofit. 

-----------------------------------------

According to the United Nations, nearly 8 million people in Nepal were significantly affected by this massive earthquake, and 3.5 million people are in need of food assistance immediately.

How you can help: Please donate $25, $50, or $100 here so that we can send the funds for relief as soon as possible. 100% of your contribution will go directly to the American Red Cross' Nepal Earthquake Relief! 

-----------------------------------------

The American Red Cross operates several programs in Nepal, including a community-level disaster response team for emergencies like this. The American Red Cross has teamed up with Nepal Red Cross for the Community Action for Disaster Response program, which will train volunteers from 96 communities in eight districts of Nepal and will benefit thousands of people. 

None of your donations will be used for admin. – I will pay all fees myself.

-----------------------------------------

Thank you all very much for your kind generosity!

story:
Who We Are

ONE STEP INITIATIVE (OSI) seeks out intelligent and engaged young people in inner city high schools. OSI offers them an opportunity to study abroad for two or four weeks at minimal costs to them or their families. Our Team coordinates the selection process with the school administrators and teachers. Next we conduct an introductory meeting between the parents and International Programs experts, followed by a three-phase program designed to teach the importance of leadership, multicultural appreciation, and prepare our young Global Ambassadors for their first journey of a thousand miles. Once returned we require the students to report their experience in a group presentation at their home schools and hopefully, plant a seed of curiosity amongst their peers and the community.



The Story

OSI introduces to our nation's most underserved inner-city high school students study abroad opportunities for college credit.  Our flagship program includes a four-week Spain Language Immersion cultural experience complete with site visits to four Spanish cities and Portugal. Day classes will be held at the University of Salamanca, and students receive 5 college credits in Spanish to apply towards any undergraduate school our global leaders choose to attend. We offer college credit to encourage them to continue their education while developing respect and integrity for another culture.  


Student Highlight

Now in the 12th grade, being Class of 2016 marks a new era in her family’s history. Jessica will become a first generation high school graduate next year, and already has a goal worth smiling about. “I’m going to be the first college graduate in my family. I want to be a dentist. I want to become fluent in Spanish so I won’t have to depend on a translator, and patients can tell me what’s wrong with their teeth.” When asked about her interests in Spain she said the inspiration came from her current Spanish teacher. 

“Senora Hunter told us about her experience in Spain and said it helped her learn and placed her around people so that she could become a better speaker. I really appreciate this experience and don’t take it for granted. I can use this later on in life because I plan to use it in my career. It’s something I’ve wanted to do for a while; I’ve wanted to be a fluent speaker since the 9th grade."

Where it Starts 
Memphis has a high school dropout rate of 30%, with more than 7,000 students leaving the educational system every year. 70 schools in the city are classified as “under-performing”. Most are located in Shelby County's most economically challenged areas.

“The national poverty rate is going down, but the Bluff City’s numbers are climbing, and Memphis’ children are listed among the poorest of the poor.”
(WREG Memphis, 2014)

Majority of Memphis' youth have never traveled outside of the city limits, barely making it beyond their own neighborhoods. Oftentimes the family simply can’t afford to go anywhere else. The OSI program is designed to help disassociate under-performing from lost cause. Every child deserves an opportunity to be great!



The Need & What You Give

  • Cost of attendance for each student: $5,600.
  • Our Goal: $35,000 (5 students, 2 faculty administrators).

Covers the costs of transportation to all social, recreational, and cultural activities in the respective country for five students and two faculty members; housing; meals; multiple city excursions and day trips; admission to museums and national heritage sites, school tuition; medical insurance; transcript services; passport registration; and pre-departure orientation.


The Impact

OSI brings experience-based learning activities to under-privileged youth that would have never been afforded the possibility otherwise. Each additional $35,000 will provide another group of students from another disadvantaged community a chance to take their first step.

OSI's Global Ambassadors will develop a new understanding of how people can better serve their own communities. Upon return they’ll each work to help five of their peers in expanding global awareness. In turn they’ll help five more students, creating a never-ending chain of support for everyone to get the help they need. Every dollar takes us ONE STEP closer to making this dream a reality for some of the nation's most underserved students.

The Journey of a Thousand Miles begins with One Step.........

What would you do if you knew you couldn’t fail?


Sources: Rufener, K. (2014). Memphis ranked as one of the poorest cities in the nation. WREG Memphis. Retrieved from http://wreg.com/2014/09/26/memphis-ranked-as-on.... / Institute for International Education. (2013). U.S. Study Abroad: Student Profile 2000-2013." Retrieved from http://www.iie.org/Research-and-Publications/Open-Doors/Data/US-Study-Abroad/Student-Profile/2000-13

story:
Short Summary

We need your help in sending a group of inner city youth to Egypt this summer.  Our students have raised $196,000, but the cost of the trip is $208,000.  We need your help to raise the remaining $12,000.

African Genesis Institute (www.africangenesis2.org) is a Philadelphia based, 501c-3 “school without walls” that produces a 24-month study program for Black and Latino youth between the ages of 7 and 14.  Our motto is “it is better to build a child than repair an adult”.

During the 24 month program, the students:

  • Attend 10 classes at the African American Museum of Philadelphia,
  • Complete 24 reading and writing assignments from an African history curriculum designed by Dr Edward Robinson, Jabari Osaze and Chike Akua
  • Make oral presentations
  • Travel on 5 field trips in the United States and Canada to sites that are relevant to the history of our people in both countries and
  • Participate in 3 fundraising drives
Once they successfully complete the program, their graduation reward is a free 10-day, life altering trip to Egypt where they can see with their own eyes what they have been learning about for the past 2 years.

What We Need & What You Get

For your generous donation, you will help us take the students to Egypt.  They will return primed for future leadership in our communities.  You will also receive the amazing gifts listed on this site.

The Impact

The results have been impressive:

  • Since inception, we have taken over 2000 students to the African continent
  • There has been an increase in academic performance, scores on standardized tests and respect for elders
  • There has been a dramatic decrease in absenteeism, lateness and incidences of disruptive behavior
  • 97.2 % of our graduates attend college, many on 4-year fully paid scholarships

Risks & Challenges

Without you, this year's trip is in jeopardy!  Don't let the students diligent work go unrewarded! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to make a donation in the amounts listed?  Please go to our website (www.africangenesis2.org) and make a donation in any amount that you are able.  Please share this page and the mission of the African Genesis Institute with you friends and follow us on Facebook.

story:
What is an Onomatopoeia?


Onomatopoeia is a word adopted from the French language "onomatopée". In Japanese, we call them imitative words and mimetic words; "giongo" and "gitaigo". 

Onomatopoeia is used frequently in the Japanese language. For example, the rain is falling heavily "ザーザー(za:za:)" and the stars are twinkling "きらきら (kira-kira)". Undoubtedly every language has onomatopoeia, but it seems that despite the number of words or species, they are not as succinctly used in these other languages as they are in Japanese. That is the reason why the Japanese language is referred to as a language fertile in onomatopoeia.



Speech sounds which express the natural noise of things, such as "buzz", "crackle", "splash", and "wail" are called imitative words. Imitative words are divided into two parts: non-living things' noises, such as "tap" at the door/"トントン(ton-ton)", and the living things' sounds, such as "bow-wow"/"ワンワン(wan-wan)" and "meow"/"ニャーニャー(nya:nya:)".

Mimetic words are speech sounds which describe the soundless movement, condition, and situation of inanimate or living things, including human beings. Mimetic words are divided into three kinds: showing the condition of non-living things, such as "glittering"/"きらきら(kira-kira)" and "slippery"/"つるつる(tsuru-tsuru)", showing the condition of living things, such as "groggy"/"ふらふら(fura-fura)" and "loitering"/"のろのろ(noro-noro)", and showing human feelings, such as "impatiently"/"いらいら(ira-ira)" and "excitedly"/"わくわく(waku-waku)" .

 


About this site



This is teaching material that goes beyond words that never existed before. Most of its features are free and for those who want to get deeper into the world of onomatopoeia, a membership page is available to you for only 500 yen/month.

Japanese people learn these imitative words, mimetic word, and echoic words together with their senses as they grow up. These words are very much rooted in Japanese customs, culture, tradition, and aesthetics, as well as senses. Therefore, once you are able to understand the nuances and grasp the image of these expressions, I am sure you will find your Japanese enriched in various ways.  Furthermore, these words should enable you to get to know us, the Japanese people, better.

 

 

Trustworthiness of the teaching materials

There were two essential tasks for this project.
①How do I correctly understand the meanings of Japanese onomatopoeias?
You might have noticed I am not an expert in linguistics, and it would dangerous to use only my own understanding. I considered using online resources, but I don't have access to the rights of online dictionaries. I decided to contact Meiji University's Professor Masahiro Ono, who has published Japan's largest onomatopoeia dictionary, with 4500 entries.

I presented him with this project and he decided to let me use his data, which later became the foundation for my website. But 4500 words is too extensive and some of these words are outdated, so I  narrowed the scope down to the  450 most important, commonly used words.


 

②Who is going to translate the material?
At first, I met Tokyo Metropolitan University's Professor Jiro Nishigori, who does research in Onomatopoeia and creates websites for non-Japanese speakers himself. He was fascinated by the sample of my website, and introduced me to two alumni of Edith Cowen University in Australia who have Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPY) competence n1 (most difficult level).

I also have a friend who is a program coordinator for the Tokyo International Film Festival, fluent in English, and she gladly decided to do the translation for this project.

 

 

Important materials in this site

What's most important for this website are the visual materials such as animations and illustrations. I am trying to create a website that is not a typical educational website consisting texts, but something that is enjoyable for everyone.
Each one of the materials is high-quality, entertaining, and enthralling.


Each page is divided by categories, and there is wonderful pictures or illustrations.

For each of the 450 words, the page includes  at least one of the following: photos, videos, animations, illustrations or manga. We will choose the most appropriate material for each word.  For example; "Soyo-Soyo", a word that describes the wind softly blowing, is explained with the .gif illustration below:


 

A manga is used when the materials can be explained more easily with a story:

"Biku-Biku"

"Assari"

"Ukkari"

 


What We Need

I do have a financial issue since I am basically the only one working on this website. I want my vision for the quality level to become a reality. This website will not be as valuable without a high level of quality, and acquiring it requires that I pay the creators and artists and that I invest in filming equipment.

For example,let's examine how much it costs to make a hand-drawn animation. I inquired at some of the major studios in Japan, and discovered that it costs about $1,000 ~ $2,000 for a 10 second animation. I researched online and contacted freelancers, explaining to them the concept of this project and the level of payment I could provide. They are very talented and highly skilled Japanese animators and they promised to work with me for about $300 per clip for this website.

The total sum for the animation materials, which covers about 70 words, is 70x$300=$21,000.

At the same time, I am raising funds for translators and supervisors, sound recorders, actors, illustrators and manga artists, also all very important.

I will need to spend a sufficient amount of time and money for the creators who are going to work with me, to avoid having any mistakes in the dictionary and to create an exciting language learning tool like none that has ever existed before.

 


About a membership page.

For only 500 yen (about $5) a month, you can achieve a better understanding of the deeper meaning of Japanese words and their nuances.
Many of the onomatopoeia have similar meanings and it's important to know how each of them are used differently in daily conversations. 
Also, some words sound similar but have completely different meanings. We will prepare special pages that are designed to describe the meanings and explain the contexts of these words. Furthermore, I have a plan to create pages to introduce Japanese gourmet spots, culture, traditions, festivals, and characteristics of specific regions in Japan.

 

 

 

Enjoy Japan!


My dream is to help some very special people:​

People who want to speak Japanese, who are interested in the Japanese culture, who
love Japanese food, who want to find a Japanese friend, who interested in Japanese traditions, manners and customs.
People who love Japanese manga and anime.
People, who do not know much about Japan, but are curious to learn more.
People who are fascinated by language and linguistics and want to learn more about this very unique and beautiful aspect of Japanese language.

I hope that this website will help to enhance and deepen your interests and fascination for Japan.
In the near future, interactions as well as business transactions between people of different cultures and races will become even more important. I decided to create this website in the hope of making such interactions more joyful.

This website is also introduced some food and culture, which are uniquely Japanese, such as a great ramen place, a dye house, a rice field, etc.
​I hope that even more people will have the chance to discover how wonderful Japan is.

Wishing that this will be a fun and waku-waku learning experience for you!

 

 

Release date and completion date

Production for animation clips will start soon after the crowd-funding is complete in February 2017. We will spend the two following  months translating, creating the membership page, shooting and working on the materials.

I will work carefully on each one of them and have around 100 ~ 150 words up on the website. I will add new materials online every 2 to 3 months and plan to have all 450 words up by 2018. And I am planning to have this website in as many languages as possible by Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

 


Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help

Please share this on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube pages. The more people who know about this project, the closer we get to achieving our goal.

And that's all there is to it.

 

 

You can get cool Japanese perks!!

※Some of these perks may take some time until shipment. For the shuuji and the anime character, this should arrive to you sometime between April and July 2017. Time is required because we will make each one of these perks specifically and carefully per your order.

※The colors and patterns of the circular Gakubuchi and Uchiwa may differ depending on when the orders are made.

※Accessories like the food fakes, the key chains, the mini-mini food, and the earrings may also appear differently from the images, depending on order dates and stock.

※Allow me to contact you and ask your preferred Japanese characters and goods for those who will get the "lucky bag".

That is the reason why the Japanese language is referred to as a language fertile in onomatopoeia.
Speech sounds which express the natural noise of things, such as "buzz", "crackle", "splash", and "wail" are called imitative words. Imitative words are divided into two parts: non-living things' noises, such as "tap" at the door/"トントン(ton-ton)", and the living things' sounds, such as "bow-wow"/"ワンワン(wan-wan)" and "meow"/"ニャーニャー(nya:nya:)".Mimetic words are speech sounds which describe the soundless movement, condition, and situation of inanimate or living things, including human beings. Mimetic words are divided into three kinds: showing the condition of non-living things, such as "glittering"/"きらきら(kira-kira)" and "slippery"/"つるつる(tsuru-tsuru)", showing the condition of living things, such as "groggy"/"ふらふら(fura-fura)" and "loitering"/"のろのろ(noro-noro)", and showing human feelings, such as "impatiently"/"いらいら(ira-ira)" and "excitedly"/"わくわく(waku-waku)" .
 

About this site
This is teaching material that goes beyond words that never existed before. Most of its features are free and for those who want to get deeper into the world of onomatopoeia, a membership page is available to you for only 500 yen/month.
Japanese people learn these imitative words, mimetic word, and echoic words together with their senses as they grow up. These words are very much rooted in Japanese customs, culture, tradition, and aesthetics, as well as senses. Therefore, once you are able to understand the nuances and grasp the image of these expressions, I am sure you will find your Japanese enriched in various ways.  Furthermore, these words should enable you to get to know us, the Japanese people, better.
 
 
Trustworthiness of the teaching materials
There were two essential tasks for this project.①How do I correctly understand the meanings of Japanese onomatopoeias?You might have noticed I am not an expert in linguistics, and it would dangerous to use only my own understanding. I considered using online resources, but I don't have access to the rights of online dictionaries. I decided to contact Meiji University's Professor Masahiro Ono, who has published Japan's largest onomatopoeia dictionary, with 4500 entries.
I presented him with this project and he decided to let me use his data, which later became the foundation for my website. But 4500 words is too extensive and some of these words are outdated, so I  narrowed the scope down to the  450 most important, commonly used words.

 
②Who is going to translate the material?At first, I met Tokyo Metropolitan University's Professor Jiro Nishigori, who does research in Onomatopoeia and creates websites for non-Japanese speakers himself. He was fascinated by the sample of my website, and introduced me to two alumni of Edith Cowen University in Australia who have Japanese Language Proficiency Test (JLPY) competence n1 (most difficult level).
I also have a friend who is a program coordinator for the Tokyo International Film Festival, fluent in English, and she gladly decided to do the translation for this project.
 
 
Important materials in this site
What's most important for this website are the visual materials such as animations and illustrations. I am trying to create a website that is not a typical educational website consisting texts, but something that is enjoyable for everyone.Each one of the materials is high-quality, entertaining, and enthralling.

Each page is divided by categories, and there is wonderful pictures or illustrations.


For each of the 450 words, the page includes  at least one of the following: photos, videos, animations, illustrations or manga. We will choose the most appropriate material for each word.  For example; "Soyo-Soyo", a word that describes the wind softly blowing, is explained with the .gif illustration below:
 A manga is used when the materials can be explained more easily with a story:
"Biku-Biku"

"Assari"

"Ukkari"

 

What We Need
I do have a financial issue since I am basically the only one working on this website. I want my vision for the quality level to become a reality. This website will not be as valuable without a high level of quality, and acquiring it requires that I pay the creators and artists and that I invest in filming equipment.For example,let's examine how much it costs to make a hand-drawn animation. I inquired at some of the major studios in Japan, and discovered that it costs about $1,000 ~ $2,000 for a 10 second animation. I researched online and contacted freelancers, explaining to them the concept of this project and the level of payment I could provide. They are very talented and highly skilled Japanese animators and they promised to work with me for about $300 per clip for this website.




The total sum for the animation materials, which covers about 70 words, is 70x$300=$21,000.


At the same time, I am raising funds for translators and supervisors, sound recorders, actors, illustrators and manga artists, also all very important.
I will need to spend a sufficient amount of time and money for the creators who are going to work with me, to avoid having any mistakes in the dictionary and to create an exciting language learning tool like none that has ever existed before.
 

About a membership page.

For only 500 yen (about $5) a month, you can achieve a better understanding of the deeper meaning of Japanese words and their nuances.Many of the onomatopoeia have similar meanings and it's important to know how each of them are used differently in daily conversations. Also, some words sound similar but have completely different meanings. We will prepare special pages that are designed to describe the meanings and explain the contexts of these words. Furthermore, I have a plan to create pages to introduce Japanese gourmet spots, culture, traditions, festivals, and characteristics of specific regions in Japan.


 
 

 
Enjoy Japan!
My dream is to help some very special people:​
People who want to speak Japanese, who are interested in the Japanese culture, wholove Japanese food, who want to find a Japanese friend, who interested in Japanese traditions, manners and customs.People who love Japanese manga and anime.People, who do not know much about Japan, but are curious to learn more.People who are fascinated by language and linguistics and want to learn more about this very unique and beautiful aspect of Japanese language.
I hope that this website will help to enhance and deepen your interests and fascination for Japan.In the near future, interactions as well as business transactions between people of different cultures and races will become even more important. I decided to create this website in the hope of making such interactions more joyful.
This website is also introduced some food and culture, which are uniquely Japanese, such as a great ramen place, a dye house, a rice field, etc.​I hope that even more people will have the chance to discover how wonderful Japan is.
Wishing that this will be a fun and waku-waku learning experience for you!
 
 


Release date and completion date
Production for animation clips will start soon after the crowd-funding is complete in February 2017. We will spend the two following  months translating, creating the membership page, shooting and working on the materials.
I will work carefully on each one of them and have around 100 ~ 150 words up on the website. I will add new materials online every 2 to 3 months and plan to have all 450 words up by 2018. And I am planning to have this website in as many languages as possible by Tokyo 2020 Olympics.
 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help

Please share this on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Youtube pages. The more people who know about this project, the closer we get to achieving our goal.
And that's all there is to it.
 
 
You can get cool Japanese perks!!




















※Some of these perks may take some time until shipment. For the shuuji and the anime character, this should arrive to you sometime between April and July 2017. Time is required because we will make each one of these perks specifically and carefully per your order.
※The colors and patterns of the circular Gakubuchi and Uchiwa may differ depending on when the orders are made.
※Accessories like the food fakes, the key chains, the mini-mini food, and the earrings may also appear differently from the images, depending on order dates and stock.
※Allow me to contact you and ask your preferred Japanese characters and goods for those who will get the "lucky bag".

story:
Il progetto:

Per arginare il dilagare della pseudoscienza, delle truffe e degli inganni, abbiamo deciso, come gruppo regionale dell'Emilia Romagna, di realizzare una serie di trasmissioni dedicate alla scienza e ai suoi metodi per cercare di capire quali siano i suoi limiti e le sue potenzialità. Cercheremo anche di spiegare, in modo semplice e diretto, come leggere e indagare le notizie di tutti i giorni in modo critico ma senza pregiudizi, per comprendere se ci troviamo di fronte ad una verità oppure ad un falso o ad una vera e propria truffa. Abbiamo cominciato con una puntata pilota di 30 minuti, che vorremmo proporre a canali televisivi ed altri media.

Cosa ci serve:

Abbiamo realizzato il programma utilizzando figure professionali, tecnici audio/video, macchinisti e registi che si sono prestati gratuitamente perchè credevano nel progetto e nelle sue potenzialità. Abbiamo speso un po' di soldi, auto finanziandoci, per pagare il noleggio delle studio e il materiale tecnico. Il programma è già stato registrato e montato. 

Ci manca solo la post-produzione per realizzare uno studio virtuale di alto livello qualitativo. Questo impegnativo lavoro richiede strumenti e competenze che vanno pagate (sebbene ci sia stato preventivato un prezzo di favore).

Tutti coloro che contribuiranno, anche con poco, verranno ringraziati nei titoli di coda e avranno la nostra perenne gratitudine!

story:
What is Pay Away the Layaway?

Pay Away the Layaway is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization. Our mission is to create awareness of the "Layaway Angel" movement and to raise funds to help families across the country pay off layaway plans of GIFTS, TOYS and CLOTHES FOR KIDS during the holidays. 

Wait....what is Layaway?

Many stores provide customers the option to purchase items on "layaway". Think of layaway as the opposite of buying something with a credit card.  Layaway puts your items aside at the retailer and you make payments until it is paid in full. Customers who purchase items on layaway earn approximately 15% less than the national average. 

Where is my donation going?

Your tax-deductible donation will help pay off layaway plans in low-income neighborhoods across the United States. All donations pay off layaway plans that ONLY include items for kids, such as toys, blankets, books, games and more. Pay Away the Layaway Angels visit stores such as Kmart, Toys R us, and Babies R Us. You are not alone...we have raised money throughout the United States:

The Impact

The impact your donation makes is truly incredible.  Last year we raised approximately $25,000 and paid for hundreds of layaway plans for kids across the country. Watch our video on our page, or click here to see examples of the "layaway angel" movement: Pay Away the Layaway Video

The Perks

We have multiple perk packages that include a thank you holiday card to be shared on our Facebook Fan Page, a personal hand written letter from the founder of Pay Away the Layaway, and a Pay Away the Layaway Holiday Gift. 

But what about...

Is there something we didn't answer that you are still wondering about? We love getting questions, feedback and even ideas, so please don't hesitate to contact us at donate@payawaythelayaway.com

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you might not be able to contribute financially to our cause, but that doesn't mean you can't help.

Please consider SHARING our cause or our website, www.payawaythelayaway.org with your friends and family on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc.

Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about our organization, cause and mission.  A VERY HAPPY HOLIDAYS TO YOU AND YOUR FAMILY!

story:
Background:

Entrepreneurs’ Organization (EO) is dedicated to promoting and expanding entrepreneurial ethos and to help transform ideas into realities. EO’s Global Student Entrepreneur Awards will launch one young entrepreneur on to his/her next challenge; the GSEA Global Finals. From creating a business plan to turning a profit, each of these CEO’s built successful companies during one of the toughest economies, while taking a full course load of classes. This event is more than a competition; it’s a look at the future of American business, how the game is changing and the new networks of young entrepreneurs that are re-writing the rules.  

The National competition includes students attending college from across the country. The student entrepreneurs will present their companies to world class CEOs, business luminariesand Entrepreneurs’ Organization (EO) members. The winner will go on to the Global Finals in April. 

This year’s US competitors include:

  • Austin White-Pentony, U of M Twin Cities, Tech Bank LLC
  • Blake Marggraff, Washington University in St. Louis, Betaversity
  • Kina De Santis, Champman University, MotorMood LLC
  • Justin Lonis, Hiram College, Lonis, Sheppard & Associates
  • Hunter Crowder, University of South Carolina, Stunt Players Directory
  • Michael Zaengle, Penn State University, GreenTowers LLC
  • Khalid Al-Dhubaib, Case Western Reserve University, Triple Analytics
  • More to be added!


What is EO GSEA?

The Global Student Entreprepreneur Awards (GSEA) is the world's premier student entrepreneur competition.

  • Over 1,600 college students globally applied for EO GSEA last year.
  • Competitions are held in over 20 countries throughout the year.
  • EO GSEA provides students with the opportunity to examine their business, receive valuable feedback, connect with experienced entrepreneurs and collegiate peers.
  • Operated by the Entrepreneurs' Organization and supported by EO members and partners.


How does it work?

Competition flow:

  • Qualifier competition
  • National competition
  • Winners compete at Global Finals
Competition format:
  • Students have timed blocks to prepare, present and respond to questions
  • Intention is to evaluate the "entrepreneur" the "business model" -- with emphasis on the entrepreneur 
  • Judges score and provide written feedback that entrepreneurs are able to apply to their business. Through the organic engagement, judges often become a part of the student's business advisory council.
Evaluation criteria:
  • The Entrepreneur
  • Business Fundamentals
  • Lessons Learned
  • Growth & Future Plans

What does GSEA US Nationals represent?
  • Collegiate pride!
  • Optimism in the American economic recovery
  • Showcasing the positive econimic and social impact American college students are making.
  • Supporting young entrepreneurs on their journey.
  • Playing a vital role in ending youth unemployment.
