story:
Ladies and gentlemen! Sheiks and shebas! Dishes and dames!

After two decades of providing humdinger writing camps for kids, teenagers, and now alumni and adults, YouthWrite is celebrating its Roaring 20th birthday and we want you to be a part of it!

What Is YouthWrite®? 

“[YouthWrite] has been the catalyst for many changes in my life, [helping] me to find my voice.”
- Candice Benson, YouthWrite alumna
YouthWrite® is a camp for kids who love to write... just about anything!© And not just one, but a whole smorgasbord: 

  • The YouthWrite Winter Wordplay weekend camp, at the end of each January in Edmonton.
  • Drawn to Write—a three-day camp for Grades 4–9—in partnership with Happy Harbor Comics each summer.
  • Our week-long YouthWrite Summer Camps happen each July, the first for teens aged 14-19, the second for children aged 11–14, in Bragg Creek and Edmonton, respectively.
  • JustWrite, a summer writing camp designed specifically for alumni and adults.

Courses are designed to provide students many ways to work with words— including songwriting, illustration, screenwriting, journalism, storytelling, fiction writing, poetry, and many more, via instruction from writers, guest presenters, supervisors and volunteers, who gather from across Canada. Campers also participate in a variety of arts, leadership and community-building activities.

Our goals are simple.

  • To foster a thoughtful and literate society for future generations.
  • To provide a safe haven for youth, including those from minority or low-income populations.
  • To encourage young writers to consider the possibilities of the written word.
  • To continue to welcome participants from a variety of backgrounds and increase diversity and inclusion in all our programs.
  • To facilitate a camp that focuses on "process" rather than a “product.” 

We also strive to make the camp accessible to young writers of limited financial means, through the help of sponsors, writing contests, and scholarships.

This is where you come in!

YouthWrite has been operating a whopping TWENTY YEARS and we couldn't be happier! Now's the time for celebration, for us to reflect on where we’ve come from as well as where we’re going.

The truth is YouthWrite® would not be possible without the generous support of our donors (both corporate and individual), alumni, past instructors, supervisors, and other generous community members.

So, we’re looking to you to help us raise some heavy sugar by donating a few of your hard-earned simoleons to this insanely good cause! 

What We Need & What You Get

“What I discovered during my week ... was something completely different. I found myself in an environment where self-expression was encouraged, ideas were never wrong, and passion for the arts was something to be admired.” 
- Heather André, YouthWrite alumna
Many of our past campers, instructors and supervisors will tell you YouthWrite is an incredibly special place. However, putting on a writing camp takes a whole lotta clams, bones, fivers and dough. Any funds raised during this campaign are going directly towards making future YouthWrite programming happen. This includes:

  • Providing materials for classes (paper, pens, pencils, paints, clay, musical instruments, gumboots, laptops, etc.)
  • Helping us publicize the camp to students, teachers and parents all over Alberta.
  • Paying instructor, supervisor, and/or co-ordinator salaries.
  • Facility rentals.
  • And more!

For $600, you can send a kid to camp. Seriously $600 is all it takes to dramatically change a kid's summer and possibly life!

You may be wondering, "Is my donation tax-deductible?" YouthWrite Society of Canada is a registered charity, so for any donation of $40 or more, the answer is yes!

As a thank you for your generosity, we’re offering a variety of perks, including pins, books, plush figurines of our mascot Inkling, one-of-a-kind custom t-shirts, and more, allowing you to wear your YouthWrite pride in style.

Other Ways You Can Help

"YouthWrite is where I learned how powerful words can be. When you're in a room full of people who are sitting and listening to your stories-- whether you tell them through poetry, prose, song, or dance-- those people are implicitly saying that your voice matters. And it does matter. You matter. YouthWrite fosters that notion by creating a space of inclusiveness, festivity, and warmth. YouthWriters take that energy into the world and make it a better place."  

- Charlotte Cranston, YouthWrite alumna, current YouthWrite Supervisor and Edmonton's Youth Poet Laureate

If you’re low on Benjamins or have already made a donation to YouthWrite, fear not! There are other ways you can help!

  • Share this campaign over social media. Any buzz is the bee’s knees!
  • Leave a note in our comments section showing your support!
  • Keep an eye on our website, Facebook, and Twitter to find out more about our Spring Fundraiser, happening in Edmonton in 2016!
  • If you have someone in your life who you think would enjoy YouthWrite, encourage them to look us up. We’re always excited to meet new campers!

Let’s get dapper Inkling and dazzling Quill dancing the Charleston! (Credit for Inkling and Quill illustrations go to the incomparable Spyder Yardley-Jones!)

Hot dog! Thanks for stopping by our campaign! Keep checking in to watch our progress over the rest of the month!

think would enjoy YouthWrite, encourage them to look us up. We’re always excited to meet new campers!

Let’s get dapper Inkling and dazzling Quill dancing the Charleston! (Credit for Inkling and Quill illustrations go to the incomparable Spyder Yardley-Jones!)



Hot dog! Thanks for stopping by our campaign! Keep checking in to watch our progress over the rest of the month!

story:
Versiunea in limba română

We are a team which started an educational project that's been going for 5 years now and hundreds of people came here to learn. Over the years we studied ecological architecture and permaculture design in order to bring you the best quality education in acroecology and natural construction.

Baza Ulmu is a unique permaculture design school where people from all around the world come and learn natural building, no till gardening, food forests and much more useful information following the key permaculture design principles. We are here to give you the right tools and neccessary skills to create your abundant landscape and/or eco-house with all the facilities in order improve the quality of life for you and your family.

Andrei is a designer and passionate eco-builder who teaches natural building. From concept to implementation, anything is possible within reason. 

Lucian can walk you through our no dig, productive food systems and tell you things you never knew about the magic in the plant kingdom. 

Roxi has translated permaculture books and helped with the immigration situation from Africa.

We are dedicated to things that really matter!

Baza Ulmu was created to inspire people of all ages. 

An international project developed by its co-founders and people from all around the world have helped make this dream come true and now we can say it's time to turn this into a public educational space. We bring in permaculture designers and architects as well as eco-builders for courses to teach people how to start their own projects, build their houses or grow their food in a sustainable way. Sometimes entire classrooms of children come here with their teachers and we don't have the necessary facilities to accommodate them. This campaign will help create the right learning conditions for people of all ages and will give an example for other educational projects.

We want to dedicate ourselves full-time to this project that can go on for decades. 

Together we can make a world class permaculture center where people can learn the importance of where their food comes from, agroecology systems, passive solar houses, alternative energy and much more. Everything we've done so far was through our own effort and honest earned money which is quite limited (minimum wage in Romania is 220 euro/month).

Together we can produce valuable video content for everyone! 

“ Come to this place and get to learn some permaculture, some natural building techniques / It’s lovely place in the middle of nature. / With very involved very motivated knowledgeble pleople sharing what they learned in the past years with you”.

                                       TUDOR Petrutiu - Romanian Permaculture Association

What if there was a place like a Hobbit land in the middle of nature where you could come and learn everything you wanted to know about eco-building about permaculture, agroecology, passive solar houses, rocket stoves, plants and animals, growing your own food or sustainability?

What if you could learn all this through online courses made specially for your needs, both from a classroom environment and directly from the field when we go to clients for consultancy.

What if there was also a glamping resort wher you could come and get hosted?

What about a space designed especially for children where adults and children alike could come and learn thru play and non formal education?

In order for you to fully enjoy our educational center we need to build a classroom for the courses, develop the glamping resort for good accommodation, make a communal kitchen and dinning space and built showers. This would make it fit for an educational trip and a summer retreat vacation.

This picture represents "poster A"

“The aim is to teach people how to acomplish these things because now everybody is living in the city and it’s very hard for them to learn these skills, these practical skills. /Using a chainsaw chopping some wood, maybe climbing on a ladder, everything. / What type of wood is a certain tree when you see it, how to use it in a bio-construction.”

                                               Lupse Andrei - designer and co-counder of Baza Ulmu

“I think it’s better to give Idea as soon as possible to the young people, Mr Clint - Tell you the truth. like this they are not contaminated with all they can see all the common things we can see in real life like a big big building and wood and bitumen. / So educate them, I think it’s always a question of education.

/ For all things, all that go bad, I think that education can change it.”

                                                    Ludo  - Ermitaj Malin (the first permaculture center in Romania)

This picture represents "wallpaper A"

It was an amazing experience creating BAZA ULMU, but we are a small team and we can’t do everything on our own. That’s why we ask your help so we can improve the quality of our corses and to build all the facilities needed in order to bring more people in and to make sure that everyone takes home a wealth of information as well as an amazing experience!

  With 10.000 USD we can build a classroom with all the necessary equipment and accommodation for overnight stay for 24 people. 

The cost of the classroom + equipment is 4000 USD

The cost of accommodation huts is 1000 USD/hut x 6 can host 4 people/hut

With 15000USD we could finish the main house, build the classroom, huts and plant our entire food forest and make a new film.

With 20000USD we could have all of the above plus off the grid electricity and the ability to invest in a business that can generate our income so that we can become financially independent.  

From the target of our first campaign we managed to raise approximately $4000

Check out our previous campaign

This should provide us a good start to begin works for the classroom. So far we managed to put forward the necessary papers for creating Baza Ulmu Association, currently an ongoing process. With your help we can do more, we can make applied ecology accessible to everyone.

The fact that we reached almost 40% of our initial goal which was $10000 made us set the goal of this campaign at $6000 which will account for the rest of our initial target. 

Many people are continuously writing about getting the films, courses or other perks which is another reason for our relaunch.

What if you could learn to design natural integrated systems that produce healthy and abundant food indefinitely?

You could meet a lot of people who have the same mindset about ecology.

You could have some hands on experience and practice some skills which they could never do in a classic city classroom.

You could learn how to use some tools like different hand tools and start getting building start to get designing…

Finding solutions for building your home with natural materials and techniques can be difficult.

So is designing a food production system… It’s amazing how many people design and build their houses without considering their health, esthetics or ergonomics.

By choosing the right kind of materials and techniques and learning how to design these natural buildings you could not only save a lot of money but also have a farm where you feel in a holiday year round.

Here you could learn how to use different tools for building, gardening and designing that will help you develop and implement your own plan.

This picture represents "postcard A"

“We offer a variety of couses including whole system design, starfing your own farm, leisure center or building your own house with all the neccesary facilities.”

                                                                      Lupse Lucian - co-founder/media director

What I find really really great at Baza Ulmu is that they-re organising a lot of courses, summer courses, a lot of workshops. / This is quite amazing because this way you can reach a lot of people.

                                                                  Catalin Savin - FEAST Theatre, FEAST Fest  

 

“At our countryside we have another place and it went also as well, almost as well as here and it’s all perfect / We’re starting to grow mushrooms now, and it’s gonna be a promising year for us. / Permaculture should be the Future”

                                                                                  Stefan Veronescu - permaculture student

This picture represents "poster B"

We carefully take every step of our way in order to provide you with two valuable films you can enjoy and get a lot of good information out of.

Film 1 - Baza Ulmu - the journey begins

This film is about our project, how it started up until this very moment. It includes specific information about our design and how everything is interconnected eg: the water from the roof is collected with no visible piping and goes passively into the garden which doesn't need any additional water year round. 

How we've built our permanent raised beds and how we manage them

Tools we use, food forest strategies

Real designs for real clients that we break down with you

Frequently asked questions and more

Film 2  - Bio-construction - how to

This picture represents "wallpaper B"

This film, you guessed it, is about natural building. It includes specific information about earth friendly materials and how to design and build a lasting and beautiful house, but also annexes such as: root cellar, terrace, solar shower, rocket mass heaters, rocket stoves, living roofs and more.

Subjects followed in the film:  What is bio-construction? How to design from scratch or upgrade your home. What you want vs what you need. Maximising resources. Passive solar houses. Different building techniques and materials: Superadobe, cordwood, living roofs, cob, thatch, wood, rocket mass heaters, 

Discussions on designs we made for different clients and situations. Frequently asked questions and many more.

Andrei studied design and ecological architecture and is working with architects and engineers to provide projects for others. 

Lucian studied film making to make all this possible, video is a powerful educational tool and with your help we can make more content in the future.

We've put together a variety of perks to include everyone's possibilities, whether you're a fan or future eco-builder/permaculture designer there is something for everybody.

     If we don't reach our entire goal we will focus on building the classroom and perhaps one or two accommodation huts but it's going to take us a very long time without your help perhaps years. And the films have already entered the production stage so they will be done within our established time frame.

You can be a part of this journey by helping this campaign to reach it’s goal!  

What would you do to help bringing this kind of project to life?

Would you contribute with your donation to bring this kind of place one step closer to reality?

Where almost there it just needs an little extra help from the public who supports this kind of actions. It just needs a little more investment to bring this project to a whole new level.

This picture represents "postcard B"

With your help, we can create an educational space which you and your friends, as well as thousands of other people will enjoy later on by attending our classes. Children need to take part in non formal education as well as ecological education as soon as possible. The outdoors and fresh air as well as healthy food combined with dynamic activities is a winning situation in which kids could learn about the importance of where their food comes from and how to play in an Earth safe environment.

Our project has already gained a lot of media attention and was featured in many newspapers, articles online and tv programmes:

We are always invited for talks in the country and abroad and are active members in the Romanian Permaculture Association. Starting February we will finish the necessary paperwork to create Baza Ulmu Association. 

Risks & Challenges

We will do our very best to finish our entire design of our education centre in a timely manner however it's pretty hard to find skilled workers that are able to stay for a couple of months (commuting is impractical every day because we are 20 km from the city in a mountaneous area). We do almost everything ourselves and are working around the clock sometimes 12 hrs a day rain or shine. Another issue is the films as they are not yet produced. We have about 90% of the video and audio we want to use and are working with a storyboard. However this is the first time we take on such a demanding challenge of completing two films in a matter of months in a 3 people team. Lucian spent around 500 euro only for ALL of the filming equipment including the post production software so cost isn't really an issue. Almost all our footage has been filmed and edited with this equipment.  We are very optimistic! 

We’ve  put together an amazing group of collaborators and partners

Hundreds of volunteers have helped and learned in this center in 5 years!

Now this is where you come in: we are so close of bringing BAZA ULMU SCHOOL to life but we need your support to help complete this project so we can share this knowledge to the world!

Please share our Indiegogo campain on the link bellow,and donate as much as you can in order to help this project come to life!

Meet the team!

 

   Lucian Lupse

Andrei Lupse

Roxana Lupse

 

THANK YOU!       THANK YOU!       THANK YOU!

 

* I really like this crowdsourcing because this is where people can direct their money into things they really like / So I think it’s an honest way to get some funding while other conventional funding systems like EU funds or what not funds, they’re very strict, rigid, they have pretentions. / They don’t neccesarily support a vision while many individuals can help support a vision."

                                                             Tudor Petrutiu -  Romanian Permaculture Association

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word on all social media platforms 

Talk to your friends and family about our project

You can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Follow our journey to keep in touch with new content

Make a difference one step at a time

story:
Akwaaba!

Welcome to the Brigitte & Bobby Sherman Children's Foundation (BBSCF), a nonprofit organization with operations in the cities of Accra and Ada in Ghana, West Africa. Our mission  is to create tomorrow's leaders through education and music. Since our start in 2011, we have built a 5 acre youth center called the Musical Village and currently provide 30 students ages 5 - 15 with a high quality education and music program.  

When we talk about our work, we do not talk about ending the cycle of poverty,   Instead, we talk about starting the cycle of success. Our goal for 2015 is to start the cycle of success for 10 more students, and we need your help. 


Who We Are 

BBSCF has two core beliefs that drive everything we do:

1. We believe that education is the path to a productive, fulfilling life 

2. Music has the power to connect, inspire and heal  

The life experiences of our founders, Brigitte Poublon and Bobby Sherman, truly demonstrate these beliefs. Brigitte used education to lift herself out of poverty and embark on a successful career. Bobby, a popular recording artist in the 1960s and 1970s, personally witnessed the power of music to transform his life and that of his fans.  

But why Ghana? Ghana has vast natural resources and a rich cultural heritage, particularly in music. But almost one-third of its citizens live below the international poverty line.  Education beyond primary school is not attainable for over 60% of its children.

In Ghana we have found partners who share our vision, ranging from national ministries and local authorities, to tribal chiefs and parents. There are many motivated but underprivileged students with a passion for learning and a will to succeed.

The Musical Village

The heart of our program in Ghana is our youth center, the Musical Village. It is located in Ada, a seaside town about 70 miles from Accra, the capital of Ghana. The Musical Village has 5 buildings:  a classroom, dormitory, kitchen, administration building and a pavilion where we hold events and performances. It opened in July 2013 and was constructed with funds from donors in the United States. It is the site of after school tutoring and music lessons for 25 students. We also hold overnight and holiday camps for our students at the Musical Village. 


Making an Impact 

We consistently measure our students' academic progress in our program and at their schools, and their grades are improving.  For example, over the 2013 - 2014 school year, the number of students with "A" or "B" averages increased from 11 students to 14 students.  

Also, our students have embraced music and dancing as a form of positive self-expression (and a break from the books!). They regularly perform traditional West African drumming and dancing at BBSCF events in Ghana.  We recently hired another music teacher, and they are now learning piano and guitar.  

Most importantly, our students' confidence is increasing and their natural curiosity has been ignited. They want to be the first in their families to attend college and become leaders in their communities.  

Our Next Phase

Thanks to three years of continued success, we have created a meaningful and inspirational program with a team who can superbly execute it.  With the completion of the Musical Village and our enrollment at 30 students, we are ready to expand.  

We will begin the process of recruiting 10 new students in April 2015.  Prospective new students and their parents will complete an application, provide report cards, and submit reference letters.  They will meet with BBSCF teachers and tour the Musical Village.  Admission decisions will be finalized by July 2015, and students will begin attending tutoring and music lessons at the Musical Village in August 2015. 

The new students will join our current students at the local private school in Ada, at the Asi-Daahey School.  We selected the Asi-Daahey School because of its excellent reputation and success at preparing students for secondary school.  The cost of tuition for the 2015 - 2016 school year for 10 students is $6,000, or $600 per student.  This is where we need your help!

  

Any excess funds raised will be used to pay for an additional teacher at the Musical Village. The annual cost of the teacher is $2,300. 

Falling short of our goal is not an option. Our team is actively approaching potential supporters in both the U.S. and Ghana to raise the funds needed. We are committed to our students and our team in Ghana, and we will do what it takes to reach this exciting goal!  

How You Can Help

Be a part of the cycle of success! Here's what you can do!

  • Share, tweet and repost this link.
  • Follow us on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Sign up for our newsletter on our website.
  • Make a donation to fund the future of a deserving student and of a nation.  

Medaase! Thank You!

We consistently measure our students' academic progress in our program and at their schools, and their grades are improving.  For example, over the 2013 - 2014 school year, the number of students with "A" or "B" averages increased from 11 students to 14 students.  
Also, our students have embraced music and dancing as a form of positive self-expression (and a break from the books!). They regularly perform traditional West African drumming and dancing at BBSCF events in Ghana.  We recently hired another music teacher, and they are now learning piano and guitar.  


Most importantly, our students' confidence is increasing and their natural curiosity has been ignited. They want to be the first in their families to attend college and become leaders in their communities.  
Our Next Phase
Thanks to three years of continued success, we have created a meaningful and inspirational program with a team who can superbly execute it.  With the completion of the Musical Village and our enrollment at 30 students, we are ready to expand.  
We will begin the process of recruiting 10 new students in April 2015.  Prospective new students and their parents will complete an application, provide report cards, and submit reference letters.  They will meet with BBSCF teachers and tour the Musical Village.  Admission decisions will be finalized by July 2015, and students will begin attending tutoring and music lessons at the Musical Village in August 2015. 
The new students will join our current students at the local private school in Ada, at the Asi-Daahey School.  We selected the Asi-Daahey School because of its excellent reputation and success at preparing students for secondary school.  The cost of tuition for the 2015 - 2016 school year for 10 students is $6,000, or $600 per student.  This is where we need your help!




  
Any excess funds raised will be used to pay for an additional teacher at the Musical Village. The annual cost of the teacher is $2,300. 
Falling short of our goal is not an option. Our team is actively approaching potential supporters in both the U.S. and Ghana to raise the funds needed. We are committed to our students and our team in Ghana, and we will do what it takes to reach this exciting goal!  
How You Can Help
 Be a part of the cycle of success! Here's what you can do! 
Share, tweet and repost this link. Follow us on Facebook and Twitter.
Sign up for our newsletter on our website.
Make a donation to fund the future of a deserving student and of a nation.  






Medaase! Thank You!

story:
Sunshine Sketches of a Little Town by OSTC

Open Source Text Canada (OSTC) is a federally-registered Canadian charity working to provide Open Educational Resources matching Canadian curricula — and by extension making them available to the world.

Stephen Leacock (1869–1944) was a hugely popular humorist in Canada and the United States and for a time the most widely-read English author.

Sunshine Sketches of a Little Town is one of his most enduring works painting a light-hearted portrait of small town North American life at the dawn of the 20th century.

Although this work is also freely available on the Internet Archive and Project Gutenberg, the reproductions are either plain text or image scans -- our free versions are re-typeset using the Project Gutenberg text so that EPUBs and PDFs are of the highest quality for classroom use, as well as making a high-res print-on-demand file available. Digital files will be freely available off our web site and will be available for print-on-demand at cost from the University of Toronto BookPOD and other sources as we partner with them. It will also be placed on the Internet Archive.

What We Need & What You Get

We already have donated services for desktop publishing this work, but unfortunately we've found some errors in the Project Gutenberg version and need to hire a professional proofreader to ensure complete accuracy to the original first edition, and also pay the $75 set up fee for the University of Toronto BookPOD.

All donors who give their permission will be mentioned at the back of the production acknowledging that they have made this work possible.

$40 or more donors will receive a printed paperback off the University of Toronto BookPOD signed with a note from OSTC CEO Glenn Ross thanking them personally for their support.

All Canadian donations of $10 or more will also receive a tax receipt from Open Source Text Canada. For $40 or more donors Canada Revenue rules will require us to deduct the cost of the printed book (about $6) from the receipt.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about Open Education and please share this campaign. Thank you.

story:
According to most recent CDC [The Centers for Disease Control] listing cerebrovascular diseases, otherwise known as stroke, is the 7th most common cause of death in children 5-24 years old. Early recognition and treatment during the first hours and days after a stroke is critical in optimizing long-term functional outcomes and minimizing recurring risk. Sixty percent of the children who survive a stroke will have permanent neurological issues. 

Educating our medical community about pediatric stroke will help children, teenagers and young adults that are at high risk by possibly preventing or having a plan of attack when a stroke happens. This campaign will help do just that.

The Children’s Stroke Foundation’s goal is to educate and create new ways to stop stroke in children, teen and young adults.

Learn About Stroke Now

Stroke can happen to anyone at any age.  Just knowing this fact could save a life.  'Like' our Facebook/YouTube page so you can keep up with the different stroke causes we discover.  You never know, the next one could save a family members life.




Why We Need You

Our funding comes from kind souls like you.  A large portion funds Children's Hospital of Boston's model program to teach hospitals across the US. The other portion, we use to teach everyone else.  We want you to be an educated advocate.

If we don't fundraise successfully, our initiatives will not launch. Join us now - don't let the movement we've created lose its only support and fizzle away.

Other Ways You Can Help

Did you know 'word of mouth' speaks volumes.  Please spread the word and make some noise about the campaign.  Use the share tools here to post in your social media.

Do you accept checks?

Yes, we do!  Please mail it to:
Children's Stroke Foundation
38 E Ridgewood Ave, STE 258
Ridgewood, NJ 07450
On the Memo line write in with pride 'TeamUCLA'

How's the competition doing?

You can see TeamUSC's progress here: Team USC

story: Freedom Schools is a program designed by Children’s Defense Fund that not only knocks out summer reading loss but promotes social action and engagement within children from ages 5-17. This program has been a resource for families in and around East Cleveland to provide a safe, healthy and enriching experience during the summer.

This program has been a resource for families in and around East Cleveland to provide a safe, healthy and enriching experience during the summer.

story:
Our Stories- 
  • My name is Mike Wagner and I'm an 18-year-old SBCC marketing student from The San Francisco Bay Area. I am hoping to raise money of the PBJ-1 because I can resonate with the Veterans working on the planes restoration. My grandfathers all fought in World War 2 and my father is a Vietnam Navy Veteran. Growing up around so many military veterans gave me an understanding of how much of an impact the war and that era played throughout their lives. I know that the restoration of this aircraft will provide hope and accomplishment to the men and women who have worked so hard on this plane. Let's make it happen!
  • My name is Maja and I'm a 19-year-old girl studying abroad, I was born and raised in Sweden and for as long as I have known, I've wanted to go to college. I'm a marketing major at SBCC and aiming for a certificate in Marketing. I believe that marketing is the foundation of everything when it comes to business and in your personal life. Working on the PBJ is something that will give me a greater understanding in marketing as well as doing something good, my personal aim for this fundraising is to see the PBJ get air beneath its wings again and fly. 
  • My name is Hanna and I am an international student at Santa Barbara City College. I am 20 years old and graduated from high school in Sweden last year, where I studied business economics. Right after graduation, I got an internship at a media and marketing analysis company, which made me interested in marketing. I also studied one semester at Stockholm University where I, among other courses, took a marketing class. I look forward to start with our marketing project and believe our fundraising can manage to raise enough money to help the PBJ aircraft fly again. Our group visited the airport in Camarillo, where we met the inspiring volunteers who have been working on the airplane for over 20 years. 
  • Hi, my name is Taylor Leabhart and I am from Annapolis, Maryland. I am a second year student at Santa Barbara City College and majoring in business and marketing. Even though we have only been working on the project to restore the PBJ-1 for a couple months; the project still means a good deal to me because we are helping volunteers, many being veterans who are putting their own/unpaid time, to restore this aircraft and it's a great feeling to give back to the people who have served our country.
  • Hi, I'm Maddy Ward. I'm from Denver, Colorado and I'm attending Santa Barbara City College for Dietetics and Nutrition Science. Learning about the PBJ aircraft with my group has truly been a fun and exciting experience. Experiencing firsthand how passionate the volunteers are about the airplane and listening to their stories about it, you can't help but feel inspired and passionate about the airplane too. They have been working on it for over 20 years and I am just as eager as them to see it take off and fly. I'm confident that Oceans 12 can raise enough money to get the PBJ back in the air again!  

  • Hi, my name is Gustav Valentin and I'm a Danish international student at Santa Barbara City College. I will be studying in the U.S. for one semester whereafter I return to Denmark. I hope to be able to help the volunteers at the Commemorative Air Force push through the last few months of work before the PBJ can fly (some have been working on it for more than 20 years!) Through this crowdfunding project, we in Oceans 12, get the chance to help restore a piece of history as well as making some of the volunteers' dreams about the aircraft come true.

Through this crowdfunding project, we in Oceans 12, get the chance to help restore a piece of history as well as making some of the volunteers' dreams about the aircraft come true.

story: A terrible tornado struck the community of Moore, Oklahoma.  At least two elementary schools were completely destroyed.  One news report stated that up to 24 children may be dead at one of the schools. Lets help them rebuild.  All funds generated will be donated to Plaza Towers Elementary School and Briarwood Elementary in Moore, OK.  Lets get this done!

story:
ALSO Adult & Family Literacy

A small program doing great things

ALSO has been active in the Ottawa community for over 30 years. We provide upgrading programs in both English and American Sign Language (ASL) to people who are struggling with the essential skills many of us take for granted. We are a safe and caring community learning centre that supports the development of the skills needed for work, further education and family life.

In addition to our adult literacy programs, we offer family literacy support to low income families. Family literacy has had a terrific impact on literacy programming, as it recognizes the need to support parents in order for them to better support their children.

Life could be easier for a lot of adults in our community if they had had better opportunities to develop their reading and writing as children.

Why we need your help

One of our key family literacy programs is the Reading and Parents Program (RAPP), an outreach initiative promoting family literacy activities for low-income families. The key element of RAPP is the RAPP pack, a fun and educational family literacy toolkit for parents and children 0 to 6 years old.

A typical RAPP pack includes a book for every child in the family, as well as crafts, poetry, and reading and language tips for parents.

We also offer two other RAPP versions: one to support parents learning English as their second language – ALSOvoices RAPP; and the other for hearing parents of deaf or hard of hearing children – the American Sign Language (ASL) RAPP.

The ALSOvoices RAPP pack includes an additional audio component, while the ASL RAPP pack includes a DVD.

RAPP has already had a positive impact on the families in our community. We work with over 150 families each year.  In order to continue to grow our program resources and continue offering free programming for families, we need your support!

Where the money will go

The funds that we are raising will go to help develop more packs so that we can bring this important resource to more families. Each pack costs on average $25 for the English literacy pack, $30 for the ALSOvoices pack and $40 for the ASL literacy pack. 

We would like to develop at least 30 new packs for each version of RAPP to share with the community.

Working together

Our Reading and Parents Program (RAPP) partners with other community organizations to build the skills of parents so they are better able to support their children and create a positive learning environment at home.

The amazing community organizations we work with on the RAPP program are:  the Vanier Community Service Centre, Rideau Rockliffe Community Centre, Heartwood House, Lowertown Community Centre, Overbrook Forbes Community Centre, Infant Hearing Program, Hands & Voices Ottawa, York Street School and the Ottawa Inuit Children’s Centre.

Staff and volunteers visit RAPP satellite sites in the community every two weeks, where they collect the old packs from families and provide new packs. This way we are able to re-use the books and only have to replace the activity materials.

By supporting RAPP, you will be joining a community of people and organizations dedicated to making a lasting impact.

Family literacy is important

The family is a child’s first teacher. Current research shows that early experiences help to determine brain structure which in turn shapes the way we learn, think, behave and respond to challenges as adults. The skills and capacity to learn that we develop before the age of six stay with us for a lifetime. Family literacy activities are the foundation of future learning and can help children develop and maintain a love of learning. 

We know that families in our society, and especially families living in poverty, are under increasing stress and need all the support they can get. When their children have an opportunity to learn at home, in community programs and even in designated family literacy programs, they have a much better chance of succeeding at school and anticipating a bright, productive future. 

Families with deaf or hard of hearing children need support and resources to allow them to develop a strong system for family communication. Having a common language base enables parents to better understand their children. It helps children to express their wants, needs, experiences and dreams to their parents. It means that families can function as a family.

We hope that one day there will be far fewer adults who face a daily struggle with literacy. Join us in making this a reality! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can afford to give money, but that doesn't mean you can't support the campaign.

  • Tell your friends and family.
  • Use the share links to spread the word on social media.
Thank you so much for learning about ALSO and RAPP! Visit our website at www.also-ottawa.org to learn more about all our programs.

story:
Short Summary

In partnership with the 2013 Bammy Awards, we are honoring one participant in the Quest2Matter with the first Bammy Award for Student Initiative.

The recipient is Mallory Fundora, a 13 year-old from Tennessee. Mallory is the founder of Project Yesu, which raises funds to provide medicine, food and education to orphans in Uganda.

We're seeking to raise funds to help Mallory and her parents attend the Bammy Awards in Washington, DC in September 2013.

What We Need & What You Get

The funding will pay for airfare, hotel and miscellaneous travel expenses for a family of three from Tennessee to Washington, DC.

The Impact

By enabling Mallory to accept the Bammy Award for Student Initiative in person, you will inspire an entire generation of youth to follow her example.

story:
Every £4,000 we raise gives a disadvantaged child a 4-year music scholarship

About Our Campaign

In the UK over 50% of children in fee-paying schools learn a musical instrument. In non-fee-paying schools 85% of children say they would really like the opportunity to learn an instrument but the reality is that only 10% of families can afford the fees. 

Not only is this a terrible waste of potential, but it’s really unfair that a child who has enthusiasm and wants to develop a life-enhancing skill is prevented from doing so because of circumstances outside of their control.  It is even more frustrating when there are so many reports evidencing the much wider benefits that come with learning a musical instrument. 

At the Mayor’s Music Fund we’re doing something about musical inequality by awarding 4-year scholarships to children (mostly aged 9 &10) from socially and economically disadvantaged backgrounds who show masses of ability and a keenness to learn, but need that all-important leg-up to make it happen.  We’d love you to join us in our mission, and our scholars on their musical journey. 

What We Need

We are an independent charity with the Mayor of London Boris Johnson as Founder Patron. We’ve been in existence 24 months and have awarded 230 scholarships, which is a financial commitment of £920,000.

Every £4,000 we raise we give another child a 4-year scholarship – it’s as simple as that!

Our Music Scholars’ program over the course of an academic year looks like this:

Activity (30-35 weeks) Average cost £ (pounds sterling)
Weekly music lesson in school (30 mins)                       300
Weekend Music Centre - ensemble, theory, choir (90 mins)                       150
Group playing days and events                         50
Instrument loan and repair                        50
Workshops & holiday courses                        50
Books/sheet music                         30
Exam fees                        40
Visits to live concerts                        30
Personal mentor                        90
Monitoring and evaluation                        60
Administration                       150
Total                       1000

Almost 10% of what we make will be swallowed up in campaign fees, so we are asking for an extra £500 to cover these cost to ensure that the full £4000 can be used for a scholarship.

Our target amount is enough to sponsor one child. We would love to sponsor as many children as possible, so please give as much as you can because all additional funds raised will go towards another scholarship.

The Impact

The importance of learning a musical instrument from a young age:

It is well-documented that good music education has a transformative impact on children. Learning an instrument enhances academic acheivement, raises self-esteem, self-confidence and a sense of personal achievement; teaches self-discipline and mutual respect; brings communities together and above all gives a sense of emotional wellbeing and provides lifelong pleasure.

“I believe passionately that if a child shows musical potential and wants to progress their talent they should be given every opportunity to play, listen to and enjoy music regardless of their social or financial background.” – Mayor of London, Boris Johnson

A Real-life Example:

Charlie’s Story

Eighteen months ago, Charlie was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome. For as long as Charlie can remember, music has been his comfort and constant companion. At nine he had some lessons through the Government’s Wider Opportunities Programme, which promises that all primary school pupils have the opportunity to try an instrument. Charlie took up the cello, and quickly became one of the strongest players in the class. But his parents, Frank, who had a kidney transplant three years ago and Sally, a full-time mother and carer (Charlie’s older brother has an inoperable brain tumour) knew that once the free taster lessons were up, they would not be able to afford the fees to allow their son to continue playing.

In December 2011, Charlie, became one of the first Mayor’s Music Scholars. When asked how his cello makes him feel: ‘It’s an emotional feeling. When I’m playing everything else goes away,’ he says. ‘I just want to do it all the time.’ When asked how he would have felt if he couldn’t have carried on learning the cello: ‘I would have been really upset because I love it so much.’

Help us to help others like Charlie by donating what you can to our campaign.   

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that isn’t always possible to contribute financially.  If you can’t (and even if you can) please spread the word because you never know who’s out there waiting to open their wallet……!

  • Follow us @MayorsMusic and tweet this.
  • Spread the word far and wide.
  • Direct people to our website www.mfym.org.uk

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT
story_txt:
Every £4,000 we raise gives a disadvantaged child a 4-year music scholarship
About Our Campaign
In the UK over 50% of children in fee-paying schools learn a musical instrument. In non-fee-paying schools 85% of children say they would really like the opportunity to learn an instrument but the reality is that only 10% of families can afford the fees. 
Not only is this a terrible waste of potential, but it’s really unfair that a child who has enthusiasm and wants to develop a life-enhancing skill is prevented from doing so because of circumstances outside of their control.  It is even more frustrating when there are so many reports evidencing the much wider benefits that come with learning a musical instrument. 
At the Mayor’s Music Fund we’re doing something about musical inequality by awarding 4-year scholarships to children (mostly aged 9 &10) from socially and economically disadvantaged backgrounds who show masses of ability and a keenness to learn, but need that all-important leg-up to make it happen.  We’d love you to join us in our mission, and our scholars on their musical journey. 
What We Need
We are an independent charity with the Mayor of London Boris Johnson as Founder Patron. We’ve been in existence 24 months and have awarded 230 scholarships, which is a financial commitment of £920,000. 
Every £4,000 we raise we give another child a 4-year scholarship – it’s as simple as that!
Our Music Scholars’ program over the course of an academic year looks like this:







Activity (30-35 weeks)
Average cost £ (pounds sterling)


Weekly music lesson in school (30 mins)
                      300


Weekend Music Centre - ensemble, theory, choir (90 mins)
                      150


Group playing days and events 
                       50


Instrument loan and repair
                       50


Workshops & holiday courses
                       50


Books/sheet music 
                       30


Exam fees
                       40


Visits to live concerts
                       30


Personal mentor
                       90


Monitoring and evaluation
                       60


Administration
                      150


Total 
                     1000


Almost 10% of what we make will be swallowed up in campaign fees, so we are asking for an extra £500 to cover these cost to ensure that the full £4000 can be used for a scholarship.
Our target amount is enough to sponsor one child. We would love to sponsor as many children as possible, so please give as much as you can because all additional funds raised will go towards another scholarship.
The Impact
The importance of learning a musical instrument from a young age: 
It is well-documented that good music education has a transformative impact on children. Learning an instrument enhances academic acheivement, raises self-esteem, self-confidence and a sense of personal achievement; teaches self-discipline and mutual respect; brings communities together and above all gives a sense of emotional wellbeing and provides lifelong pleasure.
“I believe passionately that if a child shows musical potential and wants to progress their talent they should be given every opportunity to play, listen to and enjoy music regardless of their social or financial background.” – Mayor of London, Boris Johnson
A Real-life Example:
Charlie’s Story
Eighteen months ago, Charlie was diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome. For as long as Charlie can remember, music has been his comfort and constant companion. At nine he had some lessons through the Government’s Wider Opportunities Programme, which promises that all primary school pupils have the opportunity to try an instrument. Charlie took up the cello, and quickly became one of the strongest players in the class. But his parents, Frank, who had a kidney transplant three years ago and Sally, a full-time mother and carer (Charlie’s older brother has an inoperable brain tumour) knew that once the free taster lessons were up, they would not be able to afford the fees to allow their son to continue playing.
In December 2011, Charlie, became one of the first Mayor’s Music Scholars. When asked how his cello makes him feel: ‘It’s an emotional feeling. When I’m playing everything else goes away,’ he says. ‘I just want to do it all the time.’ When asked how he would have felt if he couldn’t have carried on learning the cello: ‘I would have been really upset because I love it so much.’
Help us to help others like Charlie by donating what you can to our campaign.   
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that isn’t always possible to contribute financially.  If you can’t (and even if you can) please spread the word because you never know who’s out there waiting to open their wallet……!

Follow us @MayorsMusic and tweet this.
Spread the word far and wide.
Direct people to our website www.mfym.org.uk

 
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT

story:
Hello to the lovely community of IndieGoGo!

My name is Amanda Buckmister and I am just a few months away from potentially embarking on the journey of Graduate School! I was recently accepted into Seattle University’s Master of Education in Student Affairs program and I am reaching out to the interwebs as a final attempt to raise funds to continue my studies in international relations and holistic education.

I have put my <3 and soul into creative education working with non-profits such as ‘The International Friendship Program’, tutoring and mentoring a variety of college-aged international students in business, academic, and conversational English & the St. James ESL program to advocate justice for refugees and immigrants through education, advocacy, and English language programs. I have collaborated with Peace Corps volunteers to develop cross-cultural orientations, strategic curriculum plans, and connections to community resources in the greater Seattle area. I also worked as an off-site one-on-one English language tutor offering instruction based on U.S. History and current events to aid students for citizenship testing and basic computer instruction to improve foundational skills and resume writing.

Together with my volunteer experience, I continued my education with a series of second language acquisition, ESL methodology, and practical classroom management classes.  I recently completed my intensive TEFL/TESOL certification program in San Jose, Costa Rica where I lived and studied for two months.  

Looking to expand my bilingual and immersion teaching techniques outside of the formal classroom, I applied to a Japanese and Spanish before and after school program based out of John Stanford International Elementary School. I have now been employed as a lead  3rd grade teacher at Latona School Associates (LSA) for the last three years. LSA is a Washington state non-profit corporation that respects and fosters the whole child in experimental learning and developmental growth in a culturally inclusive manner -it also happens to be my second home.

Although my work environment at LSA initially inspired me to participate in English teaching programs abroad in Japan (JET), my fellow co-worker, a former JET now enrolled in the Masters In Teaching program at Seattle University, encouraged me to look into the professional development opportunities offered at a graduate level. Being the first female in my family to graduate from college and the only member to seek an advanced degree, I had apprehensions about taking on more student loans to invest in further education. Nevertheless, after researching Seattle University’s Student Development program I was instantly assured given I share the same cornerstone values about creative education. 

I’ve seen countless quotes from university presidents and leaders that state there is no great education without an international dimension, and I would have to agree. I strongly believe that international education and exchange not only bridge diplomatic relationships between different countries and peoples, but allows necessary introspection onto one’s self and culture. If leaders, entrepreneurs, and teachers can plant the seed of international exchange, the importance of international education will extend the classroom and the individual blossoming into mutual respect and understanding of humanity regardless of differences.

I have played many roles in my career development: teacher, mentor, educator, leadership coordinator, tutor, friend, and student but my overarching goal is unwavering-to lead, teach, and learn outside of the formal classroom. I continue to seek and thrive in classrooms, workspaces, and environments that foster student diversity and respect the holistic person and that is why I believe I am a ideal candidate for Seattle University’s Student Administration program. 

Continuing onto my Master's would fulfill my perpetual yearning to aid transitioning international students, empower adult and secondary learners in job development and self- confidence, bridge cultural populations, and positively impact my global community.

 

Please help me be a great teacher!  

 

What I Need & Where It's Going

 So here I am, a 24 year old first generation female college student with a 3.8 GPA (Not to brag) trying to take the next step in my post-baccalaureate education for myself and my students. 500 dollars will help me get on my feet and essentially cover books for the first semester of school. I have applied for the Graduate Assistantship work-study program (which is the only form of finical aid offered besides FASA) and compensation for the 2012-13 is $15,605 for an average of twenty hours per week, which would greatly help my endeavors so FINGERS CROSSED! 

500 is a lofty goal but anything will help! 

 

YOUR PERKS

I know that indiegogo requires your physical address when you donate a particular amount that gives you a 'Perk' but I hope to use an email to send you personalized "thank you's" videos from myself and my class.

Use thanksfromamanda@gmail.com in order to get your perks!

story:
The Need

Fresno, California is a diverse area where over 100 different languages are spoken.  The 2010 US Census reported that 42.16% of the population spoke a language other than English at home, and 46% listed themselves as, "not speaking English very well".  While there are many free English language classes in Fresno, the need for a private language school that provides quality, individualized instruction is extreme.  I want to open an English as a Second Language (ESL) school for adults in Fresno to help meet this need.  


I have taught ESL and Special Education in the public school setting.  I possess all the credentials required by the State of California to teach Adult ESL.  I myself am a second language learner, (Spanish), so I understand the difficulties involved in learning another language.  I believe that the free programs offered are incomplete in what they do - it is difficult to do the "hands-on", personalized teaching needed to really learn a subject well if you have 35 to 50 students in your classroom.  Central Valley Language School will limit each class to a maximum of 12 students and will offer private lessons as well.  Lessons will be customized to student needs, rather than following a scripted lesson plan.


Starting a business is always a challenge, but beginning a school from nothing is really difficult.  Students need books and materials from the first day; they can't wait until the school makes enough to buy them or to rent a place to teach in.  Classes need to be advertised, so that the learners will know that they exist.  


I need your help to jump start my school - to buy materials, to advertise, and to pay rent for at least 6 months until the school starts making enough money to support itself.

What We Need & What You Get

I estimate that I will need about $25,000 to run the school until it begins to support itself.  This would cover advertising, books and materials, and rent for the first 6 months of operation.  I have set an opening deadline of May 5th, so I will need to have things ordered by then.  If the $25,000 goal is not reached, then I won't be able to advertise as much and will have to rely more on word of mouth, which could delay school growth.  If the goal is surpassed, I will funnel the additional support into scholarships for deserving students and additional materials.

To thank you for your generous help, I have chosen some cool perks to choose from.  Some are serious, and some are silly, but all are designed to reward your thoughtfulness.

The Impact

I feel that Central Valley Language School will impact the local community in a significant manner.  Fresno is an economically disadvantaged area, where there are not many entry-level jobs available.  A better grasp of the English language is necessary for legal immigrants to move up in society and to be more productive in it.  Having a local private language school will provide an additional avenue for hardworking individuals who want to invest in their futures

I know that I can accomplish my goal with your help.  I have the experience and the knowledge, I just need a little help with the initial funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please help to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.  Share this campaign on your favorite social media site.  Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you soooooooo much!

story:
The holiday season is upon us once again. Growing up many of us were lucky enough to wake up on Christmas morning and find tons of gifts under the Christmas tree. Unfortunately since the economic downturn more and more children won't have the Christmas that they deserve. 

For the 2nd year in a row Kelsey and I would like to reach out to those that want to help and see if we can pool our resources and buy presents for families that need our help. Last year because of everyone's generosity we were able to adopt several families from the St. Dominic's Parish in Oyster Bay, New York as well take care of families at a Women's Shelter on Long Island. The picture above is an example of just some of the gifts we were able to get.

We know that this venture won't change the world but with everyone's help we can hopefully give a few children the type of Christmas that many of us were lucky to have.

story:
Since 2004 our non-profit organization of amateur astronomers has organized events in many locations in Armenia. The events mainly involved looking at the moon and planets with organization’s portable telescopes. So far we have had events in

  • Zorats Karer
  • Orphanages in Gavar, Abovyan and Vanadzor
  • Summer school of students with disabilities in Sevan
  • Prison for minors in Abovyan
  • “Poqr Mher” military institute
  • Many public schools and villages

Our organization is planning to continue its operations in the coming year by holding public classes in schools in Armenia (especially in villages far from the center). Such events are especially important for inspiring children with the wonders of the universe. The Ministry of Education and Science has given permission to our organization to hold such classes.

Currently, our organization is funded by its generous members, however more funds are necessary for making events that are far from Yerevan. The money is mostly spent on the transportation of the telescopes. Typically, each event costs about $100-200.

We are kindly asking to help us develop the knowledge of astronomy and science in the country by contributing the amount you can. You can follow our events and see information about past ones in our Facebook group.

Campaign photo by Suren Manvelyan

story:
Dallas' Gift - You can make a difference!

While my mother was in the hospital for a week over the holidays we visited her every day. While there, her best friend Dallas passed away after a lengthy battle with cancer. During Dallas’ stay at Kingston General Hospital, it didn’t take long for her family to realize the cost of parking and food was very expensive. As a tribute to Dallas, we would like to raise money to give to other families having to make frequent trips to KGH in Kingston, Ontario.

Dallas was a great friend with a dear heart.  We are happy to honour Dallas by helping the families that need it most.

Parking Rates – Stuart Street Underground Parking Garage:

  • Rate - per half hour:  $1.25
  • Daily maximum rate: $16.00
  • Overnight flat rate (between 6:30pm - 8:00am): $6.00
  • Lost ticket: $20.00

Parking info: http://www.kgh.on.ca/en/patientsandvisitors/pages/Where-do-I-park.aspx

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute - that's okay! If you can help with your time or have ideas to help make this campaign even more successful, I would love to hear from you. Get in touch! 

You can also help by:

  • spreading the word - let's make some noise about this campaign!
  • share this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools on this page! And, don't forget to use Facebook and Twitter too!

Thank you for your support!

story:
I've always been passionate about efficiency, and since discovering tiny houses, I knew I wanted to build one.  I want to include my community in the building process, so that others can learn the basics and get inspired to build their own tiny houses in the future. 

The money raised through this project will be used to purchase the building materials.

This includes:

An 8' x 16' trailer $4,000

Wood for framing the house $600

Exterior Siding $400

Exterior Plywood $500

Interior Paneling $400

Insulation $300

Windows $1500

Solar Panels $500

2 @ Car Batteries $200/ea = $400

Roofing $200

Counter Tops $600

Fridge $600

story:
Austin

Austin is pretty much one of the most fabulous boys out there! He is charismatic, affectionate, funny, and smart. He loves movies, skiing, Lego, and art, and has been wanting to try out fencing for quite some time.

This campaign will provide a way for all of us to share our love, hopes, and dreams for Austin. Together, we can create a fund out of which he can register for the activities that inspire him and his passions.

Activity Fund

All funds raised through this website will be held for Austin in a dedicated Activity Fund that his mom will use to register him in classes that make his heart sing.

For every, $25 you donate, you'll receive an electronic thank you card from Austin. If you donate $100, you'll receive a thank you card by mail. If you donate $500, you'll be invited to join Austin for an art class in Vancouver.

Let's give Austin something fabulous to look forward to!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute at this time, please help the campaign by spreading the word to others.

story:
Hi everyone!

I'm Aysel Abbasova, an Azerbaijanian girl born in Moscow, migrated with my family from Baku (the capital of Azerbaijan) to Turkey after collapse of the Soviet Union. Recently I won the First Prize at the international scholarship competition for Master in Product Design "Domestic Landscapes" hold by one of the prestigious design schools of the world Domus Academy in Milan.

Since my graduation from Middle East Technical University (one of the best universities in Turkey), Department of Industrial Design I've always dreamed to have a chance to study in the capital of Industrial Design - Milan. Eventualy, I've attended a competition hold by one of the most famous design schools in the world and won a first prize.

Being a designer and try to make the world better through my sincere designs was the main goal while choosing this profession and if I'd have a chance to study at this marvelous Master Degree Program supported by the most well known design companies and famous designers of the world, I'd be able to perfect my skills as a designer and make a greater contribution to the world's well being. 

You can see faculty visiting professors and companies:

http://www.domusacademy.com/site/home/master-programs/product-design/faculty--visiting-professors.html

In case you want to be assure you can contact them via skype and ask my name: 

http://www.domusacademy.com/site/home/contact-us.html

My program begins in February and  I don’t have enough money to cover tuition and living expenses. The total tuition fee is 32,355 dolars (23,790 euros). The first prize was %70 of total tuition fee. So, now I have to pay 9,700 dolars (7,137 euros). In addition living in Milan is also very expensive min 1,600 dolars per month. Normally the funding needed is much more than I've asked for, but the aim for asking for less is to make it more reasonable and at least this will cover the tuition fee+ the first few months of living there. Meanwhile I hope to find an extra job to meet my living expenses. 

IMPORTANT NOTE:  I do not have much time for the enrollment fee date (a few days and I've already postponed the date). If I'd miss it, the whole campaign would be meaningless. I have to pay urgently 4,000 dolars (3000 euros). It'd be better if you can transfer your donations through your paypal accounts. Those who want to trasfer donations to my bank account can contact me through my facebook account or mail me to ayselabbasova@gmail.com. Thanks a lot in advance.

Facebook event

https://www.facebook.com/events/502425896523272/?fref=ts



Plus I’ve got some great perks for you!

For donations of~

$25 I’ll send you a personal thank you email.

$50 I’ll thank you personally over Skype.

$100 I’ll  send you a postcard from Milan.

$300 I'll send you souvenir from Milan or Istanbul.

$500  You'll get a handmade felt bracelet designed by me.

$1500 You'll get all of the above PLUS a personalized support t-shirt.

$3000 You'll get all of the above PLUS I'll design you a business card.

$5000 You'll get all of the above PLUS I'll design a piece of furniture you prefer.


The Impact

While my involvement in this program  will make me better qualified designer, designs and my contributions to the world will be more conscious in terms of making people's everyday life easier and more comfortable. I will also be able to have a career in worldwide companies and thus my designs could reach more people on the planet.

Milan - the capital of Industrial Design and there is hard to find such a school like Domus Academy with all its oportunities that it offers to a designer. 

Check out what are the career opportunities for the graduates of the program:

http://www.domusacademy.com/site/home/master-programs/product-design/careers.html

Help me make a world better place through my product designs reached to thousands of people!

If you have questions about the campaign you can contact me via ayselabbasova@gmail.com


Other ways you can help


Don’t worry if you can’t donate. 
There are other ways you can help.
Just use the indiegogo share tools below and spread the world!
story_txt:
Hi everyone!
I'm Aysel Abbasova, an Azerbaijanian girl born in Moscow, migrated with my family from Baku (the capital of Azerbaijan) to Turkey after collapse of the Soviet Union. Recently I won the First Prize at the international scholarship competition for Master in Product Design "Domestic Landscapes" hold by one of the prestigious design schools of the world Domus Academy in Milan.
Since my graduation from Middle East Technical University (one of the best universities in Turkey), Department of Industrial Design I've always dreamed to have a chance to study in the capital of Industrial Design - Milan. Eventualy, I've attended a competition hold by one of the most famous design schools in the world and won a first prize.
Being a designer and try to make the world better through my sincere designs was the main goal while choosing this profession and if I'd have a chance to study at this marvelous Master Degree Program supported by the most well known design companies and famous designers of the world, I'd be able to perfect my skills as a designer and make a greater contribution to the world's well being. 
You can see faculty visiting professors and companies:
http://www.domusacademy.com/site/home/master-programs/product-design/faculty--visiting-professors.html
In case you want to be assure you can contact them via skype and ask my name: 
http://www.domusacademy.com/site/home/contact-us.html
My program begins in February and  I don’t have enough money to cover tuition and living expenses. The total tuition fee is 32,355 dolars (23,790 euros). The first prize was %70 of total tuition fee. So, now I have to pay 9,700 dolars (7,137 euros). In addition living in Milan is also very expensive min 1,600 dolars per month. Normally the funding needed is much more than I've asked for, but the aim for asking for less is to make it more reasonable and at least this will cover the tuition fee+ the first few months of living there. Meanwhile I hope to find an extra job to meet my living expenses. 
IMPORTANT NOTE:  I do not have much time for the enrollment fee date (a few days and I've already postponed the date). If I'd miss it, the whole campaign would be meaningless. I have to pay urgently 4,000 dolars (3000 euros). It'd be better if you can transfer your donations through your paypal accounts. Those who want to trasfer donations to my bank account can contact me through my facebook account or mail me to ayselabbasova@gmail.com. Thanks a lot in advance.

story:
My name is Stephanie Brown. I am a Senior Photography Student at Savannah College of Art and Design(SCAD) in Savannah, GA. I am originally from Delray Beach, FL. I graduated from Atlantic Community High School's International Baccalaureate (IB) Programme in 2011. This Spring 2014 I will graduate from SCAD and finish my degree coursework the following Summer in Lacoste, France.

  • This campaign is dedicated to helping me raise funds to afford to travel to Lacoste, France to complete my studies. For many years I have dreamt of traveling and pursuing my career in photography. This trip abroad is the start of many more foreign travels in store for me.

         

  • In my young years I have accomplished so much! I defied odds by finding adequate sources to help pay my way through my private art school education. After 3 years of college I have yet to take up any loans and managed to finish school a year in advance.


    I chartered a Relay For Life club/event on my school's campus. I have helped raise over $10,000 for the American Cancer Society to help others get well, stay well, and create more birthdays.

     
    I have curated and coordinated a free exhibition for student artists of color in the community and south eastern region.

    I have been a student athlete running Track & Field.
    I have been a model for the SCAD Fashion Design Seniors/Show for the past three years.

       

    I have been an advocate in the natural hair community of Savannah by providing photography to the local salon The Nappy Hutt.

     
    I became a member of a wonderful church, Living Hope Community Fellowship. I recently began praise dancing, and I can't forget to mention the incredible body of work I have created while studying at SCAD.

  • Traveling to France is more than an experience.It is a window of opportunity to help build my network. It is a chance to open my eyes even more to see this beautiful world God has crafted. Studying abroad is my new adventure. By donating to my campaign you are joining my adventure.


Your Investment & Your Return

Breaking it down:

  • I need $13,552.00 + Airfare
  • This is how it breaks down:
    Tuition for 2 classes = $7,322
    Mandated Insurance = $80
    Program Fees = $6,150
    __________________________
    Total Charges = $13,552
     - $5,287.33 (my SCAD scholarships)
    ___________________________
    BALANCE DUE = $8,264.67 + Airfare

WHAT IF YOU DO NOT REACH YOUR GOAL?
If I do not reach my goal the money raised will be sent to me and I will use it toward my trip. The money will still be used to go to France this summer. My spot is reserved and my classes are registered for so no matter what I am still going. The amount raised will determine how much I need to take out in loans, I am praying that I don't have to take any money out in loans.

The Impact

This campaign has the greatest impact on my academic financial history. I am 10 credits away from obtaining my undergraduate degree with a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Photography.
I am proud to say that I have completed 95%of my degree program without the use of any loans. By funding my campaign you are helping to assure that I have nothing to pay back after graduation.

If I do not reach my goal I will have to take out a loan to afford my studies in France.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, and that is understandable!
Instead I ask that you try one of the following:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Utilize the social media you have and share my campaign with others
  • Lastly, pray for me, my endeavors, and for safe travel!

story:
What is the Twin Cities Doula Project?

The Twin Cities Doula Project (TCDP) emerged from a desire to make birth doula care accessible to all families in the Twin Cities metro area of Minnesota.  A birth doula is a trained professional who provides continuous physical, emotional, and informational support to a mother during labor and the birth of her child.  Research shows that with continuous labor support complications are fewer, babies are healthier, and breastfeeding more successful.

TCDP offers free labor support to women who would like a doula at their birth but would otherwise be unable to afford one.  We intend to raise $750 in order to expand our promotional outreach to area hospitals, birth centers, and clinics and in doing so expand our services to mothers in need.  Thank you for your consideration of our campaign!

What We Need

TCDP is an entirely volunteer-run organization of birth doulas who offer free doula care to women in need.   In 2014, Twin Cities Doula Project will expand its promotional efforts to area hospitals, birth centers, and clinics in order to reach more women who are in need of free doula services.  Because we ask for no compensation from clients or their families, the support of the extended community is essential to cover costs for promotional printings, mailings, and conference attendance.  Would you be willing to donate $10, $20, or more to help us more effectively get the word out about our services to expectant mamas and families?

What You Get

Any donation you can offer is helpful to our work.  If you make a donation of any amount during the campaign we will list you on the Supporters Page of our website and give you a shout out of gratitude on our Facebook page.  Donations of $5 or more can expect a personal note of thanks in the mail.

In addition, $25 donations will receive an official TCDP button and $50 donations will receive a complimentary 2 oz. tea blend, hand-prepared by doula Melanie.  

Looking to de-stress during the busy holiday season?  Donations of $100 or more receive complimentary yoga instruction for two from doula and certified yoga instructor Nicole*.

Are you expecting or do you know someone who is?  Make a donation of $500 or more and receive free doula services from one of our very own TCDP doulas!*

We are confident that we will achieve our goal of $750.  Whatever money is earned will go directly toward outreach efforts that spread the word about our work.

*Note: This perk is available only to those in the Twin Cities metro area.  Not local?  Consider giving a perk to a friend or family member in the Twin Cities as a perfect holiday gift!

The Impact of a Doula

"I don’t know how I went through labor last time without a doula.  It was like she just knew exactly what to do and when to do it."     ~Annie, TCDP Client

Though only a year and a half old, the Twin Cities Doula Project has already welcomed over 30 trained volunteer doulas to its ranks and supported nearly 50 women in childbirth.  

Many of our clients have shared with us how crucial their doula’s support was during their labors.  Annie, a TCDP client, welcomed her second baby in April via VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean).  Take a moment to read Annie’s reflection on the birth of her baby girl and her gratitude to her TCDP doula, Mary.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not all are able to make a financial contribution.  Please consider supporting us by sharing our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family, and by referring expectant moms in need of free doula services to our website.  Thank you and Happy Holidays!
