story:
Short Summary

My name is Emily Bryson and I'm a graduate student at San Diego State University working toward a masters degree in environmental health. I have been selected by the California Environmental Health Association to be a part of their team of judges in the upcoming Greater San Diego Science and Engineering Fair for high school students in the greater San Diego area. As a component of the California Environmental Health Association’s (CEHA) outreach and recruitment efforts,a judging team has been assembled for the past 20 years to select and recognize projects with the focus of environmental health. Scholarship funds are are very limited this year and we, as judges, feel compelled to raise additional funds for scholarships to inspire and encourage future scientists and engineers. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise at least $500 with all proceeds going directly to the Greater San Diego Science and Engineering Fair scholarship fund through CEHA. We hope that these scholarships will show high school students that we believe in them enough to invest in their futures as scientists and engineers and the future of our field.   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you feel as passionate as we do about helping young scientists, The Greater San Diego Science and Engineering Fair still needs volunteers to help setup, judge, and work the event. If this is something you're interested in, please email or message me or visit:

http://www.gsdsef.org/volunteer/volunteershort....

story:
Hey guys!  My name is Avery.  I'm a junior studying psychology at the George Washington University, and I'm spending a semester abroad at The University of Cape Town in Cape town, South Africa with a service-learning program.  As part of the program, I am volunteering at Manenberg Primary School, an elementary school in one of the most dangerous townships in Cape Town.  

Manenberg is a township that is plagued by poverty, gangsterism, HIV/ADIS, unemployment, drugs, and violence.  The consequences of these issues not only have an effect on the individuals participating in the activities, but also on the children of the community that attend Manenberg Primary.  It is my sincere hope to raise the funds to not only renovate the current eating space in the school, but also to help create a sustainable vegetable garden which will supplement the meager feeding scheme already in place.

There are about 640 students in the school.  The government is only able to provide about 150 school meals.  As such, the 150 meals have to be stretched to feed 640 hungry children.  For most of the students, this fraction of a meal is the only thing they have to eat all day.  The current space in which the children eat is an old classroom that has not been updated since the school's founding in 1969- the flooring is peeling off, the paint is chipping off the walls, everything is covered in chalk and dust, and the furniture in the room is dilapidated.  These children need a safe, clean and healthy environment in which to eat!

What We Need 

In order to fully complete this project, we need $2,000 at a minimum.  In the cafeteria, we are looking to put in a new floor, paint the walls, make new curtains to hang over the windows (thanks for all your wonderful help with this already, Grammy!), and hang some educational posters regarding subjects like nutrition and hygiene.  For the garden, we need supplies such as seeds, fertilizer, and gardening tools.

Any contribution will help- the dollar can accomplish more than you might think! $15 can buy a can of vibrant, colorful paint (we decided on using primary colors!) that will light up the cafeteria and make the atmosphere more inviting. $10 can purchase several seed packets, which could help to provide the children of the school with essential vitamins and minerals. 

If we (unfortunately) don't reach our fundraising goal- don't worry! The existing funds will still go toward making a difference in the school, just not as big of a difference.  

The Impact

By investing in this school project, you are investing in the future of South Africa because aren't today's children tomorrow's future? Your contribution will make a world of a difference to these children.  These are eager, excited, strong, resilient children who, despite the odds, make it to school every day in an attempt to get a better education than their parents received.  They need proper nutrition and a bright, happy place to eat in order to flourish and fully reach their potential! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this campaign- we only have 15 days to reach our fundraising goal! Facebook, Twitter, e-mail, word of mouth, carrier pigeons... any sharing helps!!!! Thank you!!

story:
About the Booklet

We are starting this project to raise funds for the publication of a booklet detailing the history of the Bradford House and the Whiskey Rebellion.  The house was the home of David Bradford, a leader of the Whiskey Rebellion in western Pennsylvania.  The house was built in 1788.  Today, the Bradford House is recognized as a National Historic Landmark.  Schools, social organizations, tour buses and individuals come to the house for a unique history lesson led by our docents dressed in 18th century attire.   In addition, we offer educational outreach programs to schools and social organizations.

The booklet will be published by an online publishing company or a local publishing company.  I have set up meetings with both companies and have had extensive conversations with both.  I am looking for the best price for our non-profit association.

The booklet will be roughly 40 pages and will include approximately  50 images including pictures from 1965 when the Museum opened and copies of historic documents. 

The core of the booklet with contain information on:

  • David Bradford's biography
  • Whiskey Rebellion timeline
  • Rebecca Harding Davis' biography
  • National Historic Landmark Registration
  • House Ownership and BHHA Board Members
  • House Architecture and stonework
  • House Construction/Restoration
  • House tours
  • House furnishings
  • Garden
  • Archeologist studies

The booklet will be sold in our museum gift shop, at special events and online.

There has never been a booklet published on the Bradford House and many house visitors have requested such a booklet.  We are excited to produce a booklet and share the story of the Bradford House, its occupants and the Whiskey Rebellion.

About the Risks

Once the project is fully funded, we are faced with the typical publishing risks:  potential legal risks and production delays.  To reduce these legal risks, we plan on utilizing all of the photos and verbiage that is owned by the Bradford House.  In addition, we will obtain releases from all individuals whose materials (written and visual) we plan to include in the booklet.  To reduce the production delays, we have a team working on the core of this project and the actual publishing, formatting and editing will be done by a reputable publishing company.

About the Museum

2015 marks the 50th anniversary of the Bradford House being a museum.  The Museum is managed by the Bradford House Historical Association, which is a dedicated volunteer Board.  In addition, the staff includes one part time employee and seventeen volunteers.

About Us

At the present time I am the Bradford House Museum Administrator for this 501 (c) 3 corporation.  The museum receives no state funding.  We hold various fundraisers throughout the year to keep the museum open to the public.

The booklet will be published by an online publishing company or a local publishing company.  I have set up meetings with both companies and have had extensive conversations with both.  I am looking for the best price for our non-profit association.
The booklet will be roughly 40 pages and will include approximately  50 images including pictures from 1965 when the Museum opened and copies of historic documents.  The core of the booklet with contain information on:
David Bradford's biography
Whiskey Rebellion timeline
Rebecca Harding Davis' biography
National Historic Landmark Registration
House Ownership and BHHA Board Members 
House Architecture and stonework
House Construction/Restoration
House tours
House furnishings 
Garden 
Archeologist studies

The booklet will be sold in our museum gift shop, at special events and online.
There has never been a booklet published on the Bradford House and many house visitors have requested such a booklet.  We are excited to produce a booklet and share the story of the Bradford House, its occupants and the Whiskey Rebellion. 
About the Risks
Once the project is fully funded, we are faced with the typical publishing risks:  potential legal risks and production delays.  To reduce these legal risks, we plan on utilizing all of the photos and verbiage that is owned by the Bradford House.  In addition, we will obtain releases from all individuals whose materials (written and visual) we plan to include in the booklet.  To reduce the production delays, we have a team working on the core of this project and the actual publishing, formatting and editing will be done by a reputable 
publishing company.
About the Museum
2015 marks the 50th anniversary of the Bradford House being a museum.  The Museum is managed by the Bradford House Historical Association, which is a dedicated volunteer Board.  In addition, the staff includes one part time employee and seventeen volunteers.About Us
At the present time I am the Bradford House Museum Administrator for this 501 (c) 3 corporation.  The museum receives no state funding.  We hold various fundraisers throughout the year to keep the museum open to the public.

story:
Backstory 

At the tender age of 18 I went to University to study History, mainly because I liked my History teacher. After under a year I decided that I had chosen the completely wrong subject to study so took a few years (7 to be precise) to gather my thoughts an reassess what I wanted to do with life. Last year was my first year back at university I finished the year with a 1st. This year after reapplying for my student finance I have been told because of my previous study I am not eligible for funding but I will be next year. In the last couple of years University fees have been hiked up to an astronomical £9000, this is what I need to pay to get my degree and this is where I need YOUR help. 

Cut to the chase.

After exhausting all avenues of funding and scraping my savings together I have come up with £5500 of the £9000 required and secured a payment plan with the university however I am required to pay £7500 on Oct 1st.  
  • £3500 savings
  • £2000 family funding
  • Still in desperate need of £2000. 

If I am fortunate enough to raise anything at all, it will be used to pay my tuition fees anything over this amout will be used for books and my uniform. Yep thats right I need to invest £200 in a uniform to wear to University everyday.


Why support me? 

I want to change the world. Its taken me a VERY long time to figure out how I'm going to do that and find something that i'm passionate about. My Biomedical Science and Nutrition BSc Undergrad is just the beginning, I want to pursue a Masters, PHD, lecture and educate others on the importance of nutrition. 

So basically I am a complete nutrition geek, (anyone who has been in a room with me for longer than 15mins can attest to this.) I love learning, whether it be about human biology, performance or anything health related. This originates from my personal journey, from being a fat kid and have body dysmorphia for more years than I care to remember - enough of the sob story. I currently offer free coaching and advice to support those who want to make a change in their life.

In the UK, 64% of adults are classed as being overweight or obese. We also have the highest childhood obesity rate in Europe. I want to change the way people think about nutrition and its effect on our body, I want to empower kids and adults alike to think for themselves and question the "norm". Think a smaller, tanned, Northern version of Jamie Oliver for an idea of my intentions. (Side note : my cooking ability is pretty damn hot.)


Perks

Anyone kind enough to donate will receive homemade fruit & nut bars with a personalised thank you note. You can choose from : 
Chocolate Orange
Pecan Pie
Granola Bar
For those also interested I will provide weekly podcasts and videos on topics and modules from the degree course. This way you learn too.  

Please email fundingolly@gmail.com to place your orders.

story:
Short Summary

I teach an American Studies course at Trinity College on museum and library exhibitions--these are our future curators of historical societies and art galleries! One of the most engaging ways to promote collections or to explore a subject or theme is to create an exhibition—telling a story with artifacts. These are SIX STORIES told by my students with books, manuscripts, prints, etc. found in the special collections at Trinity College:

Voices for the Vote: What Women were Saying and Reading during the Fight for Suffrage (Gaia N. Cloutier ‘16)

The Impossibility of Translating Culture (Alix A. de Gramont ‘15)

Aotearoa: The Land of the Long White Cloud (Quirin A. Sackmann ‘15)

Vinegar Valentines (Meghan E. Shaw, graduate student)

Shall We Dance? The Evolution of Etiquette on the Dance Floor (Karen J. Tuthill-Jones, graduate student)

Functional Pottery in America (Mariah J. West, graduate student)

Our Budget

$1,500 for the design and printing of a full color brochure, with essays by each student and select images of the items in their shows (each donor gets a copy)

$500 for the catering

$200 for poster design and printing

$300 for live music (keyboard: classical)

The Impact

This is a practical application course, and part of our curriculum is fundraising. Spread the word, please, and come to the opening event if you can on December 10th!

story:
Our Nicaragua Project!

Hi everyone! Each year, Pacific University and the Jessie F. Richardson Foundation (JFRF) join forces to send a group of inter-professional students and faculty to Nicaragua to provide health-related services to Nicaraguan older adults. This year there are four occupational therapy students, Julia, Teresa, Katy, & Eva, along with pharmacy, physician assistant, and master of healthcare administration students, going to Nicaragua to improve the quality of life of the elderly citizens there.

The program is designed to assist abandoned older adults living in care homes funded by charitable organizations. The homes, "hogares" in Spanish, house older adults who can no longer care for themselves and do not have family to care for them.

Nicaragua is the second poorest country in the Western hemisphere, forcing many young people to find work in other countries, leaving behind their elder family members. 

Here's a little more information about each of the OT students:

  • Julia Naumes is a second year occupational therapy student who hopes to specialize in elder-care issues and neurological conditions. This service-learning trip will give her valuable information on how typical aging can affect a person's physical and mental well-being, as well as how it changes the individual's role and family dynamics. She is passionate about providing for those in need and believes that her time volunteering in Nicaragua will enable her to have a better appreciation for the US healthcare system, her family, and her education. She also feels blessed to have this interprofessional experience, as it will make her a better practitioner in the future, who knows the scope of practice and abilities of other healthcare professionals. 
  • Teresa Wright is a second year occupational therapy student who is drawn to facilitate adults and older adults with neurological conditions to live fulfilling lives. After majoring in Spanish and finding her passion for engaging people in meaningful activities, Teresa is eager to merge her two passions in this service-learning project. She is particularly enthusiastic about Nicaragua as this is more than a "trip"; it is an opportunity to facilitate sustainable change for the population of chronically underserved older adults. Teresa believes this service-learning project will challenge and strengthen her, both personally and professionally. She is honored to have been selected to participate in this experience and is grateful for the other students who also sought out this opportunity to invest in something bigger than themselves.
  • Katy Danforth is a second year occupational therapy student whose passion is helping adults with neurological conditions rediscover what they love to do. With a undergraduate background in Biology, Spanish, and Neuroscience, it only seemed natural to continue on the path to Nicaragua. Katy was interested in the Nicaragua program before she even was accepted to Pacific. She loves the sustainable mission of the program and the population it serves. Her favorite quote to describe her personal mission statement is as follows: Not all of us can do great things, but we can all do small things with great love. -St. Therese of Lisieux. This trip is dedicated to her dear friend Katie Chale, who passed away in September and dedicated her life to service, particularly those in Latin America. 
  • Eva Zajac is a third year occupational therapy student whose passion is to support the health and well-being of underserved populations across the lifespan. She has a background in psychology and has worked with individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds nationally as well as internationally. Eva is interested in community-based interventions in health promotion, and is excited to serve the elders in Nicaragua. 

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this fundraising project is to raise at least $3,200 to go towards our airfare, immunizations, accommodations, and insurance. As graduate students, we have limited personal funds to contribute and need all the help we can get. The money raised here goes back to covering the direct costs of our participation in the project and providing wonderful services to the people at the "hogar".

As a thank you to those who graciously donate $20.00 towards our trip, we will send a personalized postcard from Nicaragua with a gorgeous photo and details about our trip. See the other Perks we are offering, including post-cards, coffee, and cigars!

The Impact

In 2007, the first trip to Nicaragua with both organizations (Pacific & JFRF) was initiated. Together, we have established long-term interventions and have advanced sustainable healthcare within the means of the local economy of Nicaragua. This is extremely important because of the poverty levels and lack of education in Nicaragua. Our volunteer work makes a difference in the quality of life of not only the people living in the "hogares", but also the caregivers and surrounding community. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please spread the word about our campaign. Even if you do not have funds to contribute, you can help by spreading the word about our campaign. 

      We also need materials donated to lead group activities and provide for the basic needs of the people at the "hogar". Older adults in Nicaragua experience the long-term effects of aging, poverty, and a lifetime of poor healthcare. They do not have ready access to common over-the-counter pharmaceuticals, basic hygiene and self-care products. Older adults in the hogar also lack access to productive and leisure pastime activities. Items we need donated include:

      • Shampoo & Conditioner
      • Soap
      • Toothpaste
      • Pampers (or any brand of baby wipes)
      • Depends (or any incontinence guards) 
      • Games
      • Mittens, Scarfs & Hats
      • Construction Paper
      • Blank Christmas Cards 
      • Fabric scraps
      • Fleece fabric
      • Adaptive equipment

      You can sign up for FREE SAMPLES at 

      http://www.depend.com/products/get-samples?WT.mc_id=DPY&WT.srch=1, and https://www.poise.com/samples-and-offers/samples. 

      We could not do this without the love and support of our friends, family members, professors, and each other!

story:
Nurse Uganda offers Nursing students the opportunity for a unique and life changing elective. Nurse Uganda works with three charities; KISS (kiddies support scheme) Kids club Kampala and Hands for Hope, to support children and their families with healthcare and education. During the four weeks Nurses are expected to share skills and deliver health education in a variety of challenging healthcare settings to provide Ugandans with access and provisions to healthcare. This includes acute and community healthcare settings such as city slums, large towns, individual homes, rural settings, schools and government / private hospitals.

To be able to take part of the project I need to raise £2,600 to raise funds towards lifesaving treatments, and support healthcare for individuals, families and communities to improve quality of life to those in desperate poverty and the challenges they face.

Please donate to this meaningful and valuable project and make a difference to the lives of those in desperate need of your support.

For more information please contact me via Facebook.

Many thanks for your time to read this and any donations you are willing to make.

Katie

.

story:
My story

This October I am going to Brazil to volunteer with kids and young people in a favela in the north zone of Rio de Janeiro.

I will be working with a small organisation called CIACAC who works with the local community organising workshops and language classes to keep the kids off the streets. During my stay with CIACAC , I will be teaching yoga, dance and photography to kids of various ages. 

I believe that with my skills, I will be able to contribute to this organisation. My main aim is to share my passion for life with the local kids, give them an opportunity for a better future and a chance to expand their horizons while also having fun. 

What I Need & What You Get

I am looking for €500. The money will pay for the following:
  • compact cameras and transport costs ( in order for me to do photography workshops, I must bring the kids outside of the favela and therefore I need money to cover transport costs and also snacks for the kids.)
  • yoga mats ( for those you have mats to give away, you can also contact me, used mats are welcome) 
  • any remaining money will be donated to CIACAC  
For donations over €50, you will be rewarded with one of my images from the series ‘Rathmines Photographs’ ( 20cmx20cm, framed) 

    The Impact

    The classes will have an extremely positive effect on the kids and will give them an opportunity to learn something new. 

    Through photography they will be encouraged to develop their creativity and to share their vision with others while having fun. 

    CIACAC previously had a volunteer who taught yoga to the kids and they enjoyed it a lot. 

    This project will be a great contribution to the wonderful work that CIACAC is already doing promoting learning and education for the children. 


    My website : www.annaprzybylo.com
    CIACAC : http://www.ciacac.org

    Thank you! 

    Anna

story:
Short Summary

In the wake of Hurricane Sandy, thousands of volunteers flocked to the areas affected by the storm. In the case of Red Hook, Brooklyn, a dedicated core of volunteers took on the full gamut of relief: distribution of resources, allocating clean up and construction crews, and advocating for ongoing needs. Through the march of time, this core consolidated into what is now formally called the RED HOOK VOLUNTEERS. We at Red Hook Volunteers (RHV) are still working within the framework of giving relief to our community for free. Even with our small staff, we have had great success at fostering support for our efforts. Yet while we have been able get funding for our ongoing programs, little money is granted for administration costs, namely, rent. 

  • RHV is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization. We facilitated over 4,000 volunteers within the first 14 days. Since then we have coordinated over 7,000 volunteers into the community. We have helped over 500 addresses and continuously strive to shrink our client list, which is currently just around 100 people. 
  • This campaign is for one simple purpose: keep our doors open. We try to connect our neighborhood in more ways than one. Besides physical rebuilding, we open our space for art exhibits, community potlucks, workshops, and of course, our famous Friday Night Community Jam!
  • RHV is still the driving force behind Hurricane Sandy recovery in Red Hook. Yes, there is still work left to be done. Yes, there are people still displaced from their homes. Yes, volunteers and donations are still needed. 

YOU CAN HELP! A recovered neighborhood is a stronger neighborhood. A stronger neighborhood builds a more resilient New York City. And a more resilient New York City is exactly what is needed when another disaster hits again. JOIN US AND HELP BUILD A STRONGER NEW YORK CITY!

What We Need & What You Get

Let's get down to brass tacks here,

  • We need $2,500 to cover one month's rent. If we get over our initial goal, the remaining money will go towards rent. If we don't achieve the full $2,500, whatever we do receive will go towards rent. The great thing about this campaign is you know exactly where your donation is going. It's going to pay for rent.
  • Recognition goes a long way in this neighborhood. By helping us help others, your good name will be heralded through the streets and through the infinite spaces of cyberspace. There are even gilded treasures for gifts to those who are generous enough.  

Why this is important.

There is a simple and direct correlation between your donations and our success. 

  • Again, RHV is the driving force behind the ongoing recovery work in Red Hook. If we were to shutter our doors, the hopes of getting relief by so many homeowners, renters, and small business owners would be dashed. We continue to be the "boots on the ground" in the community; still cleaning, rebuilding, and physically helping as much as we can. 
  • We balance all physical recovery work with all administrative work.   
  • We do all of this with a core staff of FOUR people - all of us being in our mid-20's. There have been times where everyone has taken a pay cut. There have been months where we didn't get paid at all. This has never stopped us from sticking to our mission and doing as much as we can for our neighborhood. And please, this shouldn't be viewed as a "pity party" section, it's just to clarify that not getting paid personally, and not being able to pay the landlord, are two different things entirely. 

Our Risks

Obviously we can't keep crowd sourcing our rent money, but being that our situation has become somewhat critical, it has led us to all of you fine people. While time is a factor for this instance, we otherwise mitigate financial crises by

  • research and network as much as possible as to what grants are available and how effective they will be in our disaster response work.
  • By having partners with local, state, and federal government agencies as well as local and national NGO's throughout our organization's life, we have gained an invaluable understanding on how these different bodies can help one another out - avenues we are perpetually seeking out. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Love us, just got no cash?? DON'T FRET. Remember, the V in RHV is for Volunteers. We have plenty of work that needs to get done, so if you're down for the cause, here are other ways you can do your part.  

  • We always need SKILLED and UNSKILLED volunteers to help out. Anything from cleaning, to carpentry and plumbing, to database management and I.T. - basically if you can help, WE WANT YOU.  
  • SHOUTOUT TO ANY C.P.A'S - We at Red Hook Volunteers are very interested in on-boarding a C.P.A. to volunteer some time with us. Please pass the word along to any and all C.P.A's that are awesome and want to help out.

RHV is a registered 501(c)3 non-profit organization. We facilitated over 4,000 volunteers within the first 14 days. Since then we have coordinated over 7,000 volunteers into the community. We have helped over 500 addresses and continuously strive to shrink our client list, which is currently just around 100 people.  This campaign is for one simple purpose: keep our doors open. We try to connect our neighborhood in more ways than one. Besides physical rebuilding, we open our space for art exhibits, community potlucks, workshops, and of course, our famous Friday Night Community Jam! RHV is still the driving force behind Hurricane Sandy recovery in Red Hook. Yes, there is still work left to be done. Yes, there are people still displaced from their homes. Yes, volunteers and donations are still needed.  YOU CAN HELP! A recovered neighborhood is a stronger neighborhood. A stronger neighborhood builds a more resilient New York City. And a more resilient New York City is exactly what is needed when another disaster hits again. JOIN US AND HELP BUILD A STRONGER NEW YORK CITY!   What We Need & What You Get Let's get down to brass tacks here, 
We need $2,500 to cover one month's rent. If we get over our initial goal, the remaining money will go towards rent. If we don't achieve the full $2,500, whatever we do receive will go towards rent. The great thing about this campaign is you know exactly where your donation is going. It's going to pay for rent. Recognition goes a long way in this neighborhood. By helping us help others, your good name will be heralded through the streets and through the infinite spaces of cyberspace. There are even gilded treasures for gifts to those who are generous enough.     Why this is important. There is a simple and direct correlation between your donations and our success.  
Again, RHV is the driving force behind the ongoing recovery work in Red Hook. If we were to shutter our doors, the hopes of getting relief by so many homeowners, renters, and small business owners would be dashed. We continue to be the "boots on the ground" in the community; still cleaning, rebuilding, and physically helping as much as we can.  We balance all physical recovery work with all administrative work.    We do all of this with a core staff of FOUR people - all of us being in our mid-20's. There have been times where everyone has taken a pay cut. There have been months where we didn't get paid at all. This has never stopped us from sticking to our mission and doing as much as we can for our neighborhood. And please, this shouldn't be viewed as a "pity party" section, it's just to clarify that not getting paid personally, and not being able to pay the landlord, are two different things entirely.    Our Risks Obviously we can't keep crowd sourcing our rent money, but being that our situation has become somewhat critical, it has led us to all of you fine people. While time is a factor for this instance, we otherwise mitigate financial crises by
research and network as much as possible as to what grants are available and how effective they will be in our disaster response work.
By having partners with local, state, and federal government agencies as well as local and national NGO's throughout our organization's life, we have gained an invaluable understanding on how these different bodies can help one another out - avenues we are perpetually seeking out. 
Other Ways You Can Help Love us, just got no cash?? DON'T FRET. Remember, the V in RHV is for Volunteers. We have plenty of work that needs to get done, so if you're down for the cause, here are other ways you can do your part.   
We always need SKILLED and UNSKILLED volunteers to help out. Anything from cleaning, to carpentry and plumbing, to database management and I.T. - basically if you can help, WE WANT YOU.   SHOUTOUT TO ANY C.P.A'S - We at Red Hook Volunteers are very interested in on-boarding a C.P.A. to volunteer some time with us. Please pass the word along to any and all C.P.A's that are awesome and want to help out.

story:
The Future We Are Creating

Canine Assisted Therapy, Inc. (C.A.T.)  has seen a need for the development of materials that can be utilized during our Pack Reader and Read-a-thon events with children. Due to a lack of educational materials on how to approach a dog correctly and the appropriate ways to interact with animals and each other C.A.T. has written a book called Georgia’s Tale. This book will be used in one-on-one reading sessions with 1st and 2nd grade students in South Florida. The book also will be used during school Read-a-thons where over a hundred children read to the therapy dogs during one session.

Not only will students come away with knowledge on interacting with dogs, a higher reading level and increased self esteem but they will also go home with the book. By getting the books into the children’s homes for them to share with siblings and parents, we hope to reduce the number of dog-bite injuries and emotional scars affecting children; lower medical costs; provide fewer insurance claims associated with dog bites; and decrease the number of dogs euthanized for biting children who may have unknowingly provoked them.

The sponsorship funds will be used specifically for expenses related to publishing and distributing the book created by Canine Assisted Therapy, Inc. This sponsorship would allow for the creation, layout, design, artwork, proofing, ISBN and copyright and misc. expenses involved in the creation of the book. The message the book will convey is to be kind and responsible to animals but will also instill the notion that they should be kind and show good behavior towards each other. The book will relay an anti-bullying message as well as an educational lesson. 

How We Are Creating It

A group of Canine Assisted Therapy volunteers consisting of grade school teachers, a speech therapist, music teacher, and business leaders got together to write a book about approaching and interacting with dogs from the dog's perspectitive. 

The book will be illustrated in a way that will be appealing to children and adults alike. Once complete, the book will be printed and used in reading programs. The books will be left with the children to take home and to share with siblings, family and friends.

Budget for “Georgia’s Tale”:

Illustrator:                                                         $2,500

Layout, proofing, design:                               $1,615
ISBN, barcode, e-book formatting costs:   $550
Copyright fee:                                                         $35
Printing 2,000 books:                                    $2,200

                                                        Total:  $6,900

Our Story & Why You Should Support Us

Founded in 2009, Canine Assisted Therapy, Inc. (C.A.T.) is the premier volunteer pet therapy organization in South Florida, currently with 125 certified pet therapy teams.  C.A.T.’s mission is to provide support, training, education, and mentoring to those interested in volunteer dog therapy programs in Miami-Dade, Broward, and Palm Beach Counties and builds connections between volunteers and facilities. C.A.T. has received national and international inquiries on how to establish a similar program. 

The organization is unique and different than other pet therapy organizations in that it requires Level 2 background checks for the handlers, provides a mentoring program to new volunteer teams, offers pet therapy preparation classes and mandates an additional evaluation to work with children.

C.A.T. has provided pet therapy programs and formed partnerships with organizations such as Dade, Broward and Palm Beach County School Districts; SafePlace; Ann Storck Center; Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital; Family Central; Veterans Hospitals in Sunrise and West Palm Beach; Kids in Distress; Broward Guardian ad Litem; 17th Judicial District; Ronald McDonald Houses in Miami and Ft. Lauderdale; Girl Scouts of Southeast Florida and Equine Assisted Therapies of South Florida, Inc.

The following is a brief overview of C.A.T. programs:                                                          

  • Dogs Healing Hearts:
    • Teams work with veterans, and other adults with psychiatric disorders like post-traumatic stress, schizophrenia, bipolar disorders, and children and adults in grief counseling.
    • Teams assist physical, occupational and speech therapists when working with individuals on the autism spectrum, cerebral palsy, traumatic brain injury, and other physical rehab issues.
  • Dogs in the Judicial System:
    • Helps children traumatized by an event and calms them for testimony in a courtroom or other similar setting.  The teams working in this capacity need very specialized training.
  • Pack Reader Program:
    • Helps students achieve grade level reading including those learning English as a second language or children with self-esteem issues.  The reading-challenged children in the program often view reading as a chore. But dogs don’t judge, so reading to them removes inhibitions and helps a child focus. It makes reading fun and creates a positive, memorable experience that stays with children for a long time.
    • Animal Assisted Activities (AAA) for seniors:
      • Helps elderly in assisted care facilities or senior care centers relieve loneliness and anxiety by interacting with the dogs.

story:
This campaign is now closed and we are thrilled that we surpassed our goal! To donate now please visit www.miraclefeet.org. 

Why clubfoot?

Clubfoot affects one out of every 750 children worldwide, making it one of the most common birth defects in the world. Yet it is one most people might not even be aware of.  In the US, Europe and the UK, it is usually detected in utero and treated shortly after birth, allowing the child to live a healthy, active lifestyle. In fact, Mia Hamm, Kristi Yamaguchi, Steven Gerrard and Troy Aikman - all very successful athletes - were born with clubfoot and received proper treatment.

In contrast, 80% of children born with clubfoot in the rest of the world have no access to treatment.  This is untreated clubfoot in a young child:

What if clubfoot doesn't ever get treated?

Unfortunately, children living with untreated clubfoot face incredible hurdles their whole lives. Often they are shunned from society – left alone and hidden away because the family is ashamed. Because walking is so difficult, they are usually unable to attend school. These children are subjected to much higher risk of neglect, poverty, physical and sexual abuse.  They might end up begging and facing a life of discrimination and pain. Below is a photo of a young father in India who lives with untreated clubfoot (on left) and his son Pradeep, who was also born with clubfoot, but is being treated in a miraclefeet-supported clinic. See a video of their story here.

Founded by parents of children born with clubfoot in the US, miraclefeet increases access to proper treatment for children born with clubfoot in developing countries through our partnerships with local healthcare providers. In just 4 years, miraclefeet has helped change the lives of more than 6,000 children in 12 different countries.  What we do goes beyond fixing feet. This is not just about treating clubfoot - it is is about lowering the chances of living a life of poverty, abuse and neglect in a  vulnerable group of children who can easily be identified and helped. We are helping them rewrite their story and  transform their lives with this low-cost, non-surgical and relatively easy treatment.

How does it work?
Unlike so many of the world’s problems, this one is solvable – and surprisingly inexpensive. miraclefeet supports local health practitioners in developing countries who are trained in the Ponseti method, a non-surgical treatment that involves a series of simple, properly applied plaster casts that are changed weekly. In 95% of cases, this results in full correction of the foot in four to six weeks of casting. Following casting, a brace is worn at night for several years to prevent relapse.  The total cost of treatment? Only $250 per child. It’s a small price to pay to transform a child’s life.

The innovation.

The miraclefeet brace is a low-cost ($20) foot abduction brace developed at the Stanford d.school through the Design for Extreme Affordability course, in collaboration with miraclefeet, Clarks Shoes and Suncast, to treat clubfoot using the non-surgical Ponseti method. Brace compliance is the most important variable in achieving a good treatment outcome: corrected feet and the ability to walk, run and play as any child should be able to. 

This brace was designed specifically for low resource settings with children and their parents in mind. The brace was designed to be tamper-proof and easy-to-use, simplifying the daily bracing struggle that caregivers endure so as to improve compliance rates in the  treatment process. The lightweight, child-friendly design includes easy-on, easy-off accessibility through detachable shoes and built-in stability for standing and walking. Using plastic injection-molding manufacturing methods to keep costs low, our brace is easily scalable for distribution in low-resource countries and we are about to start that process. 

Bracing has been one of the biggest hurdles in scaling up Ponseti treatment globally.  Having an off-the-shelf, inexpensive foot abduction brace keeps the cost of treatment low. This will significantly increase the chance that governments and hospitals will make proper treatment available for the 160,000 children born each year in developing countries who are currently at risk of a life of pain, marginalization, abuse and poverty because of untreated clubfoot. Over a ten-year period, this brace could enable as many as 1.6 million children to live active  and productive lives for a relatively small investment. 

The Ponseti timeline below shows the importance of the bracing phase over the 4-5 year treatment, which typically lasts from seven weeks to four-years-old:

The miraclefeet brace innovation has been covered by:

The campaign will specifically send braces to children with clubfoot being treated by miraclefeet-supported clinics in the following places. Each boot below represents 100 children:

How you can help.
All  donations to the Indiegogo campaign will go directly to getting braces to children in Brazil, Nicaragua, Ecuador, Mexico, South Africa, Liberia, Botswana, Namibia and the Philippines.  We have received corporate, foundation and individual support of this project, but we need your help to get the braces distributed to all of the countries mentioned above in the next six months.Our goal is to get the brace to every child in miraclefeet-supported clinics around the world by 2016. Every donation is tax-deductible.
  • $20 provides a child with clubfoot with one brace
  • $40 provides a child with two braces - they need up to four to complete treatment
  • $50 provide a brace, family transportation and casting for one child
  • $100 provides family follow up, bracing, casting and transportation
  • $250 provides full Ponseti treatment to one child
  • $1,000 provides full Ponseti treatment to FOUR children
The new miraclefeet clubfoot brace.

Anthony testing out the miraclefeet brace.

A smile that penetrates: Joao in Brazil with corrected feet.

$250 provides full Ponseti treatment to one child

Anthony testing out the miraclefeet brace.

story:
About Us

Founded in 2008 by educators Gillian Barclay-Smith and Edith Bailey, The Barclay School is a nonprofit, year round K-12 school primarily offering educational services to children with learning differences. These differences include dyslexia, dysgraphia, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, Asperger’s syndrome, and other diagnosed learning differences. The primary mission of the school is to provide a rich, diverse curriculum in a safe, nurturing environment for children in the Columbia, South Carolina area. The Barclay school is also the home of ‘Bunnies’ Brew’,  “nature’s best organic fertilizer,” manufactured by the children of the school.

About The Project

Over the past year, we as a school have grown to the point where we are running out of space! We began looking into expansion and into adding another building but then we realized we had the chance to do something special, building and using the state's first state-permitted, all-natural building. We began looking further into to see how possible it was and eventually found a dynamic architect with a passion for natural building, a structural engineer, and a contractor.  Their work convinced the City of Columbia to provide the first permit for a rammed earth building in our state.  (Rammed earth was used locally in the mid 19th century.) The Richland County Conservation Commission even gave us a grant for $22,000 to get our project rolling. (THANK YOU County Commissioners and County Council for support of an innovative project!)  All signs are now go, all we need now is the rest of the funds for the project to begin!

What We Need & What You Get

The total remainder of funds needed to complete the building is about $20,000. This money will ensure that once the we break ground that the building will be completed on schedule. For any contribution our donors will receive perks from our greatest gratitude to actually participating in a all-natural building workshop themselves! Check out our perks to learn more!

The Impact

Not only does this project impact the Barclay School, it also impacts the community of Columbia, South Carolina. Members of the community can come and learn more about what it takes to build a building naturally and even participate in building workshops. Not to mention the beauty that a building like this can offer to the area!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word, anything helps!

story:
Make a unique connection that can last a lifetime.

Our Adopt A Vet Program allows you and your family to develop a special bond with one of our veterans currently enrolled in our reintegration programs. Make a lasting change in a veteran's life by helping provide safe & stable housing, nutrition and health services, counseling, workforce development programs and life-skills training.

We are asking YOU to help us continue to offer these fundamental programs to our veteran population.  We Can't Do It Alone.

Because we currently receive no funding from the government, we depend on the generosity of our community to help us cover the costs to provide the housing and services required to change the lives of veterans and their families.

Our Adopt A Vet Program allows you to develop a relationship with an individual veteran and be there for their milestones in recovery and reintegration back into the Metro-Atlanta community. With your support, you are helping transform the lives and hearts of veterans in our great city.

1 in 4 homeless individuals has served as an American Veteran. Now is the time to take action and change the lives of the veterans in our community.

About VEO:

Having a stable and safe place to sleep, clean up, get a meal, and a place to prepare mentally are the first steps in an effective job search and maximizing education and vocational training. But, really...they are the first steps in living. 

Veterans Empowerment Organization (VEO) has helped thousands of veterans and their families obtain immediate and permanent housing, food, clothing, and support services, since 2008. 

VEO is filling the gap & meeting unmet needs among the veteran community. VEO offers a continuum of care that includes immediate and long-term housing, treatment and recovery for addiction, food, and clothing, as well as medical, counseling and job placement.


Other Ways To Show Your Support:

Please help us get the word out about our fundraiser by sharing our campaign page!

  1. Share this campaign by using the share tools on this page 
  2. "Like & Share" our Facebook Page
  3. "Tweet" #AdoptAVet @VEOHERO
  4. Sign up for our email list
  5. Volunteer

Other Ways To Show Your Support:

Please help us get the word out about our fundraiser by sharing our campaign page!


Share this campaign by using the share tools on this page 


"Like & Share" our Facebook Page

"Tweet" #AdoptAVet @VEOHERO

Sign up for our email list

story:
Help the Debra S. Fish Early Childhood Resource Library at Think Small® purchase bilingual children’s books to support young English language learners' reading skills in preparation for kindergarten!

These dual language children’s books will help ease the process of learning English for immigrant and refugee children by presenting written English alongside a child’s primary language. At Think Small one of our goals is for Minnesota's bilingual and English language learning children to start kindergarten with the same reading skills as their peers.

Our goal is to raise $500 to purchase 33 dual language books so families across the state will have free and easy access to books they can read with their children.


WHY EARLY LITERACY SKILLS MATTER

A child’s early literacy skills—such as vocabulary size, letter recognition, and understanding of letter sounds—are consistent predictors of a child’s reading abilities in kindergarten, throughout his or her schooling, and in life. Yet, 40% of Minnesotan children start kindergarten not fully prepared (Minnesota Department of Education 2012). At Think Small we strive to close Minnesota’s achievement gap before a child enters school by working with providers and parents to implement research-supported methods to ensure healthy development and prepare children for kindergarten. A key part of this approach is providing educational resources that support essential skills such as early literacy.


WHY BILINGUAL BOOKS?

Minnesota is home to many refugee and immigrant populations. In fact, the Twin Cities Metropolitan Area has the largest Hmong, Karen, and Somali populations in the United States. The Karen and Hmong people are ethnic minority groups from East and Southeast Asia that have immigrated as refugees to Minnesota.

Life as a New American comes with many challenges, including learning a new language. Bilingual books ease this transition by presenting English alongside a child’s primary language in popular children’s books such as The Very Hungry Caterpillar and My First Words at Home. It can be difficult to find materials in languages like Karen in Minnesota, so these books will also serve as a resource to connect these groups to their primary language.

These books reinforce early learners’ language skills and prepare them to participate in an English-speaking classroom—especially important when English is not the primary language spoken in the home. Parents and providers who are not fluent in English can use these books to nurture children’s English skills with age appropriate vocabulary and correct grammar. Additionally, providers and pre-school teachers who speak only English can use these books to support a child’s cultural and linguistic background. 


WHY THESE FOUR LANGUAGES?

We are buying books in English/Hmong, English/Karen, English/Somali, English/Spanish because these are the most prevalent languages besides English spoken by the families Think Small serves. 


OUR LIBRARY

The Debra S. Fish Early Childhood Resource Library at Think Small is the region’s largest early childhood education resource library collection. Housed in St. Paul, Minnesota, we offer diverse resources for parents and providers to support healthy development and quality education for children 0-5. We have over 5,000 items on a variety of topics: child development and learning, early childhood literacy, the business of child care, parenting and much more. These materials are available for checkout for anyone with a public library card and they can be requested and delivered to local libraries through the state.

Think Small is a 501(c)(3) non-profit agency dedicated to advancing quality care and education of children in their crucial early years in Minnesota and beyond by Strengthening Families, Preparing Providers and Advocating for Change. 


The Debra S. Fish Library:

www.thinksmall.org/for_early_childhood_professionals/debra_s_fish_library

Learn Other Ways Think Small Advances Quality Care and Education of Young Children:

www.thinksmall.org

Questions?

Contact Gracie Klumpp  gklumpp@thinksmall.org

story:
I am a 21 year old female pursing a premed/biology degree at Baker University in Kansas.  I received a scholarship in high school to attend Baker due to my academic success and ACT score.  I commute 20 minutes every day and the gas money is considerably expensive.  Although I receive scholarships and grants, I still have a debt that I must pay before I can enroll every semester.  This debt has put a huge strain on me every enrollment time because I have to come up with at least 1,200 dollars.  I have paid out of pocket and I have borrowed money from family members to try to attend Baker each semester.  I have three semesters to go before I can attend Medical school. 
 
I want to start this campaign to raise money to keep attending Baker University.  My dream career is to become a general practice doctor and contribute to my community.  I have a passion for science and health and I love helping people.  I had hoped in high school that I could combine those two passions in a health career.  There was a doctor that came and visited my high school that inspired me to pursue a career in general practice medicine.  I work every weekend four shifts at the local nursing home and I still don't have enough money to pay for food, gas, and rent.  I hope that family members and supporters for future doctors can help me out, every little bit counts.
If people are willing to donate to my cause, I will make them proud by continuing my studies at Baker university.  I have a love for learning and I could engage more in school if I did not have to constantly worry about my financial situation.  I hope that people will be willing to help me one day help them.  I want to some day help people through medicine and make a great doctor.  With more money I would not have to worry about whether or not I can make it to school that day or whether or not I can continue to next semester. 
 
If I am able to raise my goal amount of money, I will be able to pay off my debt for this semester and I will be able to enroll.  If I can raise more than the goal amount, then I can put that money in an account in the bank for the next semesters text books and gas money to commute.  The more money I can raise, the more I can save it for next semesters or even medical school.

The Impact

Any amount of money will help me in my journey through college.  If I can raise any amount of money I will be happy because I know that people out their were willing to support a future doctor.  I want people to trust in me and believe that I can achieve excellence in my education and becoming a great doctor.

     

Risks & Challenges

 Challenges of this campaign include getting people engaged and spreading the word of who I am and what I stand for.  I believe with a little help, I can go far and purse my dreams of becoming a great doctor. 

Just as I did on facebook, I will have troubles spreading the word of my campaign, but I will not give up because I believe in myself and I have faith that others will support me in my journey, especially if I can one day give back to the community through my knowledge of medicine.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help,  If you support my campaign, just spreading the word can help me.  Recognizing that students in college are in need of financial aid, is support enough in some cases.

story:
Funding Goal: $3600

Book Project: Intuitive Art

Created while undergoing

Hatha Yoga Teacher Training

Goa, India with Vijay Amar (500 hours)
http://www.vijaypoweryoga.com
Objective: 
  • Challenge my Body and Mind in 500 hours of Hatha Yoga study
  •  Illustrate in pen ink my subconscious experience – 70 days of training, 70 intuitive illustrations – a book of Yogini Art.
 

 

 

 

 

 I am excited and honored to invite you to travel with me through this 70-day Hatha Yoga training in Goa, India.  

 

Breakdown of Monetary Expenses:

Visa Cost+Print Cost+Shipping Cost:  $150+20+40=$210

Air Travel Cost: (Hawaii to Boston- JFK to Abu Dhabi to Dabolim) 500+1000=$1500

Approximate Course Cost/Accommodations/Food: $3000 

Total Necessary Expenses for this Trip: $4710

story:
First of all I know that it isn't the right category for my project. But since there is no other suitable category for my project, i decided to present it here and i hope that you'd be patient with my project and thank you so much.

I am sixteen years old and I live in the north part of Israel, in Yizrael valley close by Nazareth. I am really fond of motorized field trips and I've recently got my driving license which is suitable for driving side-by-side vehicles.

Since I'd love to contribute to the society and to my community, I had an idea how  to combine my favorite activity with volunteering myself for children with special needs. Which means that I would like to arrange motorized field trips for children with special needs that are fond of such trips as I am. My plan is that every weekend I would drive a side-by-side vehicle with a child seating at the passenger seat and go on a field trip.

I am sure that the children would have fun and great time. This will make them very happy.

The thing is that I had a plan to purchase a specific side-by-side vehicle, which is called Wildcat-X 2014. Unfortunately, this is a very expensive one and I do not have the entire amount which is required to finance that purchase. Such a vehicle would cost around 30,000 US dollars in Israel (including taxes). Since I already got half of that amount, I would like to ask each of you to help with a small but valuable contribution in order to finance at least the other half of the vehicle price, which is 15,000 US dollars.

On top of that, besides contributing for children with special needs, I would like to make an offer for you as well. As you know, there are many holly places in Israel for different religions. If you wish so, I would receive from you your name or your beloved names with your special blessing that you may wish me to say for you at any of the holy places in Israel, for example, in Nazareth, Jerusalem, Tiberius. Then I would arrive at these places accompanied by the Wildcat-X vehicle and make the blessing for you per your specific request and I will also record it for you.

I hope I made my point clear and please join me to help children with special needs, helping you to be blessed and to make my dream come true.

story:
Why Ethiopia?

In 2012 I was able to take a trip to Ethiopia with my church, Tapestry. I had never been to Africa and didn't really know what to expect. Lions? Elephants? Skinny people that can run real fast? Yeah, I didn't see any of those but what I did see were people in need. On our trip we played with kids, fed kids, provided groceries for families, and put on a few new roofs. But it wasn't enough. So now we're headed back! This time we're going to build a school. 

Why a School?

72% of school-aged children in Ethiopia do not have access to formal education. This is clearly evident by the poverty that can be seen throughout the country. In rural Ethiopia there aren't many options for what someone can do with their life. By building a school, we are opening doors and creating options for people to change their lives. We are giving them a chance to get themselves and their families out of the poverty they live in.

Why I need $ 1,500

Simply put, your donation will help pay for:

  • My travel expenses to include airfare, ground travel, and accommodations
  • My translators. On our last trip we built a very close relationship with our translators. Your donation will give them a job for 3 weeks!
The total cost of the trip is $ 2,500. I am only asking for $ 1,500 because I am earning the rest by working extra jobs and overtime. I wouldn't ask you to make a sacrifice unless I am willing to do it also.

Fears & Concerns

  • My wife, Sarah, and I are both making this trip. That's $ 5,000 we have to come up with! If we are not able to reach our goals then only one of us will be able to make the trip.
  • I will be staying for 3 weeks while others from the church will come on two separate trips. That's a long time to be away from home and living in a rural area of Ethiopia. 
  • I will be a team leader for our group. To me this means, keeping everyone safe, fed, and as comfortable as possible while also motivated to continue the work, no matter how hard.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not everyone has extra money. That's ok! If you can't make a monetary donation we can use help here too:
  • Pray
  • Donate supplies - we can use different types of medical supplies but also soccer balls, shoes, and other clothes. Contact me on how to get them to us.

story:
Yolsuzluğu Önlemek İçin Çalışan Cesur Gençlere Destek İçin YARDIMINIZI BEKLİYORUM

Merhaba,

Size hem “Accountability Lab” isimli sosyal sorumluluk kurumunu hem de bu kurumun projelerine sağlamak istediğim katkıyı anlatmak istiyorum.

Accountability Lab, birçok ödül almış, uluslararası alanda faaliyet gösteren kar amacı gütmeyen bir kuruluştur. (http://www.accountabilitylab.org ) Dünya üzerinde zorluk yaşayan bazı ülkelerde yolsuzluk karşıtı ve hesap verilebilirliliği sağlama amacıyla dünya çapında ihtiyaç duyan ülkelerde etkinlikler düzenlemektedir. Bu etkinliklerde görev alan katılımcılar etkinliğin düzenlendiği ülkedeki topluma eğitim, danışmanlık, network, yönetim desteği gibi desteklerde bulunmaktadır.

Ödül kazanmış bir sivil toplum kuruluşu olan Accontibility Lab, dünyanın en zor ve problemli yerlerindeki insanları, yolsuzluğa karşı mücadele ve toplumsal sorumluluk kazandırmak için kullanabilecekleri etkin ve düşük maliyetli araçları geliştirmek için kurulmuştur. Accontibility Lab, kendi bölgesinde değişim için yaratıcı fikirleri olan "değişim ajanlarına" eğitim, yol gösterilmesi, iletişim ağı sağlanması yönetim desteği ve başlangıç için maddi kaynak sağlıyor.

Bu sene de  4 ülkede yolsulsuzluk ve rüşvete karşı bilgilendirme amaçlı ve buna bağlı oluşan açlık, fakirlik ve dışlanmaya yönelik dikkat çekmek için etkinlik düzenlemektedir. Bu etkinlikler kapsamında katılan kişilerin bu konularda mesleki ve kişisel birikimlerini ihtiyacı olan toplumlara aktarılması amaçlanmaktadır.

Bu amaca hizmet eden yeğenim Can Atacık’tan öğrendiğim bu proje, bir insan ve 40 yıllık hukukçu olarak beni çok heyecanlandırdı ve gelecek için umutlandırdı. Bu projeyi yürüten ve projeye katılan gençlere destek olmak için ben de gönüllülere katılıyorum.

Accountability Lab projesinin gerçekleştireceği, sistematik yolsuzluk ve rüşvet nedeniyle halkının ciddi sorunlar yaşadığı, açlık ve fakirlikle boğulan Nepal’de Eylül 2014’te yolsuzlukla mücadele amaçlı etkinliğe katılmaya karar verdim. Ben de çeşitli ülkelerden gelen diğer gönüllü katılımcılarla birlikte bu etkinliğe katılıp, Nepal’li gençlerin yolsuzlukla mücadele etmek için hazırladıkları projeleri inceleyip, bilgilendirme ve bilinçlerdirme yoluyla çalışmalarına destek vereceğim. Dünyanın birçok yerinden ve çeşitli mesleklere sahip katılımcılar  bu etkinlikte yer alacaklar.

Tüm seyahat masraflarımı kendim karşılıyorum ve yolsuzluğa karşı mücadele eden Accountability Lab’in projelerine destek için 5.000 dolarlık bir yardım kampanyası başlatıyorum. Sizden bu kampanyama bağışta bulunmanızı rica ediyorum. Bu para ile en az 2 projenin 1 yıl boyunca tüm gereksinimlerini karşılamış ve yolsuzlukla mücadelede katkı sağlamış olacaksınız.  Gelin yolsuzlukla mücadele eden genç nesile birlikte destek verelim. Gönlünüzden ne koparsa o kadar bağışı www.accountabilitylab.org sitesinde bulunabilirsiniz.


Bir yerden başlar, tüm dünyaya yayılır. Hepimiz aynı gemideyiz. Yapacağınız bağışın her kuruşunun cesur gençler için harcanacağından emin olun. isterseniz siz de benim gibi bu çalışmada gönüllü olarak yer alabilirsiniz.  Önümüzdeki senelerde bu girişimi Türkiye'de de yapmayı umuyoruz.

Projeye destek verenler arasından Productive Yapım tarafından hazırlanan proje tanıtım videosunu bu linkte bulabilirsiniz https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yy_v-ce0n-0 .

Nepal'deki projeler şunlar: genç Nepal 'lilerin, toplumun sorunları hakkında belgesel film yapabilmeleri için Accountibility Film Okulu açılması; araştırmacı gazetecilere hükümetten bilgi almada karşılaştıkları zorlukları aşabilmek için el kitabı hazırlanması; pratik yurttaşlık eğitimlerini, okul müfredatına katmaya yardımcı olacak bir program geliştirilmesi; kamu hizmetlerinden yararlanılabilmesi için online bilgi sağlama platformu kurulması; ve Dürüstlük Abidesi adlı, en dürüst kamu görevlilerinin öne çıkartıldığı bir TV programı yapılması. Bunlar, topluca, toplumsal sorumluluk için canlı, tabandan başlayan ve ülkedeki insanların hayatlarında gerçek bir etki yapacak bir hareketi başlatacaktır.

Sizi daha temiz, onurlu ve yoksulluktan kurtulmuş bir dünyaya doğru bir adım atabilmek için bu projeye destek vermeye, bağışta bulunmaya davet ediyorum. Eminim gençlerin yolsuzlukla mücadele kararı ve eylemi sizi de umutlu ve mutlu etmiştir. Cesur gençlerin yolsuzluk, kaynakların yanlış kullanımı ve yoksulluk için hazırladıkları projelere gönlünüzden kopan bağışlarınızla destek vermeyi, onları daha da cesaretlendirmeyi en az benim kadar istediğinize, önemsediğinize inanıyorum.

Lütfen bu onurlu yaşam, yolsuzlukla mücadele hareketine bağışta bulunarak destek verin.

Detaylı bilgi edinmek isterseniz lütfen çekinmeden iletişime geçiniz.

Desteğinize şimdiden çok teşekkür ediyorum.

Şeyda
story_txt:
Yolsuzluğu Önlemek İçin Çalışan Cesur Gençlere Destek İçin YARDIMINIZI BEKLİYORUM
Merhaba,
Size hem
“Accountability Lab” isimli sosyal sorumluluk kurumunu hem de bu kurumun projelerine sağlamak istediğim katkıyı anlatmak istiyorum.
Accountability Lab,
birçok ödül almış, uluslararası alanda faaliyet gösteren kar amacı gütmeyen bir kuruluştur. (http://www.accountabilitylab.org ) Dünya üzerinde zorluk yaşayan bazı
ülkelerde yolsuzluk karşıtı ve hesap verilebilirliliği sağlama amacıyla dünya çapında ihtiyaç duyan ülkelerde
etkinlikler düzenlemektedir. Bu etkinliklerde görev alan katılımcılar
etkinliğin düzenlendiği ülkedeki topluma eğitim, danışmanlık, network, yönetim desteği gibi desteklerde bulunmaktadır.
Ödül kazanmış bir sivil toplum kuruluşu olan Accontibility Lab, dünyanın en zor ve
problemli yerlerindeki insanları, yolsuzluğa karşı mücadele ve toplumsal sorumluluk kazandırmak için
kullanabilecekleri etkin ve düşük maliyetli araçları geliştirmek için kurulmuştur. Accontibility Lab, kendi bölgesinde değişim için yaratıcı fikirleri olan "değişim ajanlarına" eğitim, yol gösterilmesi, iletişim ağı sağlanması yönetim desteği ve başlangıç için maddi kaynak sağlıyor.
Bu sene de  4 ülkede yolsulsuzluk ve rüşvete karşı bilgilendirme amaçlı ve buna bağlı oluşan açlık, fakirlik ve dışlanmaya yönelik dikkat çekmek için etkinlik
düzenlemektedir. Bu etkinlikler kapsamında katılan kişilerin bu konularda
mesleki ve kişisel birikimlerini ihtiyacı olan toplumlara aktarılması amaçlanmaktadır.
Bu amaca hizmet
eden yeğenim Can Atacık’tan öğrendiğim bu proje, bir insan ve 40 yıllık hukukçu olarak
beni çok heyecanlandırdı ve gelecek için umutlandırdı. Bu projeyi yürüten ve
projeye katılan gençlere destek olmak için ben de gönüllülere katılıyorum.
Accountability Lab
projesinin gerçekleştireceği, sistematik yolsuzluk ve rüşvet nedeniyle halkının ciddi sorunlar yaşadığı, açlık ve fakirlikle boğulan Nepal’de Eylül 2014’te yolsuzlukla mücadele
amaçlı etkinliğe katılmaya karar verdim. Ben de çeşitli ülkelerden gelen diğer gönüllü katılımcılarla birlikte bu etkinliğe katılıp, Nepal’li gençlerin yolsuzlukla mücadele
etmek için hazırladıkları projeleri inceleyip, bilgilendirme ve bilinçlerdirme yoluyla
çalışmalarına destek vereceğim. Dünyanın birçok yerinden ve çeşitli mesleklere sahip katılımcılar  bu
etkinlikte yer alacaklar.
Tüm seyahat masraflarımı
kendim karşılıyorum ve yolsuzluğa karşı mücadele eden Accountability Lab’in projelerine
destek için 5.000 dolarlık bir yardım kampanyası başlatıyorum. Sizden bu kampanyama bağışta bulunmanızı rica ediyorum. Bu para ile en az 2
projenin 1 yıl boyunca tüm gereksinimlerini karşılamış ve yolsuzlukla mücadelede katkı sağlamış olacaksınız. 
Gelin yolsuzlukla mücadele eden genç nesile birlikte destek verelim. Gönlünüzden
ne koparsa o kadar bağışı www.accountabilitylab.org sitesinde bulunabilirsiniz.
Bir yerden başlar, tüm dünyaya yayılır. Hepimiz aynı gemideyiz. Yapacağınız bağışın her kuruşunun cesur gençler için harcanacağından emin olun. isterseniz siz de benim gibi bu çalışmada gönüllü olarak yer alabilirsiniz.
 Önümüzdeki senelerde bu girişimi Türkiye'de de yapmayı umuyoruz.
Projeye destek
verenler arasından Productive Yapım tarafından hazırlanan proje tanıtım
videosunu bu linkte bulabilirsiniz https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yy_v-ce0n-0 . 
Nepal'deki projeler
şunlar: genç Nepal 'lilerin, toplumun sorunları hakkında belgesel film yapabilmeleri
için Accountibility Film Okulu açılması; araştırmacı gazetecilere hükümetten bilgi almada karşılaştıkları zorlukları aşabilmek için el kitabı hazırlanması; pratik yurttaşlık eğitimlerini, okul müfredatına katmaya yardımcı
olacak bir program geliştirilmesi; kamu hizmetlerinden yararlanılabilmesi
için online bilgi sağlama platformu kurulması; ve Dürüstlük Abidesi
adlı, en dürüst kamu görevlilerinin öne çıkartıldığı bir TV programı yapılması. Bunlar, topluca,
toplumsal sorumluluk için canlı, tabandan başlayan ve ülkedeki insanların hayatlarında gerçek
bir etki yapacak bir hareketi başlatacaktır.
Sizi daha temiz, onurlu
ve yoksulluktan kurtulmuş bir dünyaya doğru bir adım atabilmek için bu projeye destek
vermeye, bağışta bulunmaya davet ediyorum. Eminim gençlerin yolsuzlukla mücadele kararı
ve eylemi sizi de umutlu ve mutlu etmiştir. Cesur gençlerin yolsuzluk,
kaynakların yanlış kullanımı ve yoksulluk için hazırladıkları projelere gönlünüzden kopan bağışlarınızla destek vermeyi, onları daha da cesaretlendirmeyi
en az benim kadar istediğinize, önemsediğinize inanıyorum. 
Lütfen bu onurlu yaşam, yolsuzlukla mücadele hareketine bağışta bulunarak destek verin.
Detaylı bilgi
edinmek isterseniz lütfen çekinmeden iletişime geçiniz.
Desteğinize şimdiden çok teşekkür ediyorum.
Şeyda

story:
About

My name is Leslie Rhodes, I'm a film photographer based out of Maryland. As far as I can remember, I've always had the desire to serve others.  This summer I decided to get out there and help.  I reached out to Tropical Organic Farm in El Salvador and asked if I could donate educational supplies to the kids in their school.  They were so excited that I wanted to help.  Since then I have been reaching out to friends and family trying to collect the things they need.

Here's what they requested:

  • 6th grade to high school books (novels, dictionaries, literarture)
  • Art supplies (lots of paint brushes, paints, etc)
  • a drill to build a treehouse for the kids

I'm still collecting things I need but more importantly I need help to raise money to send all these supplies to them.  Shipping to El Salvador is very costly. It would be devastating to be able to collect all the things they need and not be able to send it them because of shipping.  

You can follow my journey on my blog. If you are interested in donating supplies, please email me at hello@leslierhodes.com.

 

About Tropical Organic Farm:

"Located at the site of a past Hare Krsna temple, this botanical compound is blooming year round right in the heart of the El Salvador´s most important agricultural area. The house is surrounded by rivers, mountains, lakes, and even volcanoes! We are looking for volunteers from all across the globe to come here and enjoy the beautiful experience that we cherish every day.
 
 Our mission here is to teach the local children the wonders of organic farming and sustainable lifestyle. Come and share your talents with us, the children, and the other travelers stopping through. Our organic country house (Quinta ecologica) empowers the kids to create environmental solutions in construction, utilizing recycled and organic materials (old tires, trash bottles, rocks, old wood, bamboo, etc.) We are working with the community to promote responsible land and resource management through environmental education, while teaching them English and computer skills.
 
At the house we offer dorms, hammocks and camping spots. We have running water and toilets, tropical showers, communal kitchen, and an out door brick oven onsite. We offer our volunteers internship opportunities as well as affordable Spanish, French & English classes with Gloria, our in-house linguistics professor.
 
We also  rock climbing lessons, biking trips, yoga classes, homemade organic products for purchase (bread, pizza, chocolate, jams, candy, hony,cheese ) and more!  Discover over 20 different tropical fruits, which you can learn how to pick straight from the tree, and almost as many vegetables blooming year round! Experience cooking from the garden to your plate."
 
You can also read about them and see a youtube video: http://permaculturenews.org/2013/05/02/the-organic-bubble-permaculture-in-el-salvador/
 
and facebook here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Tropical-Organic-Farm-In-El-Salvador/108588739265444
 

What I Need and Asking For:

My goal is raise to enough money to ship the supplies I have received from donations to the farm.  The funds raised here will cover costs and any surcharges that is required to ship internationally (fuel surchage, customs, extended area surcharge)

Any funds that I make above my initial goal will be used to buy any supplies I wasn't able to get through donations and pay the 4% indiegogo fee.

If I don't reach my goal all the funds will go towards paying a portion of the shipping costs and the 9% indiegogo fee. 

The Impact

I have learned that there is nothing more fulfilling then to serve others.  To help those who need it.  I beleive that helping me send these supplies to the farm can help a child's education but more importnatly their future!

My dream is help this farm and these children as much as possible and to one day travel to El Salvador and meet them.  Unitl then, your generous support will be able to help get the school supplies they need.

Other Way You Can Help:

I understand if you can't contribute any funds to my campaign  but no worries, you can still help me by spreading the word and share my link with as many people as you can think of!!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read my campaign.  And more importantly, thank you for caring.

story:
Why Young Female Entrepreneurs? 

Women make up more than 50% of the population, but only 5% of all founders are female!

  • Women are successful! Recent Dow Jones research on Venture Backed Companies in the US found those that were successful had twice the number of women on the founding team.
  • Perceptions of opportunity and capability strongly link to entrepreneurial activity - that is, "if you think you will succeed and will be supported, you are more likely to try. In the US and Developed Europe women are 18% less likely to perceive they have the capability to start a business." Harvard Business Review, June 2013
  • "About three-quarters of both male and female entrepreneurs start businesses to pursue an opportunity (rather than out of necessity), but men show more positive perceptions about opportunities and their own capabilities, as well as lower fear of failure." This is despite similar levels of educations and experience. 2012 Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM)

What is Draper University?

Draper University was founded by Free Spirited Venture Capitalist Tim Draper (Co-Founder and Managing Director of DFJ Venture Fund), aka "The Riskmaster", in 2012 to educate young entrepreneurs who want to change the world. We built this school because the world needs more heroes!

  • We are an unconventional boarding school for young entrepreneurs located in Silicon Valley. We push our students to fail and fail again, to go outside their comfort zone and become better business people and better human beings.
  • Use use a combination of lectures from real world practitioners who teach startup fundamentals AND creative, fun topics to provoke your imagination.
  • Help us raise funds for a scholarship for young female entrepreneurs in media
  • You can help young women realize their potential and reach their dreams of starting their own business

What We Need & What You Get

We want to educate more young female entrepreneurs!

  • We are working to raise $5,200 which will be matched by Jesse Draper and will fund a full scholarship + travel expenses for one young female entrepreneur to attend Draper University Boarding Program
  • Jesse Draper is a ground breaking female entrepreneur, she is the creator and host of The Valley Girl Show, and CEO of Valley Girl, Inc. She has produced and distributed over 150 interviews with some of the greatest minds in business, entertainment, government and technology, including Ted Turner, Mark Cuban, Sheryl Sandburg, Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Conner, MC Hammer and Eric Schmidt, the former CEO of Google. Valley Girl has been called "must see startup TV" by USA Today.
  • All funds will go towards a scholarship for young female entrepreneurs, no matter how much is raised.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute please help us spread the word about this great opportunity!

  • Tweet about us
  • Share our message on Facebook
  • Check out our website and spread the Draper University mission
  • Use the Indiegogo Share tools below!
