story:
**Public High Schools are NOT FREE in Jamaica!** 


NOTE:  Donate to this project after our Indiegogo Campaign is closed on Global Giving! http://www.globalgiving.org/projects/send-a-poor-child-to-high-school-in-jamaica/


Campaign Goal: 

Help us raise $5,000 on this Indiegogo Campaign! The Caribbean Education Foundation fundraising goal both online and offline is $30,000 to renew Scholarships and return 20 children to public high schools throughout Jamaica. 

$5 provides lunch to 1 child for the school day.  $25 helps 1 child with bus fare for an entire month.  A $1,500 gift funds 1 child for the entire school year and gives you Ambassador Status!  Please make a contribution Today!  Help us make it happen!

  • The Caribbean Education Foundation, Inc. (CEF) is a registered nonprofit organization formed in April 2007 in Boston, Massachusetts, USA.  We provide meaningful access to quality education for children in need.  Our current mission country is Jamaica.  
  • CEF provides scholarships to brilliant, poor children so they can attend school and be equipped with the opportunities to transform their own lives. Our Paul Bogle Scholarships pay school fees, text books, school supplies and transport.
  • CEF Scholarships are based on high academics and financial need:  each student must complete a Scholarship Application, write 4 Essays and provide Official School Transcripts and Evidence of Poverty.

What We Need:

Since 2010, CEF has 25 students in The Paul Bogle Scholarship Program.  20 of children still need full scholarships to return to high school for 2014-2015 year. 

  • 20 children need help with text books, supplies, transportation and lunch. 
  • It cost $1,500 U.S. dollars or more to send 1 child to Public High School each year.  Children must pay school fees, textbooks, transportation and lunch, including the usual uniforms and school supplies! 
  • The minimum wage in Jamaica is only $50 U.S. per week for a 40 hour work week or $200 U.S. dollars per month. 
  • 90 Percent of funds raised goes to fund our Academic Scholarships, because 4-10 Percent goes to Indiegogo and Processing Fees, 
  • If we reach our minimum fundraising goal of $5,000, Indiegogo will only take 4% fee since we are a tax exempt charity.

SEPTEMBER 2010:  Paul Bogle Scholarship Awards Dinner, Terra Nova All Suite Hotel, Kingston, Jamaica. CEF Paul Bogle Scholars   L-R:  Coya (Wolmer's Girls), Trevisa (Morant Bay High), Amoy (Ardenne High), Sarah (Immaculate Conception High), Ravorn (Calabar High), Travis (St. George's College).


MAY 2013:  Emancipation Park, Kingston, Jamaica.  CEF Paul Bogle Scholars   L-R FRONT:  Christopher (Ardenne High); Amoy (Ardenne High); Garth (Kingston College).  L-R BACK:  Andre (Jamaica College); Sarah (Immaculate Conception High); Ravorn (Calabar); Coya (Wolmer's Girls); Shamarie (St. George's College).


The Impact:

"Education is the most Powerful Weapon which you can use to Change the World." - Nelson Mandela.

Your Impact is limitless.  20 Lives Saved with Educational Opportunity.  20 Lives to transform themselves out of Poverty.  20 Lives to Empower their Communities.  20 Lives to Transform our World.

  • Last year, our SAC Campaign raised $9,000 on Indiegogo and $12,000 overall in Scholarship Funds to send 25 children to high school in Jamaica: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/send-a-child-to-high-school-in-jamaica
  • Our Year-Round Donation Platform on Global Giving to read our Project Reports of the last few years:  http://www.globalgiving.org/projects/send-a-poor-child-to-high-school-in-jamaica/

SEPT. 2010: CEF Scholarship Recipients, Sarah and Coya receiving their Backpacks filled with school supplies at CEF Paul Bogle Scholarship Awards Dinner in Kingston, Jamaica.


The Problem:

HIGH SCHOOL - A CRITICAL PROBLEM (Jamaica Education Report by the Ministry of Education)

  • Over 30% of urban youth and 50% of rural youth have little to no High School attendance. 
  • Low attendance rates are due to a lack of bus fare to attend school.
  • 50% of students are below their grade level. 
  • By Grade 9, hundreds of thousands of students, especially boys, cannot read or write.
  • Chronic poor attendance at all levels is the major cause of the high illiteracy rate, as well as a lack of text books to learn lessons taught.
  • 80% of secondary graduates did not have the requisite qualification for meaningful employment or university programs.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please Make a Contribution Today!  For only $25 you can help 1 child with transportation to school for 1 month.

BECOME a CEF Education Ambassador for $1,500 and Adopt-a-Student!

  • Spread the Word!!!  Please tell everybody you know about our Campaign: your family, co-workers, friends.  Ask them to tell everybody they know!
  • Become a Campaign Volunteer!
  • POST on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and even your own website. 
  • Send out an email, call your family, friends and colleagues!
  • Slip a note under your boss's door - maybe the company you work for would like to sponsor us as a charitable tax write-off?
  • Ask friends to contribute!

Please visit our press releases and website at www.educatechild.org for more information.

PRESS RELEASE:  Read the latest CEF Scholarship Awards news! 

Educate one child, Empower a community...and Transform our world.

One Love,

CEF Team

The Impact:


"Education is the most Powerful Weapon which you can use to Change the World." - Nelson Mandela.
Your Impact is limitless.  20 Lives Saved with Educational Opportunity.  20 Lives to transform themselves out of Poverty.  20 Lives to Empower their Communities.  20 Lives to Transform our World. 
Last year, our SAC Campaign raised $9,000 on Indiegogo and $12,000 overall in Scholarship Funds to send 25 children to high school in Jamaica: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/send-a-child-to-high-school-in-jamaica

Our Year-Round Donation Platform on Global Giving to read our Project Reports of the last few years:  http://www.globalgiving.org/projects/send-a-poor-child-to-high-school-in-jamaica/




SEPT. 2010: CEF Scholarship Recipients, Sarah and Coya receiving their Backpacks filled with school supplies at CEF Paul Bogle Scholarship Awards Dinner in Kingston, Jamaica.
  
The Problem:
  
HIGH SCHOOL - A CRITICAL PROBLEM (Jamaica Education Report by the Ministry of Education)


Over 30% of urban youth and 50% of rural youth have little to no High School attendance. 

Low attendance rates are due to a lack of bus fare to attend school. 
50% of students are below their grade level. 
By Grade 9, hundreds of thousands of students, especially boys, cannot read or write.
Chronic poor attendance at all levels is the major cause of the high
 illiteracy rate, as well as a lack of text books to learn lessons 
taught.

80% of secondary graduates did not have the requisite qualification for meaningful employment or university programs. 

  
Other Ways You Can Help 
Please Make a Contribution Today!  For only $25 you can help 1 child with transportation to school for 1 month. 
BECOME a CEF Education Ambassador for $1,500 and Adopt-a-Student!

Spread the Word!!!  Please tell everybody you know about our Campaign: your family, co-workers, friends.  Ask them to tell everybody they know! 

Become a Campaign Volunteer!

POST on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and even your own website. 
Send out an email, call your family, friends and colleagues!
Slip a note under your boss's door - maybe the company you work for would like to sponsor us as a charitable tax write-off? 
Ask friends to contribute!

Please visit our press releases and website at www.educatechild.org for more information.
PRESS RELEASE:  Read the latest CEF Scholarship Awards news!  Educate one child, Empower a community...and Transform our world.
One Love,
CEF Team

story:
English version below!


Das sind wir:

DIE WUNSCHKISTE das sind wir: Lucia-Maria und Paolo Masini. Als freiberufliche Künstler gründeten wir 2010 in Berlin die „Wunschkiste – Zirkus-Theater und Animation für Kinder in Berlin und Brandenburg“.

Seither übernehmen wir die Organisation und die Gestaltung von Kinderfesten aller Art. Spezialisiert haben wir uns auf den besonderen Zirkusgeburtstag. Als Nebentätigkeit gestartet, können wir als kleine Familie inzwischen beinahe von den Einnahmen der Wunschkiste leben.

Das ist unser Ziel:

Unsere jahrelange pädagogische Erfahrung als Zirkustrainer und pädagogische Hilfskraft in Kindergärten möchten wir uns nun zu Nutze machen und das Programm der Wunschkiste endlich erweitern. Denn von Anfang an wollten wir Kinder und Jugendliche nicht nur tageweise begeistern, sondern ihnen auch eine wirklich einzigartige Möglichkeit der Persönlichkeitsentwicklung bei uns bieten. Bisher geben wir vereinzelt Kurse und Workshops an Schulen und auch Kindergärten. Wir möchten nun aber noch viel intensiver und regelmäßig in eine pädagogische Tätigkeit eintauchen.

Das neue Ziel der Wunschkiste ist ein eigener Kinderzirkus: der Zirkus Wunschikus!

Nach der Geburt unserer Tochter haben wir letztes Jahr außerhalb von Berlin ein kleines Haus mit großem Grundstück erworben. Genug freie Fläche ist also schon mal da!
Für einen Sommerferienworkshop in Berlin können wir in diesem Jahr ein Zirkuszelt mieten. Auf unserem eigenen Gelände und für die Sommerferien auf der Festwiese von Melchow, soll jedoch schon in diesem Sommer ein eigenes Zirkuszelt stehen. Die Kinder sollen auch hier eine richtige Zirkusatmosphäre erleben können! Dabei brauchen wir dringend eure Hilfe!!!

Denn neben dem organisatorischen Talent und dem Körpereinsatz um das alles auf die Beine zu stellen, fehlt uns momentan noch das nötige Geld um das Zirkuszelt und einige Requisiten bezahlen zu können!

Wir hoffen sehr, dass ihr uns dabei unterstützt unseren Traum von einem eigenen Kinderzirkus zu verwirklichen!!

Das brauchen wir:

Für den Kinderzirkus benötigen wir noch mindestens 6000 Euro. 1000 Euro haben wir zusammen gespart. Die Fehlende Summe von mindestens 5000 Euro setzt sich wie folgt zusammen:

Ein Zirkuszelt 3000
3 Lauftonnen 270
Turnmatte 500
Seillaufgerät 900
Kostüme 330

Des Weiteren fehlt uns eine Musikanlage, eine Weichbodenmatte, ein Trampolin, Material für die Zuschauerbänke, Material für die Manegenumrandung, ein Vorhang, Feuerkeulen und und und… je mehr Geld wir zusammenbekommen, umso detailreicher und atmosphärischer können wir schon in diesem Jahr unseren Kinderzirkus eröffnen!!

Das bekommt ihr:

Als Community soll der Kinderzirkus finanziert werden. Als Community sollt ihr auch etwas in der ganz persönlichen Begegnung von uns zurückbekommen!! Lasst euch von unserer bunten Zirkuswelt verzaubern!

Wir laden euch ein, gemeinsam, oder auch in Einzelaktionen unsere Dienstleistung als Zirkuspädagogen in verschiedenen Variationen zu nutzen. Vom freien Eintritt in eine der einzigartigen Zirkusvorstellungen, bis hin zum Einzeltraining bei euch zu Hause, bei uns im Zelt oder sogar einem ganzen Zirkuswochenende bei uns auf dem Gelände ist hier alles möglich!! Wir freuen uns auf euch!
Für diejenigen, die nicht in Berlin und Umgebung leben, bieten wir selbstgestaltete Zirkusmaterialien an, z.B. als Bastelset oder von uns für euch persönlich hergestellt.

Die Auswirkung:

Unsere Vision ist es Kinder und Jugendliche zu begeistern und stark zu machen, damit sie ihre Zukunft selbstbewusst, sicher und sozial gestalten können.

Unser Kinderzirkus soll in erster Linie Freude machen. Das Können und die individuellen Fähigkeiten der Kinder und Jugendlichen sind dabei die Ausgangspunkte.

Wir führen die Kinder und Jugendlichen liebevoll an die verschiedenen Zirkusdisziplinen heran und vermitteln den Kindern einen Freizeitwert, fernab von der heutigen Computer-und Mediengesellschaft. Durch unser vielfältiges Angebot und durch die Freude und dem Spaß an der Sache wird spielerisch das soziale Miteinander gefördert.

Die Kinder und Jugendlichen lernen durch ein kreatives Medium, das sie fasziniert und sie können ohne Leistungsdruck den eigenen Interessen nachgehen oder verborgene Fähigkeiten und Talente entdecken. Gerade auch für leistungsschwache und verhaltensauffällige Kinder und Jugendliche bietet unser Kinderzirkus so eine Möglichkeit, Bestätigung und Anerkennung zu bekommen.

Das Projekt ist in diesem Sinne auch als präventive Intervention für Kinder und Jugendliche gedacht, insbesondere gilt dies für Gewalt- und Drogenprävention. Gezeigt wird ein gewaltfreier kollektiver Weg der Freizeitgestaltung.

So könnt ihr außerdem helfen:

Wenn ihr kein Geld übrig habt um unseren Kinderzirkus finanziell zu unterstützen, könnt ihr uns trotzdem helfen, indem ihr unsere Kampagne online bei Facebook oder per Mail mit euren Freunden und Bekannten teilt!

Vielen lieben Daaaank!




This is us:

The “Wunschkiste” it’s us: Lucia Maria and Paolo Masini. 2010 we founded as freelance artists the “Wunschkiste” – circus-theater and entertainment for children in Berlin and Brandenburg.

Since then we take over the organization and design of children's party’s of all kinds. We have specialized to the particular circus birthday. What started as a secondary activity, now gives enough work that we, as a small family, can almost live from the revenues of the “Wunschkiste”.

That's our goal:

Now we want to use our many years of pedagogical experience as circus coaches and pedagogical assistant in kindergarten, to finally expand the program of the “Wunschkiste”. Because it has always been our desire, not only to inspire children and young people for one day, but also offer them a truly unique opportunity of personal development with us. Until now, we give occasional courses and workshops in schools and kindergartens. Now we want to dive even more intense and regular in a pedagogical work. The new destination of "Wunschkiste" is a kid's circus: the circus “Wunschikus”!

After the birth of our daughter we acquired last year outside of Berlin a small house with large grounds. So, enough free space is already there!

For a Summer Workshop in Berlin, we hire a circus tent. But on our own site and for the summer holidays on the meadow in Melchow should be already this summer a private circus tent. The children should be able to experience a real circus atmosphere here! We urgently need your help!

We have a lot of organizational talent and a lot of power. However, we also need money to pay for the circus tent.

We very much hope that you will help us to realize our dream of our own children circus!

That's what we need:

For the children's circus, we still need at least 6000 Euro. We have already saved 1000 euros. The Missing sum of at least 5000 Euro is made up as follows:

A circus tent 3000

3 bearing balls 270

Turn mat 500

Rope treadmill 900

Costumes 330

Furthermore, we need a music system, a soft floor mat, trampoline, material for the audience benches, material for the ring border, a curtain, fire clubs and and and ... the more money we get together, the more detailed and atmospheric, we can already open this year our children's circus !

That you will receive:

As a community of children circus is to be financed. As a community, you also will get something back in the personal encounter between us! Let enchant you of our colorful circus world!

We invite you to work together, or to use in individual actions our service as a circus educators in different variations. From free entry to one of the unique circus shows, up to one training with you at home, with us in the tent or even a whole circus weekend with us on the site, everything is possible here! We look forward to seeing you!

The effect:

Our vision is to inspire children and young people and to make them strong so that they can build their future with confidence, safe and socially.

Our children's circus is especially to be fun. The skill and the individual abilities of children and adolescents are the starting points.

lovingly we show the children and young people the various circus disciplines and teach the children a recreational value far away from today's computer and media company. Social interaction is promoted by our varied range and through the joy and the fun of it.

The children and young people learn through a creative medium that fascinates them. They can follow their own interests without pressure to perform and discover hidden skills and talents. Especially for underachieving children, our children's circus is a way to get confirmation and recognition.

The project is intended in this sense, as a preventive intervention for children and adolescents. This is particularly true for violence and drug prevention. Shown is a non-violent collective way of recreation.

So you can also help:

If you have no money left to support our children's circus financially, you can help us anyway, by sharing our online campaign on Facebook or via email with your friends and acquaintances!

Many thanks!

story:
What is Farmshare Austin and Farmer Starter

In 2012, a board of dedicated volunteers created the nonprofit, Farmshare Austin.  Together, they sought to create an innovative 501(c)3 that could effectively address the complex issue of food security in the Central Texas area.  As the board looked at the barriers to achieving such security, one in particular stood out: the lack of education programs in the region for students wishing to become organic farmers.  Consequently, the board identified new farmer education as a priority, and Farmer Starter was born.

Farmshare Austin’s Farmer Starter program will start October 1, 2014. The program will be a six-month intensive residential course where students will live and work on an educational farm in eastern Travis County, just eighteen miles from downtown Austin. Students will learn about the science, theory, and business of farming while gaining experience working on the educational farm. The curriculum will be accentuated with workshops that will cover some of the diverse skills that are needed around a farm like carpentry and mechanics. The program will also include fieldtrips to area farms so students can see a variety of growing methods and scales of production.  

Produce grown on the farm will be used to support Farmshare Austin’s food access goals. The Sustainable Food Center’s Happy Kitchen program will receive produce from Farmshare, and Farmshare students will supply produce to a weekly farm stand at Sanchez Elementary School in East Austin.  Farmshare will also work with community non-profit nutrition programs to identify clients for a Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) program. The food access strategy will help ensure that Farmshare produce is used by people who may otherwise lack the means to purchase seasonal organic fruits and vegetables. At the same time, Farmshare students will gain experience operating three distribution models that are essential to local farmers—wholesale, farm stands, and a CSA program. The food access strategy will also put Farmshare students in the community where they will work with partnering non-profit organizations and serve low-income and access-challenged people.

Why Farmer Starter Matters

Aspiring farmers without a traditional background in agriculture have a lot to learn in order to be successful, and Farmer Starter will give them the foundation necessary to begin realizing their dreams. Farmer Starter will be one of the first programs of this type in Texas and one of the only programs in the South and Southwest.

Farmer Starter graduates will play a critical role in Central Texas’ food system. The demand for high-quality local produce is increasing just as many farmers are nearing retirement. Training the next generation of vegetable farmers is essential for the health of people in the region and the businesses that rely on the availability of these products.

Finally, the disastrous effect of the standard American diet is the greatest public health challenge our country currently faces, and, like so many social problems, the burden is disproportionally borne by disadvantaged people. Farmer Starter will be one of the only producers growing nutritious organic food specifically for low-income and access-challenged people in our community. By serving these people during their education, it is our hope that Farmer Starter students will, in the course of their agriculture careers, continue to develop innovative ways to ensure that healthy food is available to everyone regardless of location or income.

What Farmer Starter Needs

Farmershare Austin needs to raise $50,000 this summer to complete construction at the educational farm and give our students the best possible experience when they start this fall. We need:

·  Six student housing units

·  A shared hygiene facility

·  A classroom and office space for students and staff to learn and work

·  Supplies to support the food access strategy

·  A scholarship fund to help ensure that the most qualified students can participate in Farmer Starter regardless of resources.

What You Get

When you contribute to Farmer Starter you become part an exclusive group of people who work tirelessly to ensure that Central Texas has a dynamic, healthy food system for generations to come. The perks for this campaign, described on the right, are designed to welcome you into this community and express our appreciation. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t give to this campaign Farmer Starter needs your help! Please share the campaign with your networks and use the Indiegogo share tools. You can also sign up for our newsletter at farmshareaustin.org/connect and follow us on Facebook and Twitter for information on upcoming volunteer opportunities.

your help! Please share the campaign with your networks and use the Indiegogo
share tools. You can also sign up for our newsletter at farmshareaustin.org/connect and
follow us on Facebook and Twitter for information on upcoming volunteer
opportunities.

story:
All About Operation Christmas Child

Hi there Indiegogo's.

I'm James Brown. A 28 year old New Zealander with a passion for community projects and making a visible difference in the lives of disadvantaged young people worldwide. 

I grew wary of giving funds to charities where I couldn't see or measure the actual impact, so now I'm involved with one that you can!

Operation Christmas Child makes this possible.

 With just a small input you too can contribute and measure the impact to children across South East Asia and the South Pacific. 

Operation Christmas Child fills and delivers to these children shoebox sized boxes with :

6 things to light up the world of a child in need

  • SOMETHING TO LOVE
    Teddy bear, doll, soft toy, etc.
  • SOMETHING FOR SCHOOL
    Exercise book, pencil case, pens, pencils, colouring pencils, sharpener,
    eraser, chalk, etc.
  • SOMETHING TO WEAR
    T-shirt, shorts, underwear, cap, beanie, sandals, thongs, etc.
  • SOMETHING TO PLAY WITH
    Tennis ball, cars, skipping rope, marbles, musical instrument, yo-yo,
    slinky, finger puppets, wind up torch, etc. (No battery operated items)*
  • SOMETHING FOR PERSONAL HYGIENE
    Soap and face washer, toothbrush, hairbrush, comb, hair-clips,
    scrunchies, etc.(No toothpaste)*
  • SOMETHING SPECIAL
    Carry bag, sunglasses, bangles, necklaces, craft kits, stickers, note
    or photo of yourself.

So far through friends and family we have raised funds and items for a whopping 200 boxes. In 2013, over 316,000 boxes were filled by Australians & New Zealanders. This year we want to contribute 1000 boxes to the total, and this is where you come in. 

What We Need & What You Get

The shipping costs for each box is just $9, and you can track the delivery point of your box with an individual code. I personally am funding 50 of these boxes, and if I could cover all 1000 I would!

  • With 200 boxes already organised, that leaves 800 boxes at $9 each = $7200. 
  • These funds go directly to the charity for shipping container costs to deliver the boxes to kids in towns and villages all across the region.
  • In order to help deliver them in person, I hope to fly from Perth, Australia to the closest delivery point, Papa New Guinea in December 2014. Average flight costs are $800 return. If the primary goal of filling all 1000 is reached, I will cover this cost myself. If not, ALL FUNDS will be directed to the Operation Christmas Child charity and I will try again next year...
With your contribution comes some very unique perks, including:
  • Your name hand written on one of the boxes (every 1 box)
  • The opportunity to include a personalised photo or message for each box (every five boxes)
  • A photo sent to you of your stack of boxes to show off to your friends (every ten boxes)
  • A framed photograph of a child receiving one of the boxes posted in the mail (every twenty five boxes)
  • A personalised Xmas box for your or your child posted in the mail (every fifty boxes)

History of Operation Christmas Child

  • The concept of Operation Christmas Child began on 10 October 1990, when Dave and Jill Cooke of Wrexham, Wales were watching a broadcast on Romanian orphanages. They asked the question: How can we help the real victims, the children, who live in these situations day after day? They knew they could not stop the wars, but they could offer something – the gift of love. Together, they filled a convoy of nine trucks with medical supplies, food, clothing and Christmas gifts for children, and headed into Romania, which had recently been devastated by war. This was the beginning of the world’s largest children’s Christmas program
  • Globally, more than 100 million shoeboxes have been given to kids in need in more than 130 countries since 1993

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Spread the word about Operation Christmas Child and help us continue to make a difference every year

    • Visit www.operationchristmaschild.org.au 
    • Share with your friends and family

story:
Our names are Jared Medeiros and Kelsey Johnson, we have been followers of Jesus Christ for years now. Up until a few months ago, we were very selfish Christians, always looking out for what's best for us and how God can help us get what we want. But God exposed the both of us to what He wants us to do -- reach out and spread His love and Word to people who desperately need it. Once we started down this path of helping others in need, God called us to go on this mission trip to Romania and Serbia through Calvary Chapel Beachside. 

On this mission, we will be working with Stepping Stone Missions, an organization that works with gypsy families who live on the outskirts of society in horrible conditions. Up to 12 people will live in a small, one bedroom shack with no pluming or electricity. They are not able to work or attend school, which has become a vicious cycle for generations. Cindy Getchman, the founder of Stepping Stone Missions, came to Romania to feed these children and has created a program to break this cycle of poverty. She has been teaching them to read and write, to be respectful, and most importantly, she is teaching them about Jesus. After working with them for 5 years, Cindy was able to enroll 8 gypsy children into Romanian schools this past year, which is nothing short of a miracle! This September, 10 more will be enrolled.

Even if you don't feel like God is calling you to donate to this cause, please pray for our team as we travel across the world. Prayer changes lives! We really appreciate the support!

story:
The Nueva Student Trip Fund: At Home Around the World!

The alumni currently working at Nueva are excited to launch the Nueva Student Trip Fund. The Fund offers alumni and their families an opportunity to remember their time at Nueva and to give back so others can share in those memories. As soon as preparations for this year’s trips began, we were reminded of how special our own trips were. As Nueva students, we traveled far and wide – to our local forests, the Nation’s capital, and even abroad, and – all by the time we were 13. Even more, we continued to realize the value of these trips once we had graduated Nueva.

Nueva offered us awesome opportunities to explore. Now that we are back on campus, we want to encourage others to reengage. We hope you will be as inspired as we are and consider giving to the Nueva Student Trip Fund. Check out the video to see what our favorite trips were, and please share yours in the comments.

What will the Nueva Student Trip Fund support?

The Fund will provide financial assistance for current students with demonstrated need to cover expenses associated with annual class trips and extracurricular opportunities. Tuition continues to provide trip support for families on financial aid. However, there are trip expenses and additional travel opportunities that are not covered by aid awards. This initiative will ensure that every child is able to partake in all the trips beyond the regular school trips— allowing Model UN students to compete as far as St. Petersburg, Russia and Futures students to travel to the International Bowl. Every gift will have a marked impact at Nueva, and we hope to raise $25,000 by Monday, June 2, 2014. 

What are the giving levels?

Lower Meadow – Up to $9

Crocker Mansion –  $10 - $49

Outdoor Adventures –  $50 - $99

Futures Travel –  $100 - $249

Crow Canyon –  $250 - $499

Washington, DC –  $500 - $999

Yosemite –  $1,000 - $2,499

Ashland, OR – $2,500 - $4,999

International –  $5,000+

All donors will receive a Nueva car decal and a picture postcard from the Nueva trip destination of their choice. Please see the Updates section of our page for answers to the most common questions we've received.

What is the Nueva Trips Program?

One of Nueva's unique hallmarks is the Trips Program and global-learning opportunities provided to our students. The program truly embodies our school motto of "Learn by doing, learn by caring."

Where do students travel?

Nueva currently offers 10 different travel experiences in addition to middle school camping trips and extracurricular trips.

·  In first grade, the trips sequence begins with the entire grade sleeping over in the Mansion Ballroom.

·  Second graders take a two-day trip to Mt. Cross Camp, a 105-acre camp located in the Santa Cruz Mountains.

·  The third grade travels to Memorial Grove Park, near Pescadero, for a three-day camping trip.

·  Fourth graders spend four days at Sonoma County's Westminster Woods -- a unique camp, conference, and retreat center nestled in coastal redwoods on 200 acres.

·  In the spring, the fifth graders travel to Crow Canyon archeological site in the Southwest.

·  The sixth grade goes to Washington, DC, and the surrounding areas, such as Williamsburg, Virginia.

·  Each spring, the seventh grade participates in a five-day outdoor program in Yosemite National Park and goes to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, in Ashland.

·  Eighth graders travel to Spain, Japan, or China, based on the language they've studied while in Middle School.

·  In ninth grade, students travel to Peru to culminate their year.

Are other forms of payment accepted?

Yes! Checks can be payable to The Nueva School and can be mailed to: 6565 Skyline Boulevard, Hillsborough, CA 94010. 

Gifts of appreciated stock are also accepted. If you wish to transfer stock or other securities to Nueva please contact Verna Patti at vpatti@nuevaschool.org.

What else is happening at Nueva?

Please visit the Nueva homepage for other news, events, and photos.

More information on Trips and Global Learning.

More information on the new Nueva Upper School.

Connect with alumni on LinkedIn.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Tweet. Facebook. Email. Thank you so much for taking the time to get involved.


Nueva Faculty Alumni Supporters

Claire Chiaravalle (Conger) – Class of 1999

Daniel Cristiani – Class of 1986

Lee Holtzman – Class of 2001

Zubin Mobedshahi – Class of 2003

Verna "Mini" Patti – Class of 2003

Liza Raynal – Class of 1995

Colin Tribble – Class of 2004

Aron Walker – Class of 1999

story:
Short Summary

Limbics combine pressure triggers and lovable plush characters that come to life with touch. They are digital toys that produce sounds and create a subtly different interaction every time they are touched.

At first all sorts of noises come out of limbics but with a constant touch pattern it settles into one sound. Change the pattern of your touch and limbics' voice will randomize again.

Limbics is the brain child of Dr. Nathalie Prevost (Dr. Thalie). The project evolved out of her PhD research in Cognitive Science on language, population dynamics and neural structures... and a love for the fuzzy and the adorable.

While researching language evolution, from the context of baby babble, she noticed the soothing power of delightful little sounds that newborns of most species seem to produce. It soon became obvious that most paedomorphic traits - new born features - elicit expressions of delight and are fundamentally comforting. Limbics is an ongoing research into the potency of the delightful and adorable for soothing and connecting people.

What We Need & What You Get

Your hard earned money will be used to put on an art show that will promote the limbics brand and perhaps most importantly the healing effects of all things delighful.  The art show will feature ten limbics that people will be able to interact with.  During the show Dr.Thalie will evaluate people's response and establish limbics potential for theraputic use.

To achieve our goal we need $6450 USD.

      - $1500 USD for Arduino reprogrammable circuit boards, Adafruit wavesheilds, Sparkfun breakout circuit boards, conductive thread, and so on, fun fur and of course the eyes.

      - $1500 USD for voice acting

      - $1000 USD for sound production

      - $1200 USD for development

      - $ 500 USD for show production costs

      - $ 300 USD for donor appreciation perks

      - $ 450 USD for campaign processing fees

 

The limbics project offers tokens of our appreciation for your incredible generosity and interest:

$1 donation: you will recieve 1 limbics wallpaper original art for your mobile phone.

$5 donation: you will receive 3 limbics wallpaper original art for your mobile phone. 

$10 donation: you will receive a limited edition 1in button featuring the limbics original art, in addition to the 3 limbics wallpaper.

$25 donation: you will receive a limited edition, giant 4in button that features more original limbics art, in addition to the 1in button and the limbics wallpaper art.

$400 donation: you can have your very own limbics interactive soft sculpture.  One of ten unique handmade specimens, numbered and certified.

Finaly, keep an eye out for the limbics iPhone app Poodidoo, which will soon be available for free on iTunes.  Poodidoo features limbics animated art and is simply meant to make you smile.

The Impact

Dealing with day to day stress can be difficult and tiring and this may be why people love watching cute kittens on You Tube.  While taking a break to watch something that make us feel better is certainly beneficial, having a healthy brain is also about getting our bodies involved.  Touching, in addition to listening and watching is an important part of engaging in the world.  Interacting with a real object that reacts to our touch is also a good way to ground ourselves in reality. Certainly, an adorable little object to interact with can only help to make that reality less intense, as it sometime can be.

As a cognitive scientist and a designer/developer Dr. Thalie has worked on many projects that involve games for brain fitness, training and educational purposes.  Those tools are usually referred to as "serious".  While it is serious business and extremely benificial to keep one's "rational" brain fit, it is also worth keeping our "emotional" brain fit, as well, by involving it in not so serious activities.

We hope that limbics as a project will grow to involve research in the mental health fields, such as psychiatry and psychology and several neuro-sciences.

Other Ways You Can Help

So if you like our little critters and you think there should be more of them in the world, please spread the word about our project and don't be shy about using Indiegogo share tools.

many thanks everyone.

Dr.Thalie and the limbics team

story: I am a 15–year-old Boy Scout from Troop 96 in Silver Spring, Maryland.  I have achieved the rank of Life Scout. As I approach the rank of Eagle Scout (which is the highest rank in Scouting), I am planning, developing and completing a service project which will benefit my community, both locally and globally.  This service project which exemplifies my passion for service to others and making a difference, is consistent with the meaning inherent in the Boy Scout slogan – Do a good turn daily.  In doing a good turn, I propose to participate in the global effort to prevent malaria in Africa. More specifically, I will participate in this effort by delivering and distributing  insecticide-treated mosquito bed nets (ITNs) to communities in Nigeria where malaria has  significantly and adversely affected the mortality rate,  especially  among young children and  pregnant women.  Every day children in Nigeria die of malaria.  As we approach this Season of Giving, please consider giving children the gift of life.

story:
"Very glad to learn about this outstanding initiative, and I wish you the greatest – well-deserved – success."   Noam Chomsky

"Regarding any input I have about your work to demilitarize public education in Chicago, it has my wholehearted support. We should be teaching our children how to resolve conflicts in a peaceful and constructive way."      Roman Catholic Bishop Thomas Gumbleton

What We Are Doing

As militarization spreads across our nation, from police departments to schools to neighborhoods, conflict resolution by violent military means becomes pervasive. Veterans for Peace, an international organization of military veterans and allies, is working to reverse this trend. 

Right now, the Chicago Chapter of Veterans For Peace is pursuing a many-pronged campaign to bring Peace at Home, Peace Abroad by focusing on children and youth and the demilitarization of public education. 

As veterans, we’ve experienced the military from inside, and many of us have fought in one or more of our country’s all-too-frequent wars. Despite the common claims of recruiters, generals, corporate media and politicians, we can tell you that when the military is sent in, they are there to dominate any person or group that is rightly, wrongly or unnecessarily identified as an enemy, and that the military’s core method is violence. 

Domination and violence, and consequently the military, have no place in the lives of children and youth. Our schools should be the bastion for education, not militarization.

Yet, due to the myths, built up over decades, that the military model is about "leadership,"  "discipline" and "service," and that students perform better in military settings, the military mindset persists in invading public schools.   True leadership, discipline and service can be taught in any environment.   The military model, with its focus on following orders without question, is a detriment to development.  If  students are given opportunities, resources and recognition in any classroom, they will perform better.  Getting the military model out of the Chicago Public Schools can be the start to removing the military model from public education nationally. 

We seek to build a movement to remove the military model of conflict resolution by violence from the lives of children and youth in Chicago, and to turn Chicago Public Schools into a national showcase for teaching a well-rounded curriculum for all students that includes cooperation, nonviolent conflict resolution skills and restorative justice.

How You Can Help

Right now, we are working to build broad support for our campaign to educate the Chicago area (and the nation) on the necessity to Save Children and Youth from the Military Model.  We are directing our effort to erecting billboards calling for an end to military involvement in our schools, but we may use other means to get the word out and generate dialogue.

Please help bring Peace at Home, Peace Abroad by ending the militarization of public education. Donate generously to our education campaign, and spread the word. 
Campaign Details
In the Chicago market, it currently costs about $12,500 to keep one full-size billboard up for one year, and that's how we set our goal. Depending on how our "Education not Militarization" drive develops, we may decide to put up more than one billboard for shorter periods or to put up a mix of billboards and digital signs and other media. 
The more generous you can be, the more media we will be able to utilize to educate and generate dialogue in the Chicago area and nationally.
How To Help If You Can't Donate
If you are unable to donate, you can still help greatly by telling as many people as possible about the militarization of education and our efforts. Post us on Facebook and other social media sites. Send emails about us to your contact lists. Whatever you can think to do to help us raise as much awareness (and money) as we can will be greatly appreciated not only by us, but by all the middle and high school students who together we might save from a militarized "education" of conflict resolution by violence. 
Thank You!
story_txt:
"Very glad to learn about this outstanding initiative, and I wish you the greatest – well-deserved – success."   Noam Chomsky
"Regarding any input I have about your work to demilitarize public education in Chicago, it has my wholehearted support. We should be teaching our children how to resolve conflicts in a peaceful and constructive way."      Roman Catholic Bishop Thomas Gumbleton


What We Are Doing
As militarization spreads across our nation, from police departments to schools to neighborhoods, conflict resolution by violent military means becomes pervasive. Veterans for Peace, an international organization of military veterans and allies, is working to reverse this trend. 
Right now, the Chicago Chapter of Veterans For Peace is pursuing a many-pronged campaign to bring Peace at Home, Peace Abroad by focusing on children and youth and the demilitarization of public education. 
As veterans, we’ve experienced the military from inside, and many of us have fought in one or more of our country’s all-too-frequent wars. Despite the common claims of recruiters, generals, corporate media and politicians, we can tell you that when the military is sent in, they are there to dominate any person or group that is rightly, wrongly or unnecessarily identified as an enemy, and that the military’s core method is violence. 
Domination and violence, and consequently the military, have no place in the lives of children and youth. Our schools should be the bastion for education, not militarization.
Yet, due to the myths, built up over decades, that the military model is about "leadership,"  "discipline" and "service," and that students perform better in military settings, the military mindset persists in invading public schools.   True leadership, discipline and service can be taught in any environment.   The military model, with its focus on following orders without question, is a detriment to development.  If  students are given opportunities, resources and recognition in any classroom, they will perform better.  Getting the military model out of the Chicago Public Schools can be the start to removing the military model from public education nationally. 
We seek to build a movement to remove the military model of conflict resolution by violence from the lives of children and youth in Chicago, and to turn Chicago Public Schools into a national showcase for teaching a well-rounded curriculum for all students that includes cooperation, nonviolent conflict resolution skills and restorative justice.
How You Can Help
Right now, we are working to build broad support for our campaign to educate the Chicago area (and the nation) on the necessity to Save Children and Youth from the Military Model.  We are directing our effort to erecting billboards calling for an end to military involvement in our schools, but we may use other means to get the word out and generate dialogue.


Please help bring Peace at Home, Peace Abroad by ending the militarization of public education. Donate generously to our education campaign, and spread the word. 


Campaign Details



In the Chicago market, it currently costs about $12,500 to keep one full-size billboard up for one year, and that's how we set our goal. Depending on how our "Education not Militarization" drive develops, we may decide to put up more than one billboard for shorter periods or to put up a mix of billboards and digital signs and other media. 
The more generous you can be, the more media we will be able to utilize to educate and generate dialogue in the Chicago area and nationally.

How To Help If You Can't Donate

If you are unable to donate, you can still help greatly by telling as many people as possible about the militarization of education and our efforts. Post us on Facebook and other social media sites. Send emails about us to your contact lists. Whatever you can think to do to help us raise as much awareness (and money) as we can will be greatly appreciated not only by us, but by all the middle and high school students who together we might save from a militarized "education" of conflict resolution by violence. 

Thank You!

story:
Short Summary

As the nation's leading organization for promoting innovation and science & technology among Canadian youth for over 50 years, Youth Science Canada is very proud to represent and support Team Canada-ISEF. 

  • Every year, over 500,000 youth take up the challenge of creating a science project at schools across Canada.
  • 25,000 of those youth qualify to compete at one of over 100 regional fairs.
  • Of those 25,000, 500 earn the right to compete nationally at the Canada-Wide Science Fair.

The Top 13 projects are selected to represent Canada on the international stage at the Intel International Science & Engineering Fair (ISEF). In 2014, ISEF will be held in Los Angeles, California May 11-16.

As you can see from our 2011 Team Canada-ISEF video above, these are some of the best science-minded youth in Canada!


(Team Canada-ISEF 2013 members. Team Canada-ISEF 2014 will be selected on March 16, 2014)

Here are the Team Canada-ISEF 2014 members and their projects:

·   Dan Alferov - London ON

Perception of Facial Expression of Emotion

·   Alex Deans- Windsor ON

iAid: A Novel Multimodal, Cloud - Based Navigation System for the Visually Impaired

·   Meagan Fabel - Windsor ON

Fun in the Sun! Increasing Gratzel Cell Efficiency Using Diatomaceous Earth

·   Ben Friesen - Grimsby ON

iSPI: Integrated System for Pest Identification

·   Ann Makosinski - Victoria BC

The Hollow Flashlights - Head and Hand

·   Daniel Mogilny - Richmond Hill ON

Tw-Lexa: A Novel Multifactor Social Media Analysis Algorithm

·   Sujay Nagaraj - Calgary AB

Treating GBM BTSCs through Growth Factor Stimulation and Drug-Polymer Conjugate Therapy

·   Amit Scheer - Ottawa ON

Personalized Medicine: A Novel Quantum Dot Bioconjugate Targeted Cancer Therapy

·   Duncan Stothers - Vancouver BC

Nanofluid CPU Cooling: Novel Block Design

·   Varsha Jayasankar - St. Catharines ON

Identification of Novel Broad-Spectrum Antibiotic Compounds in Curcuma amada

·   Nicole Ticea - Burnaby BC

Isothermal Nucleic Acid Amplification System for Point-of-Care HIV Diagnosis

·   Adamo Young - Ottawa ON

Production of an oncolytic virus enhancer protein using a bacterial and an insect cell platform


We Need

To compete at ISEF, three things are required: 1) a fabulous scientific project idea; 2) hours and hours of research and development to bring that project to life; 3) funding for travel, accommodation and registration fees.

It costs about $2,200 for each member of Team Canada-ISEF to be able to compete at this year's Intel ISEF in Los Angeles. That breaks down to:

  • $750 each for flights
  • $700 each for accommodations
  • $270 each for food
  • $70 each for Team Canada hoodies and pins
  • $30 each for travel insurance

Additional costs include:

  • $2,100 for registration and affiliation fees
  • $400 to ship projects to Los Angeles

The Impact

Your support will have a direct impact on the ability of these youth to compete on the world stage!

Past Team Canada members have gone to become world renowned researchers, successful entrepreneurs & innovators and some have even gone to become astronauts. Team Canada alumni include astronaut, Dr. Roberta Bondar and entrepreneur & inventor of the eco-friendly, electric-powered Uno, Ben Gulak. You can help inspire the next generation of great Canadian scientists to achieve these heights.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support of Team Canada-ISEF is extremely appreciated. A financial contribution will go a long way to ensuring this year's student finalists can maintain their focus on representing Canada at ISEF.

If you are unable to make a donation, please consider promoting our page to your network of friends and family.

The students of Team Canada also welcome your encouragement and support. Please visit us at http://tc.youthscience.ca/

story:
A forever home for abused and neglected Farm Animals

Kentucky ranks 50th of all states with the weakest animal abuse laws.  This has resulted in case after case of high profile animal neglect and abuse.  We want to be part of the solution.

Cloud 9 Caring Farm at Juniper Ridge Farm in Sadieville Kentucky is strategically placed to assist in putting an end to this horrific neglect and abuse.  Please visit us at juniperridgefarm.org for information about our backgrounds and for more information!

A New Barn

The main barn is the most critical component of offering care to animals in need.

  • The project is estimated to cost $19,000.  We are funding the majority, but need assistance with $5,200 to complete the project.
  • In addition to the satisfaction in knowing that your dollars have made a difference in ending animal abuse, we are offering fun rewards for your contribution.
  • We hope to reach or exceed our goal, but any dollars contributed will make a difference. 

Cloud 9 Future Endeavors

After infrastructure is complete and animals are homed, we are planning Phase II to begin in 2015-2016.  Phase II encompasses reaching out to the under-served in our communities who often live in "food deserts".  We will offer  no cost interactive CSA (community supported agriculture) shares and on farm experiences and learning opportunities!

By contributing to Cloud 9, you are not only assisting in saving animals, you are creating opportunities for people who have very little access to fresh and wholesome food and giving them an opportunity to become part of the Cloud 9 Family as they experience the magic of bonding with animals in need!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are always looking for helping hands.  Please contact us via our website to inquire about volunteer opportunities!

Your assistance in spreading the word about Cloud 9 is an instrumental part of our success.  Please be sure to tell your friends and utilize the Indiegogo share tools!

With the Greatest Appreciation,

Cloud 9 Farm Animal Sanctuary at Juniper Ridge Farm

story:
College can be one of the most stressful times in life, especially financially. All College will help relieve some of this stress through being the primary outlet for students to find money saving opportunities. 


Remember, 92% of the 1000 students we talked to said that they want and need an outlet like All College.

Read what The Arizona State Press had to say:

http://www.statepress.com/2014/01/27/all-college-app-brings-community-students-together/


A HUGE marketing opportunity for college town businesses! 

Right now, for small businesses, it's extremely hard to succeed in our economy. All College will put local small business front-and-center, by engulfing them within an online student community.

All College will also help students look for employment and allow them to interact with their peers within their specific university communities. We want to bring each college community together and offer a sanctuary for students to focus on saving money and peer interaction. 

All College is made by college students, for college students! We understand and identified the pain points that students have financially and socially, and have created the solution that they require. Through expansion we hope to be at every major university on a national level.  

"If we can get it to work in Tempe and Arizona State University, we can take that to any college in the world. The concept is duplicatable!" - Former Senior Vice President of American Express, Current Partner at Tech Know Partners, Nigel Brooks. 

This year we also received recognition in:

Phoenix New Times

http://blogs.phoenixnewtimes.com/jackalope/2013/09/phoenix_seed_spot_business.php?page=3

Phoenix Business Journal.

http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2013/09/13/seed-spot-announces-new-venture.html?page=all

By contributing, you are helping us pay for marketing campaigns, programming expenses, and several other start up cost. These will include:

  • Student/Business marketing
  • Hosting and Maintenance fees 
  • Programming fees
  • Rewards and shipping for contributors
  • All College launch event

Contributors:

Parents of students - Parents, ultimately you are the financial support for your child to go to college. All College gives your child the resources to become more financially stable, which can only help you out in the long run. All of the money they save is money you save!

Business owners - As stated above, All College's business model aids in keeping money spent by students, in the local economies across the nation. We want to support the local college communities and their small businesses. 

Alumni - For the alumni across the globe, you too know what it's like to struggle saving money, look for jobs, or even find ways to sell your unused textbooks and other items! All College will be the primary outlet for students, who are just like you were, to save money and find ways to get money throughout college.

Anyone - Supporters of higher education who want to take some of the stress out of the lives of students who are struggling with financial stability. If you know anyone in college or believe in strong education, help students stay in school by allowing them to save money and use that money towards their education or other financial necessities in their life.

                

If you have any questions or are interested in learning more about All College, feel free to contact us at:

Jon@allcollege.us

or

Kijhan@allcollege.us

story:
Greetings friends and family!

We are the Pathfinder Club sponsored by the SF Samoan SDA Church located in South San Francisco.

Pathfinder Clubs are a non-profit community service charity organization that offers a wide range of activities including, but not limited to:

·  Camping & camping/survival skills

·  Organizational & disciplinary skills taught through Fancy Drill Team

·  Grade appropriate leadership training

·  Activities promoting community pride & involvement through outreach activities such as passing out food to the homeless, collecting donations for the disadvantaged, visiting and encouraging the elderly, and MANY more

·  Interactive training in a variety of recreational, artistic, nature, conservation, vocational, and outreach areas, with awards (honors) given for successful completion of the interactive training modules

Our Pathfinder Club has been in existence for almost as long as there has been a congregation at that site, almost 50 years.  This Pathfinder Club in particular services the inner city areas of San Francisco.  Over 90% of our club is children & youth who reside in the Hunter’s Point, Sunnydale, Portrero Hill, and Double Rock low income inner city housing.

Our club is completely based on donations.  Every staff member is a volunteer who is paid nothing in return for their time and dedication to these children.  This is what brings us to you today. 

Since 1985 every 4 years there is an Worldwide International Camp where clubs from all over the world come and represent their home areas.  In the almost 50 years that our club has been in existence we have never been able to attend, until now.

For the first time our Pathfinder Club sponsored by the SF Samoan SDA Church will be in attendance at the Osh Kosh International Camporee where our Drill Team will represent for our San Francisco area.

We need your help, and we need it badly.  These children are more than just themselves, they represent their area, their home, their families, their church, and they represent the history before them and the future that is to come.  

These kids have never been outside the confines of their inner city area and now they have the opportunity to go across country to represent their area, their family, and their pride to a worldwide audience.

The tickets are paid but this group survives only on your generous donations.  The kids, their families, and their communities have worked around the clock fundraising and have secured the over $3000 needed to secure their tickets and now we need you.

We need your help family.  We are in need of new tents, camp supplies, new uniforms, transportation to get our group across country, and emergency and food funds.  Because these children all come from working class families almost all of their parents will not be able to join us as we travel cross country so we need to ensure that we have the funds to provide safe and sound travel and sustenance for them at all times.

Your tax deductible donation ensures that these kids represent right not just for themselves but for San Francisco, and the communities they each respectively represent.

Join us now please every dollar counts and every cent helps as we move forward on our MISSION:OSH KOSH!

story:
BACKGROUND

Gambia is one of Africa’s smallest and poorest nations ranking 168th out of 187 countries in the UN. 48.4% of the population is classified as living in poverty. Life expectancy is 58 years. Approximately 50% of the population is under 15 years. 49 out of 1000 children die before reaching the age of 5 years as compared to between 5 and 9 in the developed world. Malaria is a killer, also Yellow Fever and DIARRHOEA! Young children are very susceptible to this particularly when living in unsanitary conditions.

MAIN AIMS SO FAR

·  To provide healthier environments for the children to grow up in

·  To install protection against malaria

·  To educate the poorest children

·  To empower impoverished adults by helping them with small businesses

ORIGINS

Kotu Kids charity was established 5 years ago by myself – Jeanette Hodgson – although I had been helping poor families in the Kotu neighbourhood before that. In 2002, a 3 year old boy called Didance Jatta befriended me. One evening I walked him home to his room. I cried when I saw the conditions the family was living in and that is how it all began.

Never before had I seen so many people living in such a small space infested by both rats and mosquitoes. Never before had I seen people sleeping on straw mats directly onto the ground with no covers. No mosquito protection! Bare mud walls, mud floors and mostly no furniture, not even chairs or tables or beds. Roofs full of holes where water pours in during the torrential rains of July, August and September. Toilets overflowing with excreta, plagued with flies and used to shower in as well.

For 2 years I used any spare cash I had to improve the homes of 2 Gambian families.


We concreted over mud floors, cement rendered mud walls, painted, bought sponge mattresses, installed or repaired corrugate roofs, provided new floor covering (lino). It was all I could afford at the time until I had the idea to involve family and friends. And that is how Kotu Kids was born.

ACHIEVEMENTS SO FAR

·  5 families supplied with mosquito protection in the form of nets and, in some cases, mosquito proof doors and windows. Nets are replaced regularly as they quickly wear out particularly where small children are involved.

·  9 family homes have received makeovers ranging from a new corrugate roof to building a new outside "kitchen"so meals can be cooked over a fire on the ground but under cover during the rainy season.

 


·  7 families have received regular donations of a 54K sack of rice. Add a handful of vegetables, a stock cube and some small fish and you have a meal for the family!

·  12 children of all different ages from the poorest families are being sponsored at school through Kotu Kids charity. Sponsoring means paying annually for school fees, books, school bags and shoes and uniforms.

·  Caddie Camara, a 5 year old girl, was financed to obtain medicine to control her epilepsy which was preventing her from attending school. There is no facility, training or understanding within the schools to deal with such an illness. Her father was adamant we should try African herbal medicine before resorting to Western drugs and, miraculously, she has not had a fit for 2/3 years.


·  3 women, desperate not to have any more children, were helped to attend the Family Planning clinic and obtain a contraception device.

·  4 people have been helped to set up or maintain small businesses:-Bintu Badjie sells lunches to children outside school, Abdullai Balde opened a coffee shop, Ousman Taxi maintains his vehicle with our occasional help, Ousman Drammeh makes drums and sells them to musicians and students.


·  4 teenagers trained for a total of 32 hours in computer skills. This is not provided by the schools. We want to see these young people getting good jobs and helping to raise their families out of poverty.

·  3 families have been able to move to better, more spacious and healthy accommodation through rent support from Kotu Kids including Zainab Soumah, a disabled widow with deformed legs and 4 children one of whom is stone deaf; the Jatta family of 4 children whose alcoholic father has abandoned them and IsatuJatta (no relation), a grandmother living with her 2 daughters and 7 grandchildren, pictured below in the hovel we moved her from. When she saw her refurbished new rooms (also pictured) she cried in disbelief that she could be living in such a lovely place which had not only glass windows but an electricity supply.


·  Erinjang Nursery school for children aged 3 to 8 years is supported by Kotu Kids. We built a concrete bench running the length of the schoolyard so that children had somewhere to sit to eat their lunches

We bought new mats so the very youngest children could leave their desks and sit on the floor during storytime, we paid for the truck to come and empty the toilets on several occasions and, most recently, bought 20 new desks and benches for the nursery class as the old ones were completely broken.


WHAT YOUR SUPPORT WILL PROVIDE

With your help we can do more than we’ve ever been able to before.

£100 will renovate a run- down family home by filling and blocking holes in walls and floors (most of which have been made by rats entering) painting, installing new lino floor covering, patching roofs, supplying some basic items of furniture such as sponge mattresses and often mosquito proof doors or windows, and carrying out general repairs.

£4 will buy one mosquito net.

£200 will pay for one new corrugate roof.

£250 will significantly subsidise a year’s rent for one family for basic but reasonably appointed accommodation WITH ELECTRICITY! This makes it possible for pupils to study at home and do well at school .Most families in this area live without access to electricity.

£900 will pay for the 3 teachers at Erinjang School to be properly trained so that young children in this deprived area will learn the basics of reading and writing and mathematics far more effectively than they do at present where staff clearly struggle with this highly skilled task. Remember, they are teaching a foreign language (English) which most of the children have very little opportunity to practice outside school hours. The teachers themselves, of course, will benefit by commanding better salaries.

£100 will pay for 4 teenagers to receive about 32 hours training in computer skills. There is no access to computers in the government schools in Gambia .

£40 will pay school fees, uniform and books for one more child to go to school for one year

£250 will pay for a gifted pupil to continue his/her education from the age of 16 to 18 years. This level is optional and not mandatory hence the higher fees. Parents from these backgrounds are not able to afford this so highly intelligent, hard-working pupils mostly find themselves forced to take menial jobs with very little remuneration. Let's help these gifted pupils continue their education and maybe – even - go to college or university!

£200 will pay for around 40 people, a mix of adults and children, to be vaccinated against Yellow Fever (a virus spread through the bite of a particular mosquito) which is still killing people in the Gambia even though it can be effectively vaccinated against. There is a free vaccination programme for children under 5 years but many uneducated parents are unaware of their rights and entitlements or do not have sufficient money to pay for transport to and from the clinic. Many of the families in Kotu are in grave danger, especially as the area borders a river so, in the wet season, there are many more mosquitoes than are found in other, drier areas. Vaccinations cost around £3/4 per person plus transport to the clinic.

£10 will pay for one woman to attend the Family Planning clinic and receive effective contraception for up to 5 years.

 IMPORTANT INFO ABOUT PERKS

Please note that funds raised will be dispensed during my stay in Gambia from November 2014 to April 2015. Following that, I will be sending detailed reports plus photos of all works achieved to our contributors. Expect to receive your promised updates around May 2015.

For those who wish to accept the option of free accommodation in the Gambia, you can see more details of Jeanette’s Belle Afrique guest house by visiting https://www.facebook.com/BelleAfrique13


TRANSPARENCY

Donors like to know that 100% of their money is being used to support the projects and people mentioned above. Since inception, a system has been in place to contact contributors with annual reports from Kotu Kids detailing accounts, photos of any works carried out and full information. It can then clearly be seen that nothing is deducted for administration or any other costs. This system is set to continue.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Please take some time to spread the word. We want to continue in our small yet impactful way. So take a few minutes to use the indiegogo share tools to let people know about this campaign on facebook and twitter and forward the indiegogo link via e mail to friends and family. Thank you, thank you, thank you!
story_txt:
BACKGROUND


Gambia is one
of Africa’s smallest and poorest nations ranking 168th out of 187
countries in the UN. 48.4% of the population is classified as living in
poverty. Life expectancy is 58 years. Approximately 50% of the population is
under 15 years. 49 out of 1000 children die before reaching the age of 5 years
as compared to between 5 and 9 in the developed world. Malaria is a killer, also
Yellow Fever and DIARRHOEA! Young
children are very susceptible to this particularly when living in unsanitary
conditions.
MAIN AIMS SO FAR
· 
To
provide healthier environments for the children to grow up in
· 
To
install protection against malaria
· 
To
educate the poorest children
· 
To
empower impoverished adults by helping
them with small businesses
ORIGINS
Kotu Kids
charity was established 5 years ago by myself – Jeanette Hodgson – although I
had been helping poor families in the Kotu neighbourhood before that. In 2002,
a 3 year old boy called Didance Jatta
befriended me. One evening I walked him home to his room. I cried when I saw
the conditions the family was living in and that is how it all began.
Never before
had I seen so many people living in such a small space infested by both rats
and mosquitoes. Never before had I seen people sleeping on straw mats directly
onto the ground with no covers. No mosquito protection! Bare mud walls, mud
floors and mostly no furniture, not even chairs or tables or beds. Roofs full of
holes where water pours in during the torrential rains of July, August and
September. Toilets overflowing with excreta, plagued with flies and used to
shower in as well.


For 2 years I
used any spare cash I had to improve the homes of 2 Gambian families.




We concreted over mud floors, cement rendered
mud walls, painted, bought sponge mattresses, installed or repaired corrugate
roofs, provided new floor covering (lino). It was all I could afford at the
time until I had the idea to involve family and friends. And that is how Kotu
Kids was born.


ACHIEVEMENTS SO FAR
· 
5
families supplied with mosquito protection in the form of nets and, in some
cases, mosquito proof doors and windows. Nets are replaced regularly as they
quickly wear out particularly where small children are involved.
· 
9
family homes have received makeovers ranging from a new corrugate roof to
building a new outside "kitchen"so meals can be cooked over a fire on the ground but under cover during the rainy season.
 


· 
7
families have received regular donations of a 54K sack of rice. Add a handful
of vegetables, a stock cube and some small fish and you have a meal for the
family!
· 
12
children of all different ages from the poorest families are being sponsored at
school through Kotu Kids charity. Sponsoring means paying annually for school
fees, books, school bags and shoes and uniforms.


· 
Caddie
Camara, a 5 year old girl, was financed to obtain medicine to control her epilepsy
which was preventing her from attending school. There is no facility, training
or understanding within the schools to deal with such an illness. Her father
was adamant we should try African herbal medicine before resorting to Western
drugs and, miraculously, she has not had a fit for 2/3 years.


· 
3
women, desperate not to have any more children, were helped to attend the Family
Planning clinic and obtain a contraception device.
· 
4
people have been helped to set up or maintain small businesses:-Bintu Badjie sells lunches to children outside school, Abdullai Balde opened a coffee shop, Ousman Taxi maintains his vehicle with our occasional help, Ousman Drammeh makes drums and sells them to musicians and students.

· 
4
teenagers trained for a total of 32 hours in computer skills. This is not
provided by the schools. We want to see these young people getting good jobs
and helping to raise their families out of poverty.
· 
3
families have been able to move to better, more spacious and healthy
accommodation through rent support from Kotu Kids including Zainab Soumah, a
disabled widow with deformed legs and 4 children one of whom is stone deaf; the
Jatta family of 4 children whose alcoholic father has abandoned them and IsatuJatta
(no relation), a grandmother living with her 2 daughters and 7 grandchildren,
pictured below in the hovel we moved her from. When she saw her refurbished
new rooms (also pictured) she cried in disbelief that she could be living in such a lovely place which had not only glass windows but an electricity supply.



· 
Erinjang
Nursery school for children aged 3 to 8 years is supported by Kotu Kids. We
built a concrete bench running the length of the schoolyard so that children
had somewhere to sit to eat their lunches

We bought
new mats so the very youngest children could leave their desks and sit on the
floor during storytime, we paid for the truck to come and empty the toilets on
several occasions and, most recently, bought 20 new desks and benches for the
nursery class as the old ones were completely broken.

and floors (most of which have been made by rats entering) painting, installing

and carrying out general repairs.

£250

reasonably appointed accommodation WITH ELECTRICITY! This makes it possible for
pupils to study at home and do well at school .Most families in this area live
without access to electricity.
£900
will pay for the 3 teachers at Erinjang School to be properly trained so that
young children in this deprived area will learn the basics of reading and
writing and mathematics far more effectively than they do at present where
staff clearly struggle with this highly skilled task. Remember, they are
teaching a foreign language (English) which most of the children have very

of course, will benefit by commanding better salaries.
£100
will pay for 4 teenagers to receive about 32 hours training in computer skills.
There is no access to computers in the government schools in Gambia .

one year

Parents from these backgrounds are not able to afford this so highly intelligent, hard-working pupils mostly find themselves forced to take menial jobs with very little remuneration. Let's help these
gifted pupils continue their education and maybe – even - go to college or

story:
I'm going to Grad School, y'all! After sending off all of my applications back in October, and visiting several campuses over the last couple months, I have decided to attend Florida State University in Tallahassee to pursue my Ph.D. in Cellular and Molecular Biology.  Not only does this school offer an amazing academic program where I can fulfill my venom research dreams, but they also offer full tuition assistance and a (small) living stipend (all of these things are actually standard for Ph.D. programs in the sciences as we are not allowed to have outside work while in the program).

Though there is a stipend from the university, the first year especially will be very tight until I am able to apply for additional funding. Also, as part of my contract, I am not allowed to have an outside job as I will be working full time (or more so) for the university.

So, I need your help (and by help, I mean financial support) to help supplement my income so I can do my best to stay out of debt while pursuing my dreams. I am treating this campaign as a gift registry of sorts. I know this may be a foreign idea to most, but I was inspired when I came across an article recently which highlighted how we as a society have chosen to celebrate some life choices extravagantly (weddings and baby showers, for instance) and have not put enough emphasis on our hard-earned accomplishments. Graduate school is a long-term commitment (5 years on average) and just like entering a marriage and starting a family, a lot of support is needed from friends and family along the way.

With all of the expenses below, I'm anticipating I will need an additional $15,000 to cover my move and first year of extra expenses. However, I have only set the goal for $5,000 in hopes of meeting and surpassing that goal as the % taken by Indiegogo is far more favorable that way. Here are the details of the Perks you can contribute to:

Moving Expenses - We all know this can get real pricey, real fast. In addition to the actual moving, I will have a month of double rent (in Austin and Tallahassee), need to put down all new deposits, and have enough left over to cover the first couple months in Tallahassee as our first stipend checks likely won't be available until October.

Healthy Living - This funding will support a healthy diet and exercise plan for both me and my #1 man, Mr. Sheldon (my dog). We all know these are the first things to fly out the window when studying all the time, but I am determined to keep up with my healthy lifestyle. This funding will also support Sheldon's regular medications and vet visits.

Travel & Leisure - Work Hard. Play Hard. Though there won't be much time for it, I would still love to be able to see all of you as much as I can. This funding will go towards airfare and other expenses associated with visiting friends and family every chance I get. I have a miles card with US Airways/American Airlines, so gifting miles is an option too! 

Expect the Unexpected - Sh*t happens. Like needing a new clutch or tires on your car, dislocating your shoulder, your dog needing emergency care, and rattlesnake bites (the former not being true, yet). Grad School is not generally a time money can be saved, so I'm hoping to have a little cushion in the event of an emergency.

You all have NO idea how much your continued love and support means to me. I would not be the person I am today without you and am eternally grateful.

Much love,

Micaiah

story:
About Me

Music has been the biggest part of my life since I can remember.  I started playing guitar when I was eight years old and haven't stopped since.  I'm currently a sophomore at the Orange County School of the Arts' Commercial Music Conservatory as a guitarist and performer.

The Opportunity

My conservatory has been asked to collaborate with the Film and Television Conservatory on live music videos with Ditty TV in Memphis, TN, and to learn about southern music and film.  We will also be doing film work with local youth, and touring cultural and historic sites like Graceland, Stax Music Academy, and the National Civil Rights, and Rock & Soul Museums.

Contribute

This is a big opportunity that I'm excited to pursue, and your contributions will help me get there.  Donations will help pay for the trip's costs: plane ticket, hotel room, guitar and bass transportation, and basically my means of survival while I'm 1,800 miles from home.

Thank You

If you choose to contribute, I will think about you with twinkly stars in my eyes every time I play on stage.

Much appreciated,

Trevor
