story:
Short Summary

Students at CCSF, San Francisco State (SFSU) and University of California-Berkeley, are initiating the "Debt Free Future" campaign in California. This campaign is being supported by the Student Labor Action Project (SLAP) which is a national project and partnership of Jobs with Justice and the United States Student Association (USSA).

 The main component of this campaign is to educate students about student loan debt and organize for more funding from the State for higher education in California. California is #1 in prison spending and #50 in higher education spending, the priorities have to change. Student loan debt is in the trillions in the United States because students have to depend on loans to get through college. Students are faced with rising tuition, textbook costs and living expenses. Classrooms are overcrowded and there is a lack of support services and counselors to help students navigate their classes and be successful. Often after students get out of college they end up in an unmanageable financial crisis because of their loans. We seek to educate students and the entire education community about the impact of student loan debt. We will also lobby our elected representatives to promote measures for college affordability and measures that alleviate the burden of student debt.

What We Need & What You Get

If you contribute to our campaign you are funding:
-Travel costs for students to reach out to other students across California
-Materials and Technology: printing, design, website, banners, t-shirts and other materials to promote the campaign  
-Work stipends for (5) student organizers to conduct outreach and lead activities

The Impact

By contributing to our campaign you are:

-Empowering students to educate other students and formulate strategies to improve college affordability in California.  

-Helping students to unify and build the foundation for a new student movement.  

-Changing the tide of the student debt crisis so that people can have a decent quality of life after they graduate from college.                

-Giving hope to millions of college graduates who are currently in debt and need solutions.

Past Accomplishments

SLAP is committed to promoting equity, student and labor partnerships, social and economic justice and equity. In 2012, National SLAP launched a campaign aimed at Sallie Mae, the largest profiteer from student debt. At USSA’s LegCon, SLAP students were key players in leading a 300 plus student march and protest against the student loan giant, Sallie Mae. The action resulted in the arrests of 36 students engaged in non-violent civil disobedience. On April 25th, SLAP held a National Day of Action to raise awareness that student debt levels had reached $1 trillion. SLAP students across the country conducted banner drops and collected petitions against Sallie Mae’s predatory lending practices.

In May 2012, over 200 students and community allies went to the Sallie Mae shareholders meeting to demand Sallie Mae address concerns over the student debt bubble. The Student Labor Action Project played an integral role in the “Move Your Money” campaign, a nationwide movement to divest from predatory big banks and move money into community based banks and credit unions. SLAP worked to move the accounts of the University of California Student Association from US Bank, United Council of University Wisconsin Students from MNI Bank, and the United States Student Association from Wells Fargo.  

Check out these websites:

http://www.studentlabor.org/

https://www.facebook.com/ccsfslap

http://www.usstudents.org/

http://www.jwj.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word. Without your contribution students can't make the organizing happen. Even if you can't commit please forward this page to your colleagues, friends and family that might be able to make a contribution.

Share Default: the Student Loan Documentary with your community so that future generations have the chance for a future that is free from debt.

story:
So what is this all about? 

My name is Amberly Ellis, and I am a graduate film student at American University in Washington, D.C.

For years I have worked with nonprofits and organizations in Washington, D.C., abroad in the Dominican Republic and at the University of Maryland, to help enhance the opportunity for underprivileged youth and minorities to work with film and media. 

This year, I have been given the chance to tell my own story. I have been accepted to one of the most prestigious film schools in the world, The Film and TV Academy of Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague where I will have the opportunity to make my own film. This is a great chance for me to be able to gain skills that I can share with the communities in which I work, and I'm asking for your help to get me there. 

 

 

About the Program in Prague 

Each year a selected group of students will participate in FAMU’s semester-long program, dedicated to covering various aspects of filmmaking including:

  • directing
  • cinematography
  • screen writing
  • editing

This fall semester, students will have the opportunity to create their very own 35-mm films! For me, this IS the opportunity of my lifetime. The chance to create my own film at such a young age is more than I could have ever imagined. The only thing in my way now is FUNDING. And this is where I need YOUR help.

My Passion 

I am so passionate about film because storytelling is in my blood. Since I was a child, I’ve always been a storyteller. And much of it comes from my family. My grandmother was a writer and my father is a documentary filmmaker and videographer.

I’ve always kept tons of notebooks full of my play, movie and comic ideas since I was very young (see my embarrassing comic book pictures and notebooks here). 

But- WHY Prague? Why now?

For me, there couldn’t be a better place to start a career in film than Prague. Prague has a unique history rooted in film and cultural expression. After completing my master’s program, I plan to pursue my Ph.D. in film and media studies so that I can use what I’ve learned to do another thing that I am passionate about: education.

For the past year, I have taught an after-school media program at Anacostia Senior High School in Washington, D.C., and I also have worked on a computer literacy program with Haitian and Dominican youth in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. 

I believe in the power of media for social change and its ability to give communities and individuals a voice. I am fully dedicated to continuing to learn as much as I can about storytelling through film so that I can give a voice to people that may not be heard, as well as tell my own story as an African-American woman through film.

The Costs 

In order for me to attend FAMU in Prague I need to raise $5,600 to cover the costs of attendance. I’ve received a scholarship that will cover $500 of this cost, but I still need $5,100 to cover the rest of the expenses. I am asking for $5,000 to help me attend FAMU. 

Cost of attendance            $5,600.00

Scholarship                        -$500.00

 Total cost:                       $5,100.00

Giving Back: Why your donations will help me and others

With your donations, I plan to use $100 to go toward purchasing two cameras to start a summer media program when I return at the LeMoyne Community Center in Washington, Pa., the town where both my father and grandmother are from.

The LeMoyne Community Center works toward improving conditions for the underserved community of Washington County, were many of my family members still live. To learn more about the LeMoyne Community Center and the amazing strides they are making in Washington, Pa., please see the links below. 

More questions?

If you have more questions, just ask me! You can send me an e-mail at amberlyalene@gmail.com or even a phone call at (443) 306-8406. I promise I’m friendly and willing to answer any questions you may have! 

Check out my work! 

If you are interested in seeing some of the work that I have already done, please visit my Vimeo page:

https://vimeo.com/amberlyellis

To learn more about the LeMoyne Community Center, visit: 

http://lemoynecommunitycenter.org/
story_txt:
So what is this all about? 
My name is Amberly Ellis, and I am a graduate film student at American University in Washington, D.C.
For years I have worked with nonprofits and organizations in Washington, D.C., abroad in the Dominican Republic and at the University of Maryland, to help enhance the opportunity for underprivileged youth and minorities to work with film and media. 
This year, I have been given the chance to tell my own story. I have been accepted to one of the most prestigious film schools in the world, The Film and TV Academy of Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague where I will have the opportunity to make my own film. This is a great chance for me to be able to gain skills that I can share with the communities in which I work, and I'm asking for your help to get me there. 
 
 
About the Program in Prague 
Each year a selected group of students will participate in FAMU’s semester-long program, dedicated to covering various aspects of filmmaking including:

directing
cinematography
screen writing
editing
This fall semester, students will have the opportunity to create their very own 35-mm films! For me, this IS the opportunity of my lifetime. The chance to create my own film at such a young age is more than I could have ever imagined. The only thing in my way now is FUNDING. And this is where I need YOUR help.
My Passion 
I am so passionate about film because storytelling is in my blood. Since I was a child, I’ve always been a storyteller. And much of it comes from my family. My grandmother was a writer and my father is a documentary filmmaker and videographer.

story:
I am Patrick Bishop, "A real American Hero". I have a beautiful wife and 2 amazing kids who I would do anything for. I want them to grow up in the world that Jeff & Sue Paige, and everybody at Pathways is striving to achieve.

My goal is to be able to participate in the Advance Pathways Seminar coming up in November. The Basic Seminar impacted my life so much that I cant wait to see how the Advance Seminar can make me a better person

With the help from my contributors I will be able to buy food, air-fair, and hotel accomodations. If I dont reach my goal then i will make up for it with my own income, but i have a low income and really need help.

We are all in this world together, and i need your help to make this world a better place

story:
What is Tolleson New Global Citizens?

The Tolleson New Global Citizens chapter was founded by 3 students in 2010. They were inspired by the book Half the Sky, to make a difference in the world by empowering the youth in their community to take a role in solving many of the problems that plague the world. Tolleson NGC picks a grassroots project in a developing country to raise funds and awareness for. This year, Tolleson NGC is sponsoring A Ban Against Neglect, an organization that helps young mothers in Ghana attain valuable job skills, maternal health, housing, and an education. The mothers collect the 40 tons of trash that end up in the streets of Accra, Ghana and turn it into sellable merchandise, such as hand bags and bracelets. With this, they are able to learn a valuable job skill, clean up the streets of Accra, and stimulate the economy in Ghana. All funds raised by Tolleson NGC go to ABAN to further allow the women to make a difference in their own lives and their entire country.

Why we need your help

ABAN needs funds in order to keep the health care, school supplies, sewing materials, and other products that allow the young mothers to make an impact. Tolleson NGC hosts education and cultural events to raise awareness and funds for ABAN, allowing them to join the movement in creating change for the lives of these women. You too can become a part of this growing movement! By donating, not only do you help a young mother reach her goals and dreams, you also get merchandise that is hand-made by Tolleson NGC members! Since the basic idea of ABAN is to take recyclable material and repurpose and reuse it to make sellable merchandise, Tolleson NGC has adopted this idea and repurposes products when making merchandise, such as the book marks, which are made out of cereal boxes, and the pencil pouches, which are made out of slightly used fabric.

Our club's impact

Tolleson New Global Citizens has existed for three years now. Since its creation, Tolleson NGC is devoted to making a difference in the lives of people living in impoverished countries by empowering youth to take charge in their communities to raise awareness and funds to the many issues all over the world. This has proven to be very successful, as Tolleson NGC raised $1,500 in its first year for the Afghan Institute of Learning, which provides women in Afghanistan an education and promotes gender equality, and raised $1,400 for the Shelter of Friendship, which provides housing, health care, food, and an education for the children living in the slums of Brazil, and the Malawi Well Repair Project, which gives the people in Malawi access to clean water by repairing the broken wells in the country. The team has educated over a thousand people about the issues confronting developing countries, and many of the Tolleson NGC alumni have gone on to create ripple effects on their college campuses.

Since the true major goal of New Global Citizens is to raise awareness and educate people on the issues in impoverished countries, we ask that you join the movement and help us educate. Please, share our Indiegogo page with your friends on Facebook or Twitter, or share our student-made video as well!

Thank you for your help! Join the movement!

story:
Le Projet

L'idée d'offrir des séances de vulgarisation sur l'astronomie germe en moi depuis quelques années. En étudiant la Physique à l'université, je me suis vite rendu compte que l'observation des astres était ma passion. Je m'y consacre dorénavent à temps plein.

Le concept est simple:

Quelques heures, à la tombée de la nuit, à faire découvrir la plus belle histoire du monde, la nôtre. Des premières secondes de l'Univers jusqu'à l'apparition de la Vie, j'explique en mots simples toute la complexité de notre monde. Une observation par télescope suit la discussion.

Un très bon moyen d'offrir ces présentations est l'industrie du tourisme. Les voyageurs sont toujours à la recherche d'activités, et l'astronomie en passione plus d'un! Je suis présentement en train de me bâtir un réseau d'auberges et de gîtes sur le territoire du Québec, et l'acceuil est très positif!

Ce projet est pour moi une véritable source d'accomplissement, car il rejoint ma passion pour l'astronomie et la volonté de partager un sujet qui intéresse bien des gens.

Outils

Pour pouvoir faire plaisir à un groupe de voyageurs, quelques outils seront nécessaire. Le 2000$ demandé servira en partie à l'achat d'un deuxième télescope. Je dois aussi motoriser le premier, cela facilitera énormément l'observation. Avec l'argent restant, j'acheterais un projecteur qui servira durant ma présentation.

Contreparties

Avec un don de 25$, je vous offrirai une présentation dans quelconque endroit où je me trouve, un calendrier de mes déplacements vous sera envoyé.

Avec un don de 75$, j'offrirai à vous et 3 autres personnes de votre choix une présentation dans quelconque endroit où je me trouve. Un calendrier de mes déplacements vous sera envoyé, accompagné d'un cherche-étoiles.

Avec un don de 500$, je me déplacerai à n'importe quel endroit au Québec pour vous offrir une présentation, vous pourrez inviter le nombre de personnes que vous voudrez.

Éducation

Je crois sincèrement que ce projet pourra éveiller chez plusieurs personnes une envie de continuer à observer les étoiles. Les jeunes ne sont pas souvent en contact avec l'astronomie à l'école, voila une manière de, peut-être, leurs faire découvrir une passion.

 

Merci de partager et n'oubliez pas de lever la tête vers les étoiles!

-Renaud Mandeville-

story:
Central Indiana, although a leader in industry, agriculture, and education lacks a dedicated STEM-centric museum and learning center. Therefore, why not create one?

The mission of the Indiana Computer and Technology Museum is to provide a dedicated resource consisting of static and interactive displays to engage participants (adults and children) in learning about computer technology and its applications. 

These core exhibits for the museum encompass a some of the breadth of computer and technology applications, and how they relate through history and modern applications, locally and globally. Many of the exhibit materials have already been acquired and are in storage. We're mainly fundraising to build-out real-estate and sustain operations. The goal of $84,000 should include more than enough money for a basic build-out and much of the first year's operations.

Admissions charges will be small, and should be no more than $5 (children) or $10 (adult.) Right now we're also fundraising in base-2 increments.

Computers; growth, history, usage

A visual tour of computers through the last 60+ years. Seeing a tangible representation of Moore’s Law through physical comparison and ongoing demonstrations, both from old machines and new. This should include a timeline consisting of Sun and/or SGI workstations over the past 20-30 years.

A complimentary timeline of IBM-PCs, laptops, and/or Apple computers should also be pursued.

Historical Data Storage

This display would would highlight and describe data storage techniques starting with Hollerith punch card, vacuum tubes, wire-wrapped/magnetic core memory, paper tape, magnetic drum memory and the progression of hard disks from “washing-machine sizes” through current 2.5” laptop drives. As appropriate, these displays would be hands-on, where those visiting the facility could touch, feel, and view the equipment. Lifting a 15” 7MB disk pack and comparing that to a 16GB micro SD card that is the size of a fingernail should leave a lasting impression.

An additional hands-on computer display would be the use of a Frieden Flexowriter (or similar) series data processing system which stores records on paper tape. Someone could sit at the keyboard, enter data on paper tape, then feed the paper tape through the printing device to demonstrate how paper tape works.

Enterprise Computing

This exhibit would showcase modern servers and their features. A Sun Enterprise 10000 could be used to show “hot-swap” capabilities; the ability to turn off a “board” in a computer so it could be replaced, upgraded, or repaired. Literature and displays would discuss highly available computing (clustering) and the differences between that technology and “fault tolerance.” Also, discussion of cloud technologies could also be achieved in the display as well as a discussion of concepts like change control.

High performance computing

Most high performance computing today is achieved through massive parallel computing. A demonstration showing the usage of parallel computing by pushing jobs out across multiple servers to achieve a result would be ideal. This could be achieved with an animation showing a single rat trying to eat a gigantic wedge of cheese. The comparison would be 10 mice trying to eat the gigantic wedge of cheese chopped into 10 pieces. This is analogous to how computer animated movies are rendered and how weather models are predicted.

The concepts of parallel computing do have a rich history and can be exemplified by two servers already acquired, the Encore Multimax and Sun E10000.

The other method of high performance computing comes in the shape of vector processors. Unfortunately, finding a Cray Supercomputer for this kind of demonstration is prohibitive, but an explanation of how this works

Local Computer History

Indiana has a rich computer science history. Purdue housed the nation’s first Computer Science program. Further display and information on Purdue’s CS program could be provided by Purdue.

Although not Silicon Valley, there are a number of local hi-tech endeavors such as Interactive Intelligence, ExactTarget, Scale Computing, Developer Town, and Interactions. Also, there have been companies which have grown from local universities, like Tripwire from Purdue. Each of these is worthy of a small display and literature.

The US Army Accounting center at Fort Benjamin Harrison has used data processing equipment in various shapes and forms since its inception. Naval Avionics (now Raytheon) and Crane Naval Warfare Center also make use of technology. Additional displays can be created showing declassified equipment representing these facilities.

Computer Security and Today

Computer Security is topic of paramount importance, and museum visitors should be able to leave the museum with a basic understand of different kinds of threats and an idea of what a firewall, anti-virus software, and an intrusion detection system (IDS) are. A live display of these pieces of software working together with a SIEM installation

(Alienvault, NetWitness, Splunk and/or ArcSight) can demonstrate threats on a network and a computer. This demonstration would be live, and receive live events from computers at the museum and the network connection the museum uses.

Manufacturing Automation

Indiana is a manufacturing state, and technology has helped drive and expand manufacturing capabilities locally. Ideally a CNC milling machine could be on display and used for demonstrations, as well as a pick-and-place robot. Hands-on programming of these devices would be available as a guided experience to attendees.

Electronics Workshops

Basic electronics workshops designed to give attendees a glimpse into designing basic circuits (how to make a light flash, how to make a motor stop and start rotation.) Ideally using simple project boards or Little Bits equipment (see http://www.littlebits.com/ )

These electronics workshop programs could be marketed to K-12 students and schools as field trip activities or for private parties, or even through summer youth programs (ala “Computer Camp” or “Electronics Camp.”)
